The History of Hip Hop Dance |last=Pabon |first=Jorge |url=http://www.daveyd.com/historyphysicalgrafittifabel.html |work=DaveyD.com |accessdate=July 31, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdUk?url=http://www.daveyd.com/historyphysicalgrafittifabel.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref> Breaking was created in [[The Bronx]], New York, incorporating dances that were popular in the 1960s and early 1970s in African-American communities. <ref>Schloss 2009, p. 153.</ref> In its earliest form, it began as [[wikt:elaboration|elaborations]] on [[James Brown]]'s "[[Get on the Good Foot|Good Foot]]" dance which came out in 1972.<ref name=graffiti/><ref name=creation>{{cite web|title=Breakdancing, Present at the Creation |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=1151638 |date=October 14, 2002 |work=NPR.org |quote='When you're dealing with the b-boys and b-girls, you can take it... straight back to the Godfather of Soul,' says DJ [[Afrika Bambaataa]], who owns a place in the same musical lineage, as the Godfather of Hip Hop. He says that the song "Get on the Good Foot" inspired crowds to imitate the singer's dance moves. |accessdate=September 8, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uZwX237j?url=http://www.npr.org/programs/morning/features/patc/breakdancing/ |archivedate=November 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Top R&B/Hip-Hop Singles: 1942-2004|last=Whitburn |first=Joel |authorlink=Joel Whitburn |year=2005 |publisher=Record Research |location=Menomonee Falls |page=85 |isbn=0898201608}}</ref> Breaking at this period was not primarily floor-oriented as seen today; it started out as [[toprock]] which dancers perform while standing up. An influence on toprock was [[uprock]]<ref>Chang 2006, p. 20. "Toprockin's structure and form fuse dance forms and influences from uprocking, tap, lindy hop, James Brown's "good foot," salsa, Afro-Cuban, and various African and Native American dances."</ref> which was created in [[Brooklyn]], New York.<ref>Schloss 2009, p. 14.</ref><ref>Chang 2005, p. 138.</ref> Uprock looks similar to toprock, but it is more aggressive and looks like a fight. Uprock is also performed with partners, but in toprock—and in breaking in general—each person takes turns dancing.<ref>Chang 2006, p. 21. "The structure was different from b-boying/b-girling since dancers in b-boy/b-girl battles took turns dancing, while uprocking was done with partners."</ref> In 1973, [[DJ Kool Herc]] invented the break beat.<ref>{{cite book |title=Icons of hip hop: an encyclopedia of the movement, music, and culture |volume=1 |editor-last=Hess |editor-first=Mickey |page=xxi |publisher=Greenwood Press |location=Westport |year=2007 |isbn=0313339031 |quote=Jamaican American DJ Kool Herc creates the beak beat by isolating the most exciting instrumental break in a record and looping that section so that the break played continuously.}}</ref><ref name=break>Chang 2006, p. 19. "DJ Kool Herc, originally from Jamaica, is credited with extending these breaks by using two turntables, a mixer and two of the same records. As DJs could re-cue these beats from one turntable to the other, finally, the dancers were able to enjoy more than just a few seconds of a break! Kool Herc also coined the terms 'b-boy' and 'b-girl' which stood for 'break boys' and 'break girls.' At one of Kool Herc's jams, he might have addressed the dancers just before playing the break beats by saying, 'B-Boys are you ready?! B-Girls are you ready?!' The tension started to mount and the air was thick with anticipation. The b-boys and b-girls knew this was their time to 'go off!'."</ref> A [[Break (music)#Break beat|break beat]] is a rhythmic, musical interlude of a song that has been looped over and over again to extend that instrumental solo. Kool Herc did this to provide a means for dancers who attended his parties to demonstrate their skills.<ref name=break/> B-boy and b-girl stands for "break-boy" and "break-girl"; b-boys and b-girls dance to the break of a record.<ref name=break/> Further influenced by [[martial arts]]<ref>Chang 2006, p. 20. "Early influences on b-boying and b-girling also included martial arts films from the 1970s."</ref> and [[gymnastics]], breaking went from being a purely upright dance style—toprock only—to becoming more floor-oriented.
At the same time breaking was developing in New York, other styles were being created in California. The ''funk styles'' refers to several [[street dance]] styles created in California in the 1970s such as roboting, bopping, hitting, locking, bustin', popping, electric boogaloo, strutting, sac-ing, and dime-stopping.<ref name="cipher"/> Out of all of these dances, boogaloo is one of the oldest. It started out as a 1960s fad dance and was the subject of several songs released during that time such as "Do the Boogaloo" and "My Baby Likes to Boogaloo". From being a fad, it developed into a dance style called electric boogaloo and a music genre called [[Latin boogaloo]]. The most popular and widely practiced of the funk styles are locking and popping.<ref name=urban>{{cite news|last=Garofoli |first=Wendy |title=Urban Legend |magazine=Dance Spirit |date=April 1, 2008 |accessdate=October 27, 2009 |url=http://www.dancespirit.com/urban-legend-2326035185.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdWc?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/articles/1755 |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref> The television show ''Soul Train'' played a large role in giving these styles commercial exposure. Both [[The Lockers]] and [[The Electric Boogaloos]]—dance crews responsible for the spread of locking and popping—performed on this show.<ref name="funky">{{cite news|last=Freeman |first=Santiago |title=Planet Funk |magazine=Dance Spirit |date=September 20, 2010 |url=http://www.dancespirit.com/planet-funk-2326048646.html |accessdate=November 23, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdWC?url=http://www.dancespirit.com/articles/2177 |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref>
It is historically inaccurate to say that the funk styles were always considered hip-hop.<ref name=village>{{cite news|last=Seibert |first=Brian |title=Breaking Down |url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2004-10-26/news/breaking-down/ |work=[[Village Voice]] |date=October 26, 2004 |accessdate=December 5, 2012 |quote=Although much hip-hop history is murky and contested, the legendary status of these men is clear. It's the hip-hop label that's questionable. Campbell grew up in Los Angeles. Solomon started out in Fresno, and later moved to L.A. "One thing that came out of the conferences," says Harris, "is that the West Coast faction said they were not part of hip-hop. They got swallowed up by hip-hop"—an East Coast term and movement— "when they had never heard of it." Their moves pre-dated hip-hop, at least in its popularized form, and they prefer the term "funk styles." This concern with definitions and labels is partly a belated response to the international "breakdancing" fad of the early '80s, when the mainstream media and Hollywood latched onto a variety of regional and individual styles, collapsing them into a single trend. |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Cga1jacK?url=http://www.villagevoice.com/2004-10-26/news/breaking-down/ |archivedate=December 5, 2012}}</ref> In an interview with ''[[Vox Media|Racked]]'' Moncell Durden, assistant dance professor at the [[University of Southern California]], is quoted as saying "Hip-hop dance involves two dances: breaking and social dances. That's it. Nothing else is hip-hop."<ref name=racked>{{cite web|url=https://www.racked.com/2016/10/25/13351708/hip-hop-international-world-dance-championship|title=Dance, Dance Revolution|last=Grob Plante|first=Stephie|date=October 25, 2016|work=Racked.com|publisher=[[Vox Media]]|accessdate=April 15, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170331074107/https://www.racked.com/2016/10/25/13351708/hip-hop-international-world-dance-championship|archivedate=March 31, 2017}}</ref> The funk styles were adopted into hip-hop in large part due to the media.<ref name=village/> The media identified these styles as "breakdance" which caused confusion about their origin.<ref>Rivera 2003, p. 72. "With the barrage of media attention it received, even terminology started changing. 'Breakdancing' became the catch-all term to describe what originally had been referred to as 'burning', 'going off', 'breaking', 'b-boying', and 'b-girling.' Dance styles that originated in the West Coast such as popping and locking were also grouped under the term 'breakdance.'"</ref><ref>Chang 2006, pp. 18–19. "Although dance forms associate with hip-hop did develop in New York City, half of them (that is, popping and locking) were created on the West Coast as part of a different cultural movement. Much of the media coverage in the 1980s grouped these dance forms together with New York's native dance forms (b-boying/b-girling and uprocking) labeling them all "breakdancing". As a result, the West Coast "funk" culture and movement were overlooked..."</ref> They were created on the west coast independent from breaking and were originally danced to [[funk music]], rather than hip-hop music.<ref name="funky"/><ref name=village/>
As breaking, locking, and popping gained popularity in the 1980's, hip-hop social dancing (party dancing) started to develop. [[Novelty and fad dances]] such as the [[Who Framed Roger Rabbit#The Roger Rabbit dance|Roger Rabbit]], the Cabbage Patch, and the [[The worm (dance move)|Worm]] appeared in the 1980s followed by the [[The Humpty Dance|Humpty]] dance and the [[The Running Man (dance)|Running Man]] in the 1990s.<ref>Pagett 2008, p. 48.</ref>{{#tag:ref|The Running Man has African origins. It was performed at the [[Fela Kuti]] concert "Cross Examination" in Berlin in 1978.<ref>{{cite av media |year=1978 |title=Fela Kuti – Cross Examination |medium=concert performance |location=Berlin, Germany |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=uMGWx6DjMkU |time=09:20 |accessdate=March 28, 2013}}</ref>|group="note"}} The music of the day was the driving force in the development of these dances. For example, the 1980s rap group [[Gucci Crew II]] had a song called "The Cabbage Patch" that the dance of the same name was based on.<ref>Pagett 2008, p. 33.</ref> 2000s era social dances include the [[Cha Cha Slide]], the [[Cat Daddy]], and the [[Dougie]]. The previously mentioned dances are a sample of the many that have appeared since hip-hop developed into a distinct dance style. Like hip-hop music, hip-hop social dancing continues to change as new songs are released and new dances are created to accompany them.
==Main styles==
===Breaking=== {{Main|B-boying}} [[File:Air chair.jpg|thumb|right|190px|A b-boy in an ''[[Freeze (b-boy move)#Variants|airchair]]'' freeze at Street Summit 2006 in Moscow.|alt=A black and white photograph of a Russian b-boy dancing in Moscow.]] Breaking was created in the South Bronx, New York City during the early 1970s.<ref name=creation/> It is the first hip-hop dance style. At the time of its creation, it was the only hip-hop dance style because Afrika Bambaataa classified it as one of the five pillars of hip-hop culture along with [[Rapping|MCing]] (rapping), [[Turntablism|DJing]] (turntablism), [[Graffiti|graffiti writing]] (bombing), and knowledge.<ref name=kug>Kugelberg 2007, p. 17.</ref><ref name="movmnt">{{cite news|last=Brown |first=Lauren |title=Hip to the Game – Dance World vs. Music Industry, The Battle for Hip Hop's Legacy |magazine=Movmnt |date=February 18, 2009 |url=http://www.movmnt.com/monsters-of-hip-hop-2_003332.html |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdYi?url=http://www.movmnt.com/monsters-of-hip-hop-2_003332.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name=culture>Chang 2005, p. 90.</ref><ref>Schloss 2009, p. 37.</ref> Though African Americans created breaking,<ref name=mambo>{{cite podcast|host=Tony Cox |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6109914 |title=Born in the Bronx: Mambo and Hip-Hop |date=September 20, 2006 |publisher=News & Notes from [[NPR]] News |website=NPR.org |accessdate=November 23, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5uS1LYALz?url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=6109914 |archivedate=November 23, 2010 |quote=Well, [Blacks and Puerto Ricans] lived, you know, they lived side-by-side. You know, previous to this there had been a gang era and people didn't get around so much because it was dangerous. You know, the kids didn't travel outside of their neighborhood so much. But largely thanks to people like [[DJ Kool Herc|Kool Herc]] and [[Afrika Bambaataa]], who started holding jams and inviting people from all over and trying to establish peace in the communities, people began to come together... The earliest and first B-boys were black. When Latinos started breaking they were emulating what they saw, you know, the black people doing.}}</ref><ref name=start>Schloss 2009, p. 16.</ref> Puerto Ricans maintained its growth and development when it was considered a fad in the late 1970s.<ref name=ricanrock>Rivera 2003, p. 75. "...Puerto Ricans had been and were still key in the development of the b-boy/b-girl dance styles; most of the better known breaking crews (Rock Steady Crew, the Furious Rockers, Dynamic Rockers, New York City Breakers) were primarily Puerto Rican."</ref> In a 2001 interview Richard "Crazy Legs" Colón, the president of [[Rock Steady Crew]], commented on how Puerto Ricans contributed to breaking: "I think the difference is when the brothas first started doing [it] and it was at its infancy they weren't doing acrobatic moves. That didn't come into play until more Puerto Ricans got involved in the mid 70s. We then took the dance, evolved it and kept it alive. In '79 I was getting dissed. I would go into a dance and I would get dissed by a lot of brothas who would ask 'Why y'all still doing that dance? That's played out'. By 79, there were very few African American brothas that was doing this... We always maintained the flava. It was like a changing of the guard and all we did was add more flava to something that already existed."<ref name=start/><ref name=crz>{{cite web|last=Cook |first=Dave |title=Crazy Legs Speaks |url=http://www.daveyd.com/crazylegsinterview.html |work=DaveyD.com |accessdate=September 6, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdVC?url=http://www.daveyd.com/crazylegsinterview.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref><ref>Chang 2005, pp. 117, 136–137.</ref> Breaking includes four foundational dances: toprock, footwork-oriented steps performed while standing up; downrock, footwork performed with both hands and feet on the floor; freezes, stylish poses done on your hands; and [[power moves]], complex and impressive acrobatic moves.<ref name=hooch20>DJ Hooch 2011, p. 20.</ref> Transitions from toprock to downrock are called "drops."<ref>Chang 2006, p. 20. "The transition between top and floor rockin' was also important and became known as the 'drop.'"</ref><ref>DJ Hooch 2011, p. 27.</ref>
Traditionally, breakers dance within a ''cypher'' or an ''Apache Line''. A cypher is a circular shaped dance space formed by spectators that breakers use to perform or battle in.<ref name=cipher>Chang 2006, p. 24.</ref><ref name=hooch20/> Cyphers work well for one-on-one b-boy or b-girl (break-boy/break-girl) battles; however, Apache Lines are more appropriate when the battle is between two crews—teams of street dancers. In contrast to the circular shape of a cypher, competing crews can face each other in this line formation, challenge each other, and execute their ''burns'' (a move intended to humiliate the opponent, i.e. crotch grabbing).<ref>{{cite book |editor-last=Weisbard |editor-first=Eric |title=That's the Joint!: The Hip-Hop Studies Reader |page=259 |quote=Uprockers or "Rockers" battle throughout the duration of a complete song—from beginning to the end while in a line formation called the "Apache Line". The Apache Line allows two opposing dancers or Crews (dance groups) to face each other and execute their Burn gestures towards one another. |location=Durham |publisher=Duke University Press Books |date=October 2007 |isbn=0822340410}}</ref><ref>Chang 2006, p. 21. "There were also the 'Apache Lines' where one crew stood in a line facing the opposing crew and challenged each other simultaneously."</ref><ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 129. "The Apache Line was basically two opposing lineups of dancers standing face-to-face doing the step toward each other. This simple shuffle step was done in a repeated manner.</ref><ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 138. "Even the Burns (thrusting motion to disrespect your opponent) and Jerks (dropping down) terminology became synonymous with B-Boy slang.</ref>
===Locking=== {{Main|Locking (dance)|l1=Locking}} Locking, originally called Campbellocking, was created in 1969 in Los Angeles, California by [[Don Campbell (dancer)|Don "Campbellock" Campbell]] and popularized by his crew [[The Lockers]].<ref name=urban/><ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, pp. 33–35.</ref> In addition to Campbell, the original members of The Lockers were Fred "Mr. Penguin" Berry, Leo "Fluky Luke" Williamson, Adolfo "Shabba-Doo" Quiñones, Bill "Slim the Robot" Williams, Greg "Campbellock Jr" Pope, and [[Toni Basil]], who also served as the group's manager.<ref name="Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 41">Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 41.</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.thelockersdance.com/ |work=TheLockersDance.com |title=The Lockers |accessdate=August 28, 2010}}</ref><ref name=train>{{cite podcast|host=Neil Conan |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123532527 |title=How 'Soul Train' Got America Dancing |date=February 9, 2010 |publisher=Talk of the Nation from [[NPR]] News |website=NPR.org |accessdate=November 28, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63CSharBp?url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=123532527 |archivedate=November 14, 2011}}</ref> At the 2009 [[World Hip Hop Dance Championships]], Basil became the first female recipient of the Living Legend Award in honor of her role in giving locking commercial exposure.<ref>{{cite news|last=Agpawa |first=Marirose |title=Just dance: Vegas hosts international competitions |newspaper=The Rebel Yell |date=August 10, 2009 |url=http://www.hiphopinternational.com/living-legend/ |accessdate=August 15, 2009}}</ref>
Locking looks similar to popping, and the two are frequently confused by the casual observer. In locking, dancers hold their positions longer. The ''lock'' is the primary move used in locking. It is "similar to a freeze or a sudden pause."<ref name="Chang 2006, p.22">Chang 2006, p. 22.</ref> A locker's dancing is characterized by frequently ''locking'' in place and after a brief freeze moving again.<ref name=urban/> According to ''Dance Spirit'' magazine, a dancer cannot perform both locking and popping simultaneously; thus, it is incorrect to call locking "pop-locking".<ref name=urban/><ref>Chang 2006, p. 23. "Dancers in Los Angeles also distorted the name by calling it "pop-locking", while in France it was called "The Smurf".</ref> While both styles originate in Los Angeles, locking and popping are two distinct funk styles with their own histories, their own set of dance moves, their own pioneers, and their own competition categories. Locking is more playful and character-driven, whereas popping is more illusory.<ref name=urban/> In popping, dancers push the boundaries of what they can do with their bodies.<ref name=urban/> Locking has specific dance moves that distinguish it from popping and other funk styles. In the 2006 book ''Total Chaos'', hip-hop historian Jorge "Popmaster Fabel" Pabon lists some of these moves which include "the lock, points, skeeter [rabbits], scooby doos, stop 'n go, which-away, and the fancies."<ref name="Chang 2006, p.22"/> In addition, Lockers commonly use a distinctive dress style, such as colorful clothing with stripes and [[suspenders]].<ref name=urban/>
===Popping=== {{Main|Popping}} Popping was created in [[Fresno, California]] in the 1970s and popularized by Samuel "Boogaloo Sam" Solomon and his crew the [[Electric Boogaloos]].<ref name=urban/> It is based on the technique of quickly contracting and relaxing muscles to cause a jerk in a dancer's body, referred to as a ''pop'' or a ''hit''. When performed correctly, each ''hit'' is synchronized to the rhythm and beats of the music. Popping is also used as an umbrella term to refer to a wide range of closely related illusionary dance styles<ref name=pop>Chang 2006, p. 23. "Sam's creation, popping, also became known as the unauthorized umbrella title to various forms within the dance. past and present. Some of these forms include Boogaloo, strut, dime stop, wave, tick, twisto-flex, and slides."</ref> such as strobing, [[Liquid and digits|liquid]], animation, twisto-flex, and waving.<ref name="funky"/><ref name=pop/> Dancers often integrate these styles with standard popping to create a more varied performance.{{#tag:ref|Two regional substyles that developed out of popping are [[gangsta walking|jookin']] (also called ''buckin'')<ref name="funky"/> from [[Memphis, Tennessee]] and [[turfing]] from Oakland, California. Turfing borrows heavily from gliding.<ref name=turf/>|group="note"}} In all of these subgenres it appears to the spectator that the body is popping. The difference between each subgenre is how exaggerated the popping is. In liquid, the body movements look like water. The popping is so smooth that the movements do not look like popping at all; they look fluid.<ref name="funky"/> The opposite of this is strobing (also called ticking) in which the movements are staccato and jerky.<ref>{{cite news|last=Croft |first=Clare |title=Hip-Hop's Dynamic New Stage |url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A37403-2005Apr8.html |date=April 10, 2005 |newspaper=The Washington Post |accessdate=October 11, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206095354/http://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/articles/A37403-2005Apr8.html |archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref>
Popping as an umbrella term also includes gliding.<ref name="funky"/><ref name=pop/> Gliding is a lower body dance performed with little to no movements in the chest or arms. In gliding a dancer appears as if they are drifting across the floor on ice.<ref group="note">The [[moonwalk (dance)|moonwalk]], called the backslide in popping context, is an example of sliding.</ref> Opposite from gliding is tutting, an upper body dance that uses the arms, hands, and wrists to form right angles and create geometric box-like shapes. Tutting can be done primarily with the fingers rather than the arms. This method is called finger tutting. In both variations the movements are intricate, linear, and form 90° or 45° angles. In practice, tutting looks like the characters on the [[art of ancient Egypt]],<ref>{{cite book |editor1-last=Hunt |editor2-last=Ramon |editor1-first=Darnell |editor2-first=Ana-Christina |title=Black Los Angeles: American Dreams and Racial Realities |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Mk7A7bdaELsC&pg=PA121#v=onepage&q&f=false |page=121 |year=2010 |publisher=NYU Press |location=New York City |isbn=081473734X}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2012/07/2-tips-for-hip-hop-teachers-tutting-and-toning/|date=July 1, 2012|title=2 Tips for Hip-Hop Teachers – Tutting and Toning|last=Hubela|first=Geo|work=Dance Studio Life|accessdate=February 7, 2013|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130408013815/http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2012/07/2-tips-for-hip-hop-teachers-tutting-and-toning/|archive-date=April 8, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=jookin/>{{Rp|2}} hence the name—a reference to [[King Tut]].
While popping as an umbrella term is widely used by hip-hop dancers and in competitive hip-hop dancing, [[Popin Pete|Timothy "Popin' Pete" Solomon]] of the Electric Boogaloos disagrees with the use of the word "popping" in this way. Many of these related styles (animation, liquid, tutting, etc.) can not be traced to one person or group. Solomon states "There are people who wave and there are people who tut. They're not popping. I say this to give the people who created other styles their just dues and their [[wikt:props|props]]."<ref name=urban/>
==Derivative street styles== {{Main|Gangsta Walking|l1=Memphis Jookin'|Turfing|Jerkin'|Krumping}} Decades after breaking, locking, and popping became established, four new dance styles appeared. Three of them come from California and one comes from Tennessee. Memphis Jookin' was created in the 1980s in [[Memphis, Tennessee]]. It is an evolution of an older Memphis line dance called The Gangsta' Walk.<ref name=jookin>{{cite web |last=Davis |first=Chris |date=June 2013 |work=Memphis Magazine |title=Jookin – Is it the New Ballet? |url=http://www.memphismagazine.com/June-2013/Jookin-Is-it-the-New-Ballet/index.php?cparticle=1&siarticle=0#artanc |accessdate=February 8, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150906230525/http://www.memphismagazine.com/June-2013/Jookin-Is-it-the-New-Ballet/ |archivedate=September 6, 2015}}</ref>{{Rp|1}}<ref>{{cite news |last=Macaulay |first=Alastair |date=April 3, 2013 |title=Hip-Hop Meets Ballet in One Man's Body |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/04/arts/dance/lil-buck-at-le-poisson-rouge.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=February 9, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131220115854/http://www.nytimes.com/2013/04/04/arts/dance/lil-buck-at-le-poisson-rouge.html |archivedate=December 20, 2013}}</ref> According to [[Dance Magazine|''Dance'' magazine]], jookin is characterized by dancers "gliding footwork... popping and waving... [and] using the tips of their sneakers to balance on [[pointe]]."<ref name=jook>{{cite news|url=http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/August-2013/Mesmerizing-Moves|title=Mesmerizing Moves|last=Harss|first=Marina|date=August 2014|work=Dance|accessdate=September 28, 2013 |quote=Jookin' is an integral part of the African-American culture of the city. Developed in Memphis in the 1980s, jookin'—and other related forms like the gangsta walk, buckin', and choppin'—is a localized derivation of hip-hop dance. Memphis hip-hop has a particular sound, with rat-a-tat-rhythms, and a bit of a soul-funk lilt. "A little southern-ness and a basement-like quality, a homemade feel," is how [Charles "[[Lil Buck]]" Riley] describes it. The dance originated as a kind of walking step with a strong rhythmic bounce punctuated by staccato lifting of the knees, like walking on hot coals. As it evolved, the gliding footwork was added, as well as the popping and waving, and, finally, the icing on the cake: Dancers started using the tips of their sneakers to balance on pointe. |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131002140053/http://www.dancemagazine.com/issues/August-2013/Mesmerizing-Moves |archivedate=October 2, 2013}}</ref> Gliding on tiptoes is fundamental to this dance. While watching a jookin' battle in [[Jackson, Tennessee]], dance critic [[Alastair Macaulay]] observed that "the most evidently sensational feature of jookin is the extensive use of what a ballet observer is bound to call pointwork: the men, in sneakers, go onto tiptoe... many of the men not only rose onto point but also hopped, turned, ran and balanced on point."<ref>{{cite news |last=Macaulay |first=Alastair |date=November 2, 2012 |title=On Point, in Their Jeans and Sneakers |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/03/arts/dance/lil-buck-a-jook-star-from-memphis.html?_r=1& |work=The New York Times |accessdate=February 7, 2014 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20140104084624/http://www.nytimes.com/2012/11/03/arts/dance/lil-buck-a-jook-star-from-memphis.html |archivedate=January 4, 2014}}</ref> Jookers have traditionally practiced their moves at the Crystal Palace skating rink in Memphis, which is [[wikt:akin|akin]] to how [[milonguero]]s practice their moves in public spaces in [[Buenos Aires]].<ref name=jook/>
[[Turfing]], an acronym for Taking Up Room on the Floor, was created in 2002 by Jeriel Bey in [[Oakland, California]].<ref name=turf>{{cite web|last=Zamora |first=Jim |url=https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Architeckz-look-to-build-outlet-for-Oakland-youth-2610783.php |title=Architeckz look to build outlet for Oakland youth / Dance troupe channels emotions through 'turf dancing,' a younger sibling of 1980s break dancing |work=[[San Francisco Chronicle|SFGate]] |date=March 10, 2007 |accessdate=April 16, 2018 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170815063618/https://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Architeckz-look-to-build-outlet-for-Oakland-youth-2610783.php |archivedate=August 15, 2017}}</ref> Turfing is a fusion of [[mime artist|miming]] and gliding that places heavy emphasis on storytelling (through movement) and illusion. Other than [[San Francisco Bay Area]] pride, turfing avoided becoming a fad due to local turf dance competitions and local youth programs that promote turfing as a form of physical activity.<ref name=turf/>
The dance style [[Jerkin']] was popularized in 2009 by the [[New Boyz]]'s rap song "[[You're a Jerk]]".<ref name=jerk>{{cite news|last=Ducker |first=Eric |title=Jerky boys and girls: New Boyz, Rej3ctz and more lead a new youth movement |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/06/jerky-boys-and-girls.html |date=June 12, 2009 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=December 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628r8fTY5?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/06/jerky-boys-and-girls.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=history>{{cite news|last=Weiss |first=Jeff |title=We're Jerkin' (Starring the New Boyz, J-Hawk and Pink Dollaz) |url=http://www.laweekly.com/2009-08-06/music/we-8217-re-jerkin-8217/ |date=August 5, 2009 |newspaper=LA Weekly |quote=Calling themselves the New Boyz, they failed in their first attempt to make a jerkin' anthem ("I Jerk"), but the duo got it right when Legacy produced "You're a Jerk," the song that is to jerkin' what Chubby Checker was to the Twist. |accessdate=December 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206094744/http://www.laweekly.com/music/were-jerkin-starring-the-new-boyz-j-hawk-and-pink-dollaz-2160955 |archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref>{{Rp|1}} This song went viral via their MySpace page before they had a manager or were signed to a record label.<ref name=history/>{{Rp|1, 3}} After hearing about the song, Los Angeles radio station [[Power 106]] hired the New Boyz to perform at local high schools. These shows led to "You're a Jerk" entering the radio's playlist.<ref name=history/>{{Rp|2}} Later the same year, rap duo [[Audio Push]] released the song and video "Teach Me How to Jerk" which showcased the different dance moves within jerkin' including the ''Reject''—the Running Man done in reverse.<ref name=jerk/><ref>{{cite news|last=Weiss |first=Jeff |url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/07/interscope-signs-audio-push-attempts-to-cashin-on-the-jerkin-craze.html |title=Interscope signs Audio Push, attempts to cash in on the jerkin' craze |date=July 30, 2009 |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |accessdate=December 20, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628rd4YTa?url=http://latimesblogs.latimes.com/music_blog/2009/07/interscope-signs-audio-push-attempts-to-cashin-on-the-jerkin-craze.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Dancers who perform jerkin' typically wear bright colors, [[skinny jeans]], Mohawks, and [[Vans]] sneakers.<ref name=history/>{{Rp|1,5}} This trend echos locking dancers in the 1970s who traditionally wore suspenders and black and white striped socks.<ref name=urban/> Of the dance, journalist Jeff Weiss from ''[[LA Weekly]]'' stated "For a youth culture weaned on the cult of individualism, jerkin' is its [[wikt:apotheosis|apotheosis]]."<ref name=history/> Similar to breaking, locking, and popping, jerkin's popularity spread through dance crews. For example, [[The Rej3ctz]] (crew) created both the [[Cat Daddy]]<ref name=newwest>{{cite news|last=Blanco |first=Alvin |title=Rej3ctz Dance To Their Own Drum In The New West |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1662312/rej3ctz-the-new-west.jhtml |work=MTV.com |date=April 20, 2011 |accessdate=July 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206094754/http://www.mtv.com/news/1662312/rej3ctz-the-new-west/ |archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> and the Reject dance moves.<ref name=history/>{{Rp|2, 4}}
Although jookin', turfing, and jerkin' generated regional support and media attention, none have reached the same [[wikt:zenith|zenith]] as krumping. Ceasare "Tight Eyez" Willis and Jo'Artis "Big Mijo" Ratti created [[krumping]]<ref>{{cite av media| people=Shiri Nassim (producer) | date=2005 | title=The Heart of Krump | medium=DVD | location=Los Angeles | publisher=Ardustry Home Entertainment, Krump Kings Inc}}</ref> in the early 2000s in [[South Los Angeles|South Central, Los Angeles]].<ref name=krumped>{{cite journal |last=Pagget |first=Taisha |date=July 2004 |title=Getting Krumped |journal=Dance |volume=78 |issue=7 |page=32 |issn=0011-6009}}</ref> It was only practiced in Los Angeles until it gained mainstream exposure after being featured in several music videos<ref name="bozo"/> and showcased in the krumping documentary ''[[Rize (2005 film)|Rize]]''. ''Rize'' was screened at several film festivals before it was commercially released in the summer of 2005.<ref name=review>{{cite news |last=Gleiberman |first=Owen |title=Rize (2005) |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1072752,00.html |magazine=Entertainment Weekly |accessdate=September 3, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/62AQLq4gU?url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,1072752,00.html |archivedate=October 3, 2011 |date=June 15, 2005}}</ref>{{#tag:ref|''Rize'' had a [[limited release]] when shown in theaters.<ref name=review/>|group="note"}} Clowning, the less aggressive predecessor to krumping, was created in 1992 by Thomas "Tommy the Clown" Johnson.<ref name="bozo"/><ref group=note>Clowning is not the same as the [[crip walk|clown walk]].</ref> Johnson and his dancers would paint their faces and perform clowning for children at birthday parties or for the general public at other functions as a form of entertainment.<ref name="bozo">{{cite news|last1=Reld |first1=Shaheem |last2=Bella |first2=Mark |title=Krumping: If You Look Like Bozo Having Spasms, You're Doing It Right |date=April 23, 2004 |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/articles/1486576/20040423/index.jhtml |work=MTV.com |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206094735/http://ew.com/article/2005/06/15/rize/ |archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> In contrast, krumping focuses on highly energetic battles and movements which Johnson describes as intense, fast-paced, and sharp.<ref name="bozo"/> Of the dance, journalist [[Taisha Paggett]] from ''Dance'' magazine stated "If movement were words, [krumping] would be a [[poetry slam]]."<ref name=krumped/> Compared to breaking and the funk styles, jookin', turfing, jerkin', and krumping are relatively new. The music driving the dances and the cultural similarities between these [[street dance]] styles, the funk styles, and breaking have brought them together under the same subculture of hip-hop.
==Dance industry==
===Commercial/New Style=== {{See also|Tabitha and Napoleon D'umo#Lyrical hip-hop|l1=Lyrical hip-hop}} The dance industry responded to hip-hop dance by creating a commercial version of it known as urban choreography. This urban choreography, sometimes called "new style", is the kind of hip-hop dance seen in rap, R&B, and pop music videos and concerts. From the point of view of someone deeply immersed in hip-hop culture, anything that looks like hip-hop dance that did not come from the streets and is not improvisational in nature is not a true hip-hop dance form. In an interview with ''Dance'' magazine, choreographer and hip-hop dance teacher Emilio "Buddha Stretch" Austin, Jr. described his point-of-view: <blockquote> {{cquote|There are a lot of jazz dancers out there doing pseudo hip hop. A lot of teachers don't know the history, they're just teaching the steps. They're learning from videos, but they don't know the culture. If all you see is Britney Spears, you think that's hip hop, but that's never been hip hop. It's completely watered down. And studios could [sic] care less, because hip hop is one of their biggest moneymakers.<ref name=studio>{{cite journal |last=Wisner |first=Heather |title=From Street to Studio |journal=Dance |year=2006 |pages=74–76 |volume=80 |issue=9 |issn=0011-6009}}</ref>}} </blockquote> Stage performance can suppress improvisation which defined hip-hop dance early in its development.<ref name=graffiti/><ref name=studio/><ref name=jacob>{{cite news|last=Parker |first=Janine |title=Hip-hop dance party at Jacob's Pillow |newspaper=The Boston Globe |date=August 8, 2009 |url=http://www.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2009/08/08/hip_hop_dance_party_at_jacobs_pillow/ |accessdate=August 15, 2009 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206094722/http://archive.boston.com/ae/theater_arts/articles/2009/08/08/hip_hop_dance_party_at_jacobs_pillow/ |archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> Furthermore, meshing different dance styles together dissolves their structures and identities.<ref name=graffiti/> In an interview with ''The Bronx Journal'', choreographer and artistic director Safi Thomas expressed a similar qualm as Austin concerning hip-hop instruction within the studio:
<blockquote> {{cquote|In a lot of studios what you find is people just doing movement to hip-hop music. So if there's hip-hop music in the background, and they're moving, they're calling it a hip-hop class. The problem with that is let's say I wanted to teach a ballet class and I just come in, and I throw on [[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart|Mozart]], and I just start moving—and I'm not doing any of the foundational elements. I am not doing any of the movement vocabulary of ballet. I can not call that a ballet class and that's what happens in relation to hip-hop... within the studio realm there is no standard for the art form, and [the teachers] don't know what the foundational elements of the art are. They know nothing about popping, nothing about locking, nothing about boogaloo, breaking, or the hip-hop dance—[[History of hip-hop dance#Social dancing|the social dances]]—or any of that. They know none of the history which spans over 30–35 years, and so they pretty much cut off any type of [[wikt:edify|edification]] that a dancer can have.<ref name=standard>{{cite av media |people=Sandra Garcia (host) Safi Thomas, Yvonne Chow (artistic director and education director of the Hip-Hop Dance Conservatory) |date=May 20, 2011 |title=The Hip Hop Dance Conservatory Repertory Company |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=vRusg7Jzip0 |medium=Television production |accessdate=October 8, 2011 |time=04:03 |publisher=''The Bronx Journal'' |location=Bronx, New York}}</ref>}} </blockquote> [[File:Hip-hop JCoine.jpg|thumb|right|275px|Hip-hop dancer Joseph Coine performing in 2011 in Wallace Theater at [[Fort Belvoir]], Virginia.|alt=Male hip-hop dancer performing on stage inside a theater at Fort Belvoir army installation.]] The term "new style" was created by dancers outside the United States. According to Moncell Durden, adjunct professor at [[Drexel University]] and director of the film ''History and Concept of Hip-Hop Dance'', the 1992 dance documentary ''Wreckin' Shop From Brooklyn'' was very influential to hip-hop dancers in France and Japan.<ref name=moncell>{{cite av media |people=Durden, Moncell (Director) |year=2009 |title=History and Concept of Hip-Hop Dance |medium=DVD |publisher=DLex Productions/Dancetime Publications |time=31:44 |quote=The reason the term new style came about was because of a documentary in 1992 called ''Wreckin' Shop'' that heavily influenced dancers in Japan and in France. Amazingly enough these two groups of dancers from two different countries began to shorten this term and say 'we want to dance like the New York dancers... we're going to do the New Style, meaning New York Style—dancing like the kids dance in New York. And that's where that came from.}}</ref> These dancers wanted to move like the New York hip-hop dancers who were profiled in the documentary. They called the social dancing (party dancing) they saw "new style" which was short for "New York Style".<ref name=moncell/>
In the context of the commercial dance industry, urban choreography (or new style hip-hop for dancers in France and Japan) is choreographed urban party dancing with studio technique added to it. From a technical aspect, it is characterized as hard-hitting involving flexibility and isolations—moving a specific body part independently from others.<ref name=hiphopballet>{{cite web|last=Werbrouck|first=Debbie|date=December 8, 2010|title=From Fad to Foundation|url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2010/12/from-fad-to-foundation/|work=Dance Studio Life|accessdate=January 13, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131214062532/http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2010/12/from-fad-to-foundation/|archive-date=December 14, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref><ref name=crash>{{cite journal |last=Wisner |first=Heather |date=October 2007 |title=Crash Course: Hip Hop |journal=Dance |volume=81 |issue=10 |pages=82–85 |issn=0011-6009 |quote=Despite their differences, the styles are connected by the music, plus a low-slung center of gravity that comes from African dance roots, and some shared basic steps. Many steps don't have specific names; in class, teachers might speak generally of jumps and turns or use imagery to evoke how a step-should look. Hip hop training relies less on specific exercises than on strength training, flexibility, and learning to isolate and move body parts independently from the rest of the body... A good way to approach freestyling, Sparks says, is to pick out a single element in the music—the horns, a snare drum—and use that as a movement guide... Focusing on the music helps you know what accents to hit.}}</ref>{{Rp|82}}
{{quote box|align=left|width=250px|bgcolor=#C6DBF7|quote="I would say that Toni Basil was sort of our [[Abe Saperstein]] in terms of how she was able to organize us into a professional dance troupe. I remember her teaching us how to count music. She was like, okay, we were like, count music? How do you count soul? It was crazy, you know?... all of our cues kind of went something like this, boom, pop, do boom, pada da boom, pada like that. And she was like, how do you guys get in sync like that? I said it's a feeling, you know?" |source=Adolfo "Shabba-Doo" Quiñones;<br/>The Lockers<ref name=train/>}} A significant [[wikt:juncture|juncture]] in the development of hip-hop was the addition of eight-counts, a method of counting dance steps to stay in sync with the music. [[Toni Basil]] introduced this studio technique into locking in the 1970s. Basil was trained in ballet before being introduced to street dance by Don Campbell, the creator of locking and founding member of [[The Lockers]] dance crew.<ref name=urban/> She is responsible for teaching the rest of The Lockers how to dance to counts. Traditionally hip-hop dance, or any form of [[street dance]], is not performed to counts as these styles were created on the street rather than in a studio setting. Therefore, the introduction of counts was a pivotal move into bringing hip-hop dance from the street into the studio. Even with this addition, it would be years before commercial hip-hop developed into its current form.
A second important event in the development of hip-hop was the start of hip-hop dance instruction. Buddha Stretch was a pioneer in this field. He started teaching formal hip-hop dance classes in 1989 at [[Broadway Dance Center]] in New York City where he continues to teach today.<ref>{{cite web |title=Buddha Stretch Faculty Bio |url=http://www.broadwaydancecenter.com/faculty/bios/stretch_buddha.shtml |work=BroadwayDanceCenter.com |accessdate=August 13, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130622174924/http://www.broadwaydancecenter.com/faculty/bios/stretch_buddha.shtml |archivedate=June 22, 2013 |dead-url=no |df=mdy-all }}</ref> Around the same time, hip-hop party dancing started to appear in music videos and on television—this was another important point in the development and commercialization of hip-hop. An early example of this is when Janet Jackson performed the Running Man in her 1989 music video for the song "[[Rhythm Nation]]" which was choreographed by street dancer Anthony Thomas.<ref name=anthony>{{cite book|first1=Stephanie|last1=Jordan|first2=Dave|last2=Allen |title=Parallel Lines: Media Representations of Dance|publisher=John Libbey Publishing|location=London|year=1993|page=68 |isbn=9780861963713 |quote=Through her choice of Anthony Thomas, a black American street dancer, as her choreographer, Janet Jackson secures a threefold achievement: she satisfies the dictates of commercial pop music industry by creating a dance image which is significantly different from her earlier work; she demonstrates that, despite fame, she is still in touch with contemporary youth pop culture and its fashions; and finally, she utilizes, not the dance traditions of the Hollywood musical which, although often black in inspiration, remained very much under the control of white choreographers, but the work of a black young man whose training is outside the institutions of Western theatre and clearly an Afro-American cultural expression of the late 1980s.}}</ref> The dance was so popular during this time it was also performed by 1990s rappers [[MC Hammer]] and [[Vanilla Ice]] in their choreographed routines.<ref>{{cite news|last=Robertson |first=Regina |title=Throwback: The Running Man |url=http://www.essence.com/2010/02/02/throwback-the-running-man/ |work=Essence |date=February 2, 2012 |accessdate=August 14, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69tZtkEWJ?url=http://www.essence.com/2010/02/02/throwback-the-running-man/ |archivedate=August 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Michael Jackson also used hip-hop in his 1992 music video "[[Remember The Time]]" which was choreographed by a then 21-year-old [[Fatima Robinson]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Fatima Robinson—director, choreographer |url=http://stylelikeu.com/closets/fatima-robinson/ |work=StyleLikeU.com |accessdate=June 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130706015701/http://stylelikeu.com/closets/fatima-robinson/ |archivedate=July 6, 2013}}</ref> At the time, Robinson was a street dancer with no formal training and "Remember the Time" was her first music video job.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bloom |first=Julie |date=November 26, 2006 |title=Supreme Commander |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/26/arts/dance/26bloo.html |work=The New York Times |accessdate=May 31, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061202090451/http://www.nytimes.com/2006/11/26/arts/dance/26bloo.html |archivedate=December 2, 2006}}</ref> According to MTV.com, "Dances have always been a part of hip-hop culture — from the running man to the Soulja Boy dance..."<ref name=newwest/> and this era was the start of commercial hip-hop choreography as it looks today: dance routines are not specific to one genre (strictly popping, strictly locking, or strictly breaking) but rather an [[wikt:amalgamation|amalgamation]] of urban party dancing with studio technique added to it.
===Jazz-funk=== Another style the dance industry created in response to hip-hop was ''jazz-funk''. This style was shown in its early form on a sketch comedy series called ''[[In Living Color]]''.<ref name=flygirls>{{cite journal|last=Smith|first=Dinitia|title=Color Them Funny: TV's New Black Comedy Hit|journal=New York Magazine|date=October 8, 1990|volume=23|issue=39|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h7VasQrBnm8C&pg=PA28|page=35|issn=0028-7369|quote=Opening and closing the show are the Fly Girls, dancers clothed in brilliant colors who erupt on stage to a strong, sexy beat and who dance a blend of hip hop and jazz. 'A Fly Girl,' says Rosie Perez, the show's choreographer, 'is, first, someone who looks good. Second, she has the brains to complement it. She's got what's goin' on!'}}</ref> The resident dance troupe, The Fly Girls, opened and closed every show with a hip-hop and jazz performance choreographed by [[Rosie Perez]].<ref name=flygirls/> Jazz-funk (also called street-jazz) is a hybrid of hip-hop and [[jazz dance]].<ref name="funky"/> R&B singer [[Beyoncé Knowles|Beyoncé]] uses this style.<ref name="funky"/> Korean dance crew Prepix also uses this style.<ref name=prepix/> They have choreographed for [[K-pop]] singers [[Jay Park]] and [[G.NA]] as well as for K-pop boy bands [[2PM]] and [[Beast (South Korean band)|B2ST]].<ref name=prepix>{{cite web|title=Dancing Away with Prepix |url=http://seoulbeats.com/2012/05/dancing-away-with-prepix/ |work=SeoulBeats.com |date=May 3, 2012 |accessdate=June 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QRlzDIZ?url=http://seoulbeats.com/2012/05/dancing-away-with-prepix/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Although jazz-funk borrows from hip-hop dance, it is not considered a style of hip-hop because the foundational movements are jazz. In hip-hop—even in [[lyrical hip-hop]]—there are no [[Glossary of ballet#Pirouette|pirouettes]] or [[Arabesque (ballet position)|arabesques]] and dancers do not perform on [[Glossary of ballet#Relevé|relevé]] (on the balls of the feet). However, these methods are used in jazz-funk and in jazz dance in general.<ref name="funky"/>
===Business developments=== Other developments in the dance industry occurred in response to the growing popularity of hip-hop. On the traveling convention circuit there were tap, ballet, and jazz dance conventions, but there were none specifically for hip-hop. The same void existed in dancewear. There was dancewear for tap, ballet, and jazz dancers but none for hip-hop dancers. Monsters of Hip Hop and Nappytabs dancewear were formed to answer to both needs. Nappytabs is the first line of hip-hop dancewear.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Krisanits |first=Tracy |date=March 2007 |title=Keeping Tabs |journal=Dance Retailer News |volume= |issue=5 |page=46 |issn=1541-0307}}</ref> Because their clothing is made for hip-hop dancers, they do not sell [[leotard]]s, [[unitard]]s, tights, or [[leg warmer]]s. Their line consists of tank tops, shorts, t-shirts, sweat pants, [[harem pants]], and [[hoodie]]s. Monsters of Hip Hop (MOHH) was founded in 2003 in Baltimore, Maryland by Andy Funk, Becky Funk, and Angie Servant.<ref>{{cite web|title=About Us |url=http://www.monstersofhiphop.com/about/ |work=MonstersofHipHop.com |accessdate=August 1, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdbv?url=http://www.monstersofhiphop.com/about/ |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The convention is dedicated exclusively to hip-hop instruction.<ref name=funkmonster>{{cite web|url=http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2007/09/how-funk-created-a-monster/|title=How Funk Created a Monster|last=Wisner|first=Heather|date=September 1, 2007|work=Dance Studio Life|accessdate=January 22, 2012|archive-url=https://archive.is/20130120055112/http://www.dancestudiolife.com/2007/09/how-funk-created-a-monster/|archive-date=January 20, 2013|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> [[Fatima Robinson]], Stefan "[[Mr. Wiggles]]" Clemente, and Timothy "Popin' Pete" Solomon have taught classes at MOHH in the past.<ref name=funkmonster/> Every year, the convention brings together its top student dancers for a professionally choreographed showcase in Los Angeles called ''Monsters of Hip Hop: The Show''.<ref>{{cite press release|title=Monsters of Hip Hop: The Show Hits Los Angeles; Directed by Tabitha and Napoleon Dumo!|publisher=PRLog|date=August 4, 2008|url=http://www.prlog.org/10098936-monsters-of-hip-hop-the-show-hits-los-angeles-directed-by-tabitha-and-napoleon-dumo.html|accessdate=January 22, 2012}}</ref>
MOHH may have been the first hip-hop dance convention, but it is not the only one that exists. Urban Dance Camp (UDC) is a six-week-long German-based dance convention held every year in [[Lörrach]], a small town on the border of France and Switzerland.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urbandance.eu/camp/ |title=Urban Dance Camp|work=UrbanDance.eu|accessdate=January 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130312110201/http://www.urbandance.eu/camp/ |archivedate=March 12, 2013}}</ref> In a report on the event by a local paper, Bettina Kraft, the manager of UDC, estimated that 85% of the participants were from outside Germany. In 2009 Kraft created Urban Dance Showcase, a parallel event to UDC reserved only for performances by professional choreographers, dance crews, and UDC teachers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.badische-zeitung.de/loerrach/loerrach-der-nabel-der-urbanen-tanzwelt--18584092.html |title=Lörrach der Nabel der urbanen Tanzwelt |last=Ruda |first=Barbara |date=August 21, 2009 |work=Badische Zzeitung |accessdate=January 30, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6E3if6r59?url=http://www.badische-zeitung.de/loerrach/loerrach-der-nabel-der-urbanen-tanzwelt--18584092.html |archivedate=January 30, 2013 |language=de |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Dancers such as [[Shaun Evaristo]], [[Les Twins]], [[I.aM.mE]], [[b-boy Lilou]], and b-boy [[Hong 10]] have performed at the showcase in the past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urbandance.eu/show/artists/|title=Artists & Crews 2012|work=UrbanDance.eu|accessdate=January 30, 2013|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131208024641/http://www.urbandance.eu/show/artists/|archivedate=December 8, 2013}}</ref>
Aside from dancewear and conventions, developments in agency representation occurred as well. Although limited, representation for individual dancers had existed since the 1980s at the beginning of the music video era due to the pioneering work of talent agent [[Julie McDonald (agent)|Julie McDonald]].{{#tag:ref|Representation for dance ''groups'' existed before the music video era. In the 1970s, The Lockers were represented by [[ICM Partners|ICM Talent Agency]].<ref name="Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 41"/>|group="note"}} However, the UK-based dance agencies ProDance and Superbad Talent were created to exclusively represent street dancers.<ref>{{cite web|title=Kymberlee Jay launches street dance agency Superbad Talent off Serious About Street Dance |url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/04/06/kymberlee-jay-launches-street-dance-agency-superbad-talent-off-serious-about-street-dance/ |work=AllStreetDance.co.uk |accessdate=September 7, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6AULk1e4k?url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/04/06/kymberlee-jay-launches-street-dance-agency-superbad-talent-off-serious-about-street-dance/ |archivedate=September 7, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=About Us |url=http://www.prodance.co.uk/aboutus.php |work=ProDance.co.uk |accessdate=September 7, 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120815045157/http://www.prodance.co.uk/aboutus.php |archive-date=August 15, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref>
==Entertainment==
===Movies=== The entertainment industry has been largely responsible for introducing hip-hop dance to mainstream audiences around the world. The first hip-hop films ''[[Wild Style]]'', ''[[Beat Street]]'', and ''[[Breakin']]'' were made in the 1980s. When ''Wild Style'' opened in Japan, Rock Steady Crew performed breaking in Tokyo's [[Harajuku]] shopping district to promote the film.<ref>Chang 2005, p. 189.</ref> ''Wild Style'' was the first movie centered around hip-hop culture; however, ''[[Flashdance]]'' was the first commercially released film to feature breaking.<ref name=flash>Kugelberg 2007, p. 59.</ref>{{#tag:ref|''Wild Style'' was produced in New York City and independently released.<ref name=flash/>|group="note"}} In 1984, ''[[Beat Street]]'' was released in [[West Germany]] and screened at the [[Cannes Film Festival]] which helped to introduce breaking, graffiti writing, and [[turntablism]] to this part of Europe.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.festival-cannes.com/en/archives/ficheFilm/id/1297/year/1984.html |title=Festival de Cannes: Beat Street |accessdate=December 6, 2012 |work=Festival-Cannes.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Elflein |first=Dietmar |date=October 1998 |title=From Krauts with Attitudes to Turks with Attitudes: Some Aspects of Hip-Hop History in Germany |journal=Popular Music |volume=17 |issue=3 |pages=255–265 |doi=10.1017/S0261143000008539}}</ref> ''Breakin''' and ''[[Breakin' 2: Electric Boogaloo]]'' brought the funk styles to the cinema. Breaking, locking, popping, and [[waacking]] were performed in these films.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Christian|first=Margena|date=January 21, 2008|title=Where Are... SHABBA-DOO & BOOGALOO SHRIMP?|journal=Jet|volume=113|issue=2|page=22|issn=0021-5996}}</ref> At this time in the 1980s, the United States was not the only country producing hip-hop films. In 1985, [[Yuen Woo-ping]] directed a hip-hop themed romantic comedy in Hong Kong called ''[[Mismatched Couples]]'' starring [[Donnie Yen]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Mismatched Couples (1985) |url=http://www.hkmdb.com/db/movies/view.mhtml?id=6679&display_set=eng |work=HKMDB.com |accessdate=December 8, 2012}}</ref> Another hip-hop film, ''Electro Rock'', was released the same year in the United Kingdom.<ref name=bubbles>{{cite news|author=Calvin |title=The Lady In Red: Bubbles |url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2010/10/the-lady-in-red-bubbles/ |work=More Than a Stance |date=October 18, 2010 |accessdate=June 26, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69S5tatDG?url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2010/10/the-lady-in-red-bubbles/ |archivedate=July 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> This film featured a then 14-year-old Hanifa "Bubbles" McQueen Hudson, the UK's first b-girl.<ref name=bubbles/>
Several hip-hop dance films were produced after the millennium. ''The Freshest Kids: A History of the B-Boy'', ''[[Neukölln Unlimited]]'', ''B-Girl'', ''[[Bouncing Cats]]'', ''[[Planet B-Boy]]'', and ''[[Battle of the Year: The Dream Team]]'' all showcase breaking. Films such as ''[[Honey (2003 film)|Honey]]'', ''[[Save the Last Dance]]'', ''[[You Got Served]]'', the ''[[Step Up (film series)|Step Up]]'' film series, ''[[StreetDance 3D]]'', ''Hype Nation'', ''[[Saigon Electric]]'', ''Berlin Dance Battle 3D'', and ''[[ABCD: Any Body Can Dance]]'' showcase all forms of hip-hop dance, especially new style hip-hop. ''[[Rize]]'', ''The Heart of Krump'', and ''Shake City 101'' are documentaries about [[krumping]]. All of these movies and documentaries are examples of films where the plot and theme surround hip-hop dance and how it affects the characters' lives. ''Bouncing Cats'' is the story of b-boy Abraham "Abramz" Tekya who uses b-boying to empower youth in Uganda. In 2010, the film won "Outstanding Achievement in Documentary Filmmaking" at Newport Beach Film Festival and "Best Documentary Feature" at Urbanworld Film Festival.<ref>{{cite web|title=Bouncing Cats Wins Award for Best Documentary |url=http://www.redbullusa.com/cs/Satellite/en_US/Article/bouncing-cats-best-documentary-021242906678421 |work=RedBullUSA.com |date=September 21, 2010 |accessdate=August 1, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69anit2MQ?url=http://www.redbullusa.com/cs/Satellite/en_US/Article/bouncing-cats-best-documentary-021242906678421 |archivedate=August 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''Saigon Electric'' was Vietnam's first hip-hop film.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://talk.onevietnam.org/saigon-electric-vietnams-first-hip-hop-movie/ |title=Saigon Electric, Vietnam's First Hip-Hop Movie |last=Trinh |first=Vincent |date=October 26, 2011 |work=OneVietnam.org |accessdate=August 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/636C0S2Qw?url=http://talk.onevietnam.org/saigon-electric-vietnams-first-hip-hop-movie/ |archivedate=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It was written, produced, and directed by Vietnamese-American filmmaker Stephane Gauger. The film is about two female dancers (a ribbon dancer and a hip-hop dancer) and how their respective romances, the threat of their community center being torn down, and the stress of an upcoming dance battle affects their friendship.<ref>{{cite web |last=Le |first=Anderson |url=http://www.indiegogo.com/SAIGON-ELECTRIC|title=THE STORY OF SAIGON ELECTRIC: Believe In The Power Of Dreams|work=IndieGoGo.com|accessdate=November 10, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://talk.onevietnam.org/saigon-electric-vietnams-first-hip-hop-movie/ |title=Saigon Electric, Vietnam's First Hip-Hop Movie |last=Trinh |first=Vincent |date=October 26, 2011 |work=OneVietnam.org |accessdate=November 10, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/636C0S2Qw?url=http://talk.onevietnam.org/saigon-electric-vietnams-first-hip-hop-movie/ |archivedate=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The film was choreographed by Viet Max and Ricky Cole.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://saigonelectric.com/crew/ |title=Crew |work=SaigonElectric.com |accessdate=November 10, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/636C5qdMx?url=http://saigonelectric.com/crew/ |archivedate=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2012, it won a [[Golden Kite Prize]] (the Vietnamese equivalent of [[Academy Award|The Oscars]]/[[BAFTA]]s) for "Best Film" and "Best Actress".<ref>{{cite web|title=Saigon Electric wins Best Film & Best Actress at Golden Kite Awards |url=http://saigonelectric.com/saigon-electric-wins-best-film-best-actress-at-golden-kite-awards/ |work=SaigonElectric.com |date=March 18, 2012 |accessdate=August 1, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69anr0yv7?url=http://saigonelectric.com/saigon-electric-wins-best-film-best-actress-at-golden-kite-awards/ |archivedate=August 1, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Television=== Before reaching movie audiences, hip-hop dance was already being broadcast on television. ''[[Soul Train]]'' was a [[wikt:syndicated|syndicated]], music [[variety show]] that featured social dancing and performances by African-American soul, funk, and R&B singers. The show was broadcast in South Korea via the US Armed Forces Korea Network.<ref name=asiamerica>{{cite news|last=Chang |first=Jeff |title=So you think they can break-dance? |work=Salon.com |date=June 26, 2008 |url=http://www.salon.com/ent/feature/2008/06/26/korean_hiphop/index.html |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdUU?url=http://www.salon.com/entertainment/feature/2008/06/26/korean_hiphop/index.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |accessdate=August 28, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Before officially becoming a crew, The Lockers made several appearances on this show.<ref>{{cite web|last=McMillian |first=Stephen |title=Diary of an Ex-Soul Train Dancer: Q&A with Shabba Doo of the Lockers |url=http://soultrain.com/2011/06/29/diary-of-an-ex-soul-train-dancer-qa-with-shabba-doo-of-the-lockers/ |date=June 29, 2011 |work=SoulTrain.com |accessdate=November 10, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/636JAwVuS?url=http://soultrain.com/2011/06/29/diary-of-an-ex-soul-train-dancer-qa-with-shabba-doo-of-the-lockers/ |archivedate=November 10, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> After becoming a crew, The Electric Boogaloos also appeared on the show.<ref name="funky"/><ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 120.</ref> ''Soul Train'' premiered in 1970.<ref name=owner>{{cite news |last=Stelter |first=Brian |title=After 38 Years, 'Soul Train' Gets New Owner |newspaper=The New York Times |date=June 17, 2008 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/17/business/media/17soul.html?_r=3&scp=1&sq=soul+train&st=nyt&oref=slogin&oref=slogin |accessdate=November 18, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628weCAaG?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2008/06/17/business/media/17soul.html?_r=3&scp=1&sq=soul+train&st=nyt&oref=slogin&oref=slogin |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> During its 36 year run, the resident freestyle dancers were referred to as the Soul Train Gang.<ref name=blackrock>{{cite book|last=Austen|first=Jake|title=TV-a-go-go: Rock on TV from American Bandstand to American Idol|year=2005|publisher=Chicago Review Press|location=Chicago|isbn=1556525729|page=101|quote=...as a rule, the dancers (known as the Soul Train Gang) were the stars and the reason ''Soul Train'' had no competition. The dancers auditioned at an open call in 1971, and since then the producers have maintained a strong lineup of dancers via a referral system. 'We've found over the years that kids who dance really well and groom themselves really well and have a sense of style and behave well know other kids who can do the same thing,' Cornelius explained on his 1996 twenty-fifth anniversary TV special.}}</ref> Auditions were held in 1971 when the show moved from Chicago, Illinois to Los Angeles, California. Dancers who wanted to get on ''Soul Train'' after this time had to rely on word-of-mouth recommendations from dancers who were already employed by the show.<ref name=blackrock/><ref>{{cite news|last=Strauss|first=Neil|title=You say 'Soul Train' is how old|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/12/31/tv/cover-story-you-say-soul-train-is-how-old.html|accessdate=January 19, 2012|newspaper=The New York Times|date=December 31, 1995}}</ref> A regular feature during the broadcast was the Soul Train Line.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Mitchell |first=Gail |date=February 19, 2005 |title=Grammys Fete 'Train' Conductor Cornelius|journal=Billboard|volume=117|issue=8|page=28|issn=0006-2510}}</ref> To participate in the Soul Train Line, the dancers formed two lines of equal length facing each other with a large space in between them. Each dancer in line would take their turn dancing down the middle.
Other music variety shows on television at this time were ''[[American Bandstand]]'', ''[[Solid Gold (TV series)|Solid Gold]]'', and ''[[Top of the Pops]]''. Unlike ''Soul Train'' which focused on soul and funk, these shows promoted [[Top 40]] music and pop acts. ''Solid Gold'' employed a permanent dance troupe called the Solid Gold Dancers who performed choreographed routines to musical performances. [[Lucinda Dickey]], an actress and dancer who played the lead role in the ''Breakin' '' films, appeared on the show during the 1982–1983 season as a Solid Gold dancer. In 1983, street dancers Marc "Mr. Freeze" Lemberger from [[Rock Steady Crew]], Timothy "Popin' Pete" Solomon and Dane "Robot Dane" Parker from the Electric Boogaloos, and locking dancers Alpha "Omega" Anderson and Lewis "Deputy" Green also appeared on Solid Gold during a performance to the song "[[Flashdance... What a Feeling|What a Feeling]]" from the movie ''Flashdance''.<ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 145.</ref> In 1982 during a performance in London on ''Top of the Pops'', street dancer [[Jeffrey Daniel]] performed popping and the ''backslide'' during the song "[[A Night to Remember (Shalamar song)|A Night to Remember]]". This was the first time popping was shown on British television thus spreading its popularity in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web |title=Remembering Michael Jackson (August 29, 1958 – June 25, 2009) |url=http://www.soulculture.co.uk/features/scarticles/remembering-michael-jackson-1958-2009/ |work=SoulCulture.com |date=June 25, 2011 |accessdate=July 15, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Jeffrey Daniel joins judging panel of Nigerian Idol |url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2010/10/12/jeffrey-daniel-joins-judging-panel-of-nigerian-idol/ |work=AllStreetDance.co.uk |accessdate=July 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628wx0P5q?url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2010/10/12/jeffrey-daniel-joins-judging-panel-of-nigerian-idol/ |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> A year later, Michael Jackson also performed the backslide during a performance of "[[Billie Jean]]" on the [[Motown 25: Yesterday, Today, Forever|Motown 25]] TV special.<ref>Guzman-Sanchez 2012, p. 121.</ref> He called it the [[Moonwalk (dance)|moonwalk]] and his performance spread its popularity all over the world<ref>{{cite book |title=Thriller 25th Anniversary: The Book |last=Jackson |first=Michael |authorlink= Michael Jackson |year=2008 |publisher=ML Publishing Group |isbn=0976889196}}</ref> to much larger extent than Daniel's performance did. It was Jeffrey Daniel who taught Michael Jackson how to do the backslide/moonwalk.{{#tag:ref|Jeffrey Daniel learned the backslide from [[The Electric Boogaloos]].<ref>{{cite web|date=June 26, 2009 |title='Bad' Choreographer Remembers Michael Jackson |url=https://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105986636 |work=NPR.org |accessdate=August 1, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cJKMm79?url=http://www.npr.org/templates/story/story.php?storyId=105986636 |archivedate=August 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|date=November 6, 2009 |title='I taught Jacko how to Moonwalk' |url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/taught-Jacko-Moonwalk/story-12270198-detail/story.html |work=ThisIsNottingham.co.uk |accessdate=August 1, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cJHitmN?url=http://www.thisisnottingham.co.uk/taught-Jacko-Moonwalk/story-12270198-detail/story.html |archivedate=August 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>|group="note"}}<ref>{{cite news|last=Dondoneau |first=Dave |date=October 2, 2009 |title=Meet the man who taught MJ to moonwalk |url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Oct/02/en/hawaii910020315.html |work=The Honolulu Advertiser |accessdate=August 1, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/60cIZurUL?url=http://the.honoluluadvertiser.com/article/2009/Oct/02/en/hawaii910020315.html |archivedate=August 1, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |title=Remembering Michael, Jeffrey Daniel |url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1907409_1907413_1907560,00.html |work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]] |accessdate=December 5, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CgraSItn?url=http://www.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,1907409_1907413_1907560,00.html |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |date=June 26, 2009 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
[[File:JabbaWockeeZ.jpg|thumb|left|230px|The JabbaWockeez, winners of the first season of ''America's Best Dance Crew'', performing in 2008 at Vivid Nightclub in [[San Jose, California|San Jose]], California.|alt=Four members of the hip-hop dance crew JabbaWockeeZ performing in a night club wearing white masks and white gloves.]] A few hip-hop dance shows appeared on television in the 1990s such as 1991's ''[[The Party Machine with Nia Peeples]]''{{#tag:ref| Prior to ''The Party Machine'', [[Nia Peeples]] hosted the US version of ''[[Top of the Pops]]''.<ref name=peeples>{{cite news|last=Rohter |first=Larry |title=A New Diversion for Those Who Stay Up Late |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/arts/a-new-diversion-for-those-who-stay-up-late.html |work=The New York Times |date=November 3, 1991 |accessdate=August 13, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69tY2cPV8?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1991/03/11/arts/a-new-diversion-for-those-who-stay-up-late.html |archivedate=August 13, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> |group="note"}} and 1992's ''[[The Grind (TV series)|The Grind]]''. Several hip-hop dance shows premiered in the 2000s including (but not limited to) ''[[Dance Fever (2003 TV series)|Dance Fever]]'', ''[[Dance 360]]'', ''[[Wade Robson|The Wade Robson Project]]'', ''MTV Dance Crew'', ''[[America's Best Dance Crew]]'', ''[[Dance on Sunset]]'', and ''[[Shake It Up (U.S. TV series)|Shake It Up]]''. In 2006, MTV France documented the creation of a dance crew for an original series called ''MTV Dance Crew''.<ref name=mtv>{{cite av media |people=Devaud, Sebastien (Director) |year=2006 |title=MTV Dance Crew |medium=DVD |language=French |publisher=2good Productions / MTV Networks |location=France }}</ref> Viewers were able to see the crew from auditions to the selection of the final eight who were subsequently named Original Soul. Original Soul was coached by three professional choreographers who mentored them and helped refine their dancing. Over the course of 32 episodes they routinely participated in professional dance battles including the popping battle at [[Juste Debout]], the Seven 2 Smoke battle at [[The Notorious IBE]], and b-boy battles at [[Chelles, Seine-et-Marne|Chelles]] Battle Pro.<ref name=mtv/> [[B-boy Lilou]], b-boy crew Phase T, and [[Promoter (entertainment)|promoter]] Bruce Ykanji (the founder of Juste Debout) all made appearances during the show.<ref name=mtv/>
The founders of [[World Hip Hop Dance Championships|Hip Hop International]], Howard and Karen Schwartz, created the reality hip-hop dance competition ''America's Best Dance Crew'' (ABDC) in 2008.<ref name=racked/><ref name=hhi>{{cite news|last=Feldberg |first=Sarah |title=World Hip Hop Dance Championships return to Las Vegas this weekend |newspaper=Las Vegas Sun |date=July 30, 2009 |url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jul/30/world-hip-hop-dance-championships-return-las-vegas/ |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdap?url=http://www.lasvegassun.com/news/2009/jul/30/world-hip-hop-dance-championships-return-las-vegas/ |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref> On the show, different crews competed in dance challenges against each other every week. ABDC contributed to the exposure of several crews such as [[Jabbawockeez]], [[Quest Crew|Quest]], [[Beat Freaks]], and [[Poreotics]]. These crews now have official websites, work with musical artists, and perform at live events. The JabbaWockeeZ had a show in Las Vegas, Nevada called ''MÜS.I.C.'' at the Monte Carlo Resort and Casino.<ref name=muse/> ''MÜS.I.C.'' was the first hip-hop dance stage show on the Las Vegas Strip.<ref name=muse>{{cite news|last=Palopoli |first=Steve |date=April 21, 2011 |title=Fingerz on the Pulse |url=http://www.metroactive.com/features/the-bangerzs.html |work=Metro Active |accessdate=August 12, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628sB4CV1?url=http://www.metroactive.com/features/the-bangerzs.html |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2012, the Jabbawockeez performed the show during a five-month residency at the Jupiters Hotel and Casino in [[Gold Coast, Queensland]], Australia.<ref>{{cite news|last=Browne |first=Sally |title=US dance sensation Jabbawokeez to land at Jupiters |url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/life/whatson/us-dance-sensation-to-land-on-jupiters/story-fn8zvh1s-1226326724554 |accessdate=May 22, 2012 |newspaper=[[The Courier-Mail]] |date=April 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67qUE6JVT?url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/life/whatson/us-dance-sensation-to-land-on-jupiters/story-fn8zvh1s-1226326724554 |archivedate=May 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Both Poreotics and Hokuto "Hok" Konishi from Quest were nominated for a [[2011 MTV Video Music Awards|2011 MTV Video Music Award]] for Best Choreography.<ref name=nom>{{cite web|title=2011 MTV VMA Nominees For Best Choreography Are |url=http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/?p=5503 |work=Dance Track |accessdate=September 29, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628sIRGNq?url=http://www.dancetrackmagazine.com/?p=5503 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Poreotics was nominated with singer [[Bruno Mars]] for his video "[[The Lazy Song]]". Hok was nominated for [[LMFAO (group)|LMFAO]]'s video "[[Party Rock Anthem]]"; the rest of Quest crew appeared in the video as featured dancers.<ref name=nom/>
In contrast to ABDC, individual dancers from all backgrounds compete on the reality dance competition ''[[So You Think You Can Dance (United States)|So You Think You Can Dance]]'' (SYTYCD). It has a similar premise to the ''[[Idol series|Idol]]'' series of singing competitions with initial auditions leading to the selection of a winner over the course of several episodes. In 2008, poppers Robert "Mr. Fantastic" Muraine and Phillip "Pacman" Chbeeb auditioned during season four of the US series. Neither made it to the final "Top 20", but the judges were so impressed with their dancing that both were invited back to participate in a popping battle against each other on the show's live finale. According to Muraine, this was the first popping battle that was nationally televised.<ref name=battle>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=So You Think You Can Dance |serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance (United States) |credits=Robert Muraine, Phillip Chbeeb (poppers) |network=[[Fox TV|Fox]] |airdate=August 7, 2008 |season=4 |number=23 |quote=I want to give much respect to Phillip and to everyone that had us here and everything. This is the first televised popping battle and it's a honor to be a part of that and I want to thank everybody. |minutes= }}</ref> After the battle, hip-hop dancer [[Joshua Allen]] was declared the winner of season four of the competition.<ref>{{cite web |title=About |work=Fox.com |url=http://www.fox.com/dance/about/ |accessdate=December 8, 2012 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130413072947/http://www.fox.com/dance/about/ |archivedate=April 13, 2013}}</ref> The same year [[Mona-Jeanette Berntsen]], a hip-hop dancer from Norway, won the first season of ''[[So You Think You Can Dance — Scandinavia|So You Think You Can Dance Scandinavia]]''.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |episodelink= |series=So You Think You Can Dance Scandinavia |serieslink=So You Think You Can Dance — Scandinavia |credits= |network=[[TVNorge]] |airdate=May 29, 2008 |season=1 |seriesno= |number=8 |minutes= |location=Oslo}}</ref>
Hip-hop dance has also been popular among viewers of the ''Got Talent'' series. French hip-hop dancer [[Salah (dancer)|Salah]] won the first season of ''[[La France a un incroyable talent|Incroyable Talent]]'' in 2006.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=Incroyable Talent |serieslink=La France a un incroyable talent |network=[[M6 (TV channel)|M6]] |airdate=December 12, 2006 |season=1 |number=7 |language=French}}</ref> French b-boy Junior won the second season in 2007.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=Incroyable Talent |serieslink=La France a un incroyable talent |network=M6 |airdate=December 11, 2007 |season=2 |number=6 |language=French}}</ref> In 2008, hip-hop dancer [[George Sampson]] won ''[[Britain's Got Talent]]'',<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |url= |series=Britain's Got Talent |serieslink=Britain's Got Talent (series 2) |network=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |airdate=May 31, 2008 |season=2 |number=13}}</ref> Danish popping and roboting duo Robot Boys won ''Talent 2008'' ([[:da:Talent 2008|da]]),<ref>{{cite web|title=ROBOT BOYS |url=http://www.prodance.co.uk/ROBOTBOYS |work=ProDance.co.uk |accessdate=May 31, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6855lAaXJ?url=http://www.prodance.co.uk/robotboys |archivedate=May 31, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and hip-hop dance crew [[Quick (dance group)|Quick]] won the [[Norske Talenter|Norwegian version]] of the show.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=Norske Talenter |serieslink=Norske Talenter (series 2) |network=[[TV 2 Norway|TV 2]] |airdate=May 8, 2008 |season=2 |number=12 |language=Norwegian}}</ref> After George Sampson, dance crew [[Diversity (dance troupe)|Diversity]] won the next season of ''Britain's Got Talent'' in 2009.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=Britain's Got Talent |serieslink=Britain's Got Talent (series 3) |network=[[ITV (TV network)|ITV]] |airdate=May 30, 2009 |season=3 |number=13}}</ref><ref group=note>George Sampson and Diversity appeared in the film ''[[StreetDance 3D]]''.</ref> The same year, Brazilian crew
