[[D-Efeitos]] won ''[[Qual é o Seu Talento?]]'' (''What's Your Talent?'').<ref>{{cite episode |title=Final |series=Qual é o Seu Talento? |serieslink=Qual é o Seu Talento? (season 1) |network=[[Sistema Brasileiro de Televisão|SBT]] |airdate=December 16, 2009 |season=1 |number=20 |language=Portuguese}}</ref> In 2010, [[Justice Crew]] won ''[[Australia's Got Talent]]''.<ref>{{cite episode |title=Finale |series=Australia's Got Talent |serieslink=Australia's Got Talent (season 4) |network=[[Seven Network]] |airdate=June 15, 2010 |season=4 |number=10}}</ref> After signing a recording contract with Sony Music Australia, Justice Crew shot a video for their single "[[Dance with Me (Justice Crew song)|Dance with Me]]" featuring rapper [[Flo Rida]] and ''America's Best Dance Crew'' alumni [[Beat Freaks]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Issue 830 – Justice Crew Ft. Flo Rida |url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-releases/singles/2011/04/04/issue--830/justice-crew-ft-flo-rida--dance-with-me/ |work=TheMusicNetwork.com |accessdate=May 22, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67qXXts27?url=http://www.themusicnetwork.com/music-releases/singles/2011/04/04/issue--830/justice-crew-ft-flo-rida--dance-with-me/ |archivedate=May 22, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2015, nine years after he won ''Incroyable Talent'', hip-hop dancer Salah won the fourth season of ''Arabs Got Talent''.<ref>{{cite news |last=Al Tamimi |first=Jumana |date=March 8, 2015 |title='Arab Charlie Chaplin' wins reality show |url=http://gulfnews.com/arts-entertainment/television/arab-charlie-chaplin-wins-reality-show-1.1468451 |work=Gulf News |accessdate=March 9, 2015 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150309115701/http://gulfnews.com/arts-entertainment/television/arab-charlie-chaplin-wins-reality-show-1.1468451 |archivedate=March 9, 2015}}</ref>
===Theater=== {{See also|Hip-hop theater}} [[File:RennieHarris.jpg|thumb|right|200px|Choreographer and artistic director Rennie Harris in 2011.|alt=A black and white photograph of choreographer and artistic director Rennie Harris.]] Though hip-hop dancing is established on film and on television, it has not gained the same level of exposure in theater. This may be due to the fact that the dance is performed more in film and in television than it is in a theatrical setting.<ref>Chang 2006, p. 24. "As relatively new dance forms, b-boying/b-girling, uprocking, locking, and popping are rarely seen in a theatrical setting. They are usually performed in music videos, commercials, or films..."</ref> B-boy and popper Stefan "[[Mr. Wiggles]]" Clemente and hip-hop historian Jorge "Popmaster Fabel" Pabon were involved in hip-hop theater at its inception. Their dance company, GhettOriginal, produced the first hip-hop stage shows: 1991's [[off Broadway]] musical ''So! What Happens Now?'' and 1995's ''Jam on the Groove''.<ref name=gotech>{{cite web|last=Chang |first=Jeff |title=Dancing on the Through-Line |url=http://www.colum.edu/administrative_offices/Academic_Research/PDF_folder/rennie_harrris.pdf |work=Colum.edu |accessdate=November 29, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63ZTHb6O1?url=http://www.colum.edu/administrative_offices/Academic_Research/PDF_folder/rennie_harrris.pdf |archivedate=November 30, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>Chang 2006, p. 26.</ref> Both shows were performed by the Rock Steady Crew, Magnificent Force, and the Rhythm Technicians.<ref name=rsc>{{cite news|last=Milosheff |first=Peter |title=Rock Steady Crew 32nd Anniversary |newspaper=The Bronx Times |date=July 7, 2008 |url=http://www.bronx.com/news/entertainment/entertainment_music/290.html |accessdate=August 25, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdVc?url=http://www.bronx.com/news/entertainment/entertainment_music/290.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Pareles |first=Jon |title=Theater In Review |newspaper=The New York Times |date=November 18, 1995 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/arts/theater-in-review-045713.html |accessdate=August 24, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fddS?url=http://www.nytimes.com/1995/11/18/arts/theater-in-review-045713.html |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Aside from the pioneers in New York City was [[Rennie Harris]]' Puremovement hip-hop theater company. Harris founded Puremovement in 1992 in [[Philadelphia|Philadelphia, Pennsylvania]].<ref name=jacob/> One of Puremovement's theater shows ''Rome & Jewels'' won two Black Theater Alliance Awards and three [[Bessie Awards]].<ref>{{cite book |title=Hip-Hop and Urban Dance |last=Fitzgerald |first=Tasmin |year=2009 |publisher=Heinemann Library |location=Chicago |isbn=9781432913786 |page=35}}</ref> In 2012, Harris and his company toured Egypt, Israel, and the Palestinian territories as part of Dance Motion USA, a program sponsored by the [[United States Department of State|US State Department]] to showcase American dance to other countries and promote cultural exchange.<ref>{{cite web|title=Rennie Harris Puremovement |url=http://www.dancemotionusa.org/media/11688/RHPM%202012%20program.pdf |work=DanceMotionUSA.org |accessdate=December 5, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CgfKp00R?url=http://www.dancemotionusa.org/media/11688/RHPM%202012%20program.pdf |archivedate=December 5, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
German b-boy pioneer Niels "Storm" Robitzky has his performance roots in hip-hop theater. In 1991, Robitzky—who went by the name "Swipe"—left Germany with his crew Battle Squad for New York City to look for b-boy legends they could study under.<ref name=kwik>{{cite news|author=Calvin |title=The Last B-Boy in New York: The Story of Kwikstep |url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2008/12/the-last-b-boy-in-new-york-the-story-of-kwikstep/ |work=More Than a Stance |date=December 2, 2008 |accessdate=June 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QDc2mmW?url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2008/12/the-last-b-boy-in-new-york-the-story-of-kwikstep/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> When he got to New York, he met b-boy Gabriel "Kwikstep" Dionisio who personally mentored him and introduced him to New York techniques.<ref name=kwik/> While in New York, he also learned about the funk styles from Clemente.<ref name=storm/> Clemente and Dionisio knew each other since Dionisio was an original member of both GhettOriginal and the Rhythm Technicians.<ref name=kwik/> A year later in 1992, Robitzky performed with GhettOriginal at the [[John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts|Kennedy Center]] in Washington D.C. and at the [[Lincoln Center for the Performing Arts|Lincoln Center]] in New York City.<ref name=storm>{{cite web|title=UK B-Boy Championships World Finals 2011 Lineup: Judges |url=http://bboychampionships.com/lineup/judges |work=BBoyChamptionships.com |accessdate=June 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QFDc19s?url=http://bboychampionships.com/lineup/judges |archivedate=July 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It was Dionisio who gave Robitzky a new name, "Storm".<ref name=kwik/> In 2000, he wrote a book called ''Von Swipe zu Storm: Breakdance in Deutschland'' (''From Swipe to Storm: Breakdance in Germany'').<ref>{{cite book |title=Von Swipe zu Storm: Breakdance in Deutschland |last=Robitzky |first=Niels |year=2000 |publisher=Backspin |location=Hamburg |isbn=9783000055263 |language=German}}</ref>
Dancers in the United Kingdom have had success in hip-hop theater. In 2006, hip-hop dance company Boy Blue Entertainment won a [[Laurence Olivier Award]] for their show ''Pied Piper''.<ref>{{cite web|last=Roy |first=Sanjoy |date=March 9, 2009 |title=Pied Piper |url=https://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/mar/09/pied-piper-barbican-london-review |work=The Guardian |accessdate=February 28, 2014 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Nixhs4hP?url=http://www.theguardian.com/stage/2009/mar/09/pied-piper-barbican-london-review |archivedate=February 28, 2014 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2008, ''[[Into the Hoods]]'' became the first hip-hop theater show to perform in London's [[West End theatre|West End]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.londondance.com/content.asp?CategoryID=3524 |title=Kate Prince – back in the Hoods |work=LondonDance.com |date=December 8, 2009 |accessdate=July 1, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628pfGFSz?url=http://www.londondance.com/content.asp?CategoryID=3524 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It eventually went on to become the West End's longest running dance show ever.<ref>{{cite web|title=ZooNation Dance Company — Some Like It Hip Hop |url=http://www.sadlerswells.com/show/ZooNation-Some-Like-It-Hip-Hop |work=SadlersWells.com |accessdate=September 27, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628skJctu?url=http://www.sadlerswells.com/show/ZooNation-Some-Like-It-Hip-Hop |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
===Online content=== YAK Films is a three-man team that films urban dance around the world. It was founded in Oakland, California by Yoram Savion and Kash Grimes.<ref name=shave>{{cite news |last=Chipperfield |first=Ed |url=http://www.shaveyourstyle.com/news-stories/article/date/2012/02/17/profile-street-dance-goes-global-with-yak-films.html |title=Profile: Street dance goes global with YAK FILMS |work=ShaveYourStyle.com |date=February 17, 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2012}}</ref><ref name=origins>{{cite web|title=DancersGlobal: Interview with Kash Gaines of YAKfilms – YAK Like You Know Part 1 |url=http://dancersglobal.com/dancersglobal-interview-with-kash-gaines-of-yakfilms-yak-like-you-know-part-1/ |work=DancersGlobal.com |date=July 28, 2011 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688RmW0AD?url=http://dancersglobal.com/dancersglobal-interview-with-kash-gaines-of-yakfilms-yak-like-you-know-part-1/ |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Their first videos were of the Turf Feinz dance crew performing [[turfing]]—a regional hip-hop dance style from Oakland.<ref name=braun>{{cite web|title=Interview with YAK Films! |url=http://www.braunbattleoftheyear.com/news/news/date/2012/03/05/yak-films.html |work=BraunBattleOfTheYear.com |date=March 5, 2012 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688TmtAuv?url=http://www.braunbattleoftheyear.com/news/news/date/2012/03/05/yak-films.html |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> After generating significant views on YouTube, they started YAK (Yoram And Kash) Films and added music producer Ben "B'zwax" Tarquin to the team.<ref name=shave/><ref name=origins/> From shooting videos only in the United States, they were able to easily transition to covering dance events in Europe due to Savion's dual French citizenship.<ref name=shave/> In 2009, they filmed [[Battle of the Year]]'s first one-on-one b-boy competition, and in 2010 they filmed dance battles at [[Juste Debout]], a French street dance competition.<ref name=braun/> In addition to filming dance events and original freestyle performances, they post tutorials and upload a weekly web series called "YAK Like You Know".<ref name=origins/> Some of their more popular videos have been featured in ''Oakland Local''<ref>{{cite web|title=Oakland: Videos that went viral in 2011 |url=http://oaklandlocal.com/article/oakland-videos-went-viral-2011/ |work=Oakland Local |date=December 30, 2011 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688OPf1vb?url=http://oaklandlocal.com/article/oakland-videos-went-viral-2011/ |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> and the ''[[Huffington Post]]''.<ref>{{cite news|title=Next Level Squad's 'Zilla March' In New York Subways (VIDEO) |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/29/next-level-squads-zilla-march-yak-films_n_1174897.html |work=[[Huffington Post]] |date=December 29, 2011 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688OaasfW?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2011/12/29/next-level-squads-zilla-march-yak-films_n_1174897.html |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |first=Inae |last=Oh |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last=Stuart |first=Hunter |title=Incredible Urban Dancing Video In Rainy Oakland Goes Viral (VIDEO) |url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/09/incredible-urban-dancing-_n_756961.html |work=Huffington Post |date=October 9, 2010 |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688OlHAqw?url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2010/10/09/incredible-urban-dancing-_n_756961.html |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref>
Juba Films was founded in Germany by Julien Bam and Gong Bao.<ref name=mail>{{cite news|url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2186876/With-Piece-Chalk-Forget-Justin-Bieber-Justen-Beer-Amazing-video-shows-12-year-old-break-dancer.html |title=Forget Justin Bieber, this is Justen Beer! Amazing video shows 12-year-old break-dancer's gravity-defying moves |last=Farberov |first=Snejana |date=August 11, 2012 |work=Daily Mail |accessdate=February 22, 2013 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Ecsqp8hQ?url=http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2186876/With-Piece-Chalk-Forget-Justin-Bieber-Justen-Beer-Amazing-video-shows-12-year-old-break-dancer.html |archivedate=February 22, 2013 |location=London |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Rather than film freestyle content, Juba ("Ju"lien and "Ba"o) produces short films with a storyline. For their short b-boy film "More Than Bread", they won first place at the 7th International Online Dance Festival in 2011.<ref name=ODF>{{cite web|title=Julien Kho Budorovits & Gia Bao Tu – Winner 2011 |url=http://www.side-by-side.net/en/nominee/47/name/Julien+Kho+Budorovits+%26+Gia+Bao+Tu |work=Side-by-Side.net |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688NpPC62?url=http://www.side-by-side.net/en/nominee/47/name/Julien+Kho+Budorovits+%26+Gia+Bao+Tu |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2012, the ''[[Daily Mail]]'' wrote an article about Juba's short film "With a Piece of Chalk" after the video went viral and started trending on [[Mashable]].<ref name=mail/> Both Juba Films and YAK Films appeared at [[The Notorious IBE]]'s New Dance Media Conference discussing the relationship between street dance and [[visual arts]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenotoriousibe.com/program_newdancemedia.html |title=New Dance Media Conference 2012 |work=TheNotoriousIBE.com |accessdate=December 24, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6D9QBiQ9n?url=http://www.thenotoriousibe.com/program_newdancemedia.html |archivedate=December 24, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Although Juba Films has won an award and YAK Films has booked high-profile events, they are not the only film production teams distributing hip-hop dance videos on the Internet. House of Crews, Strife TV, Pacific Rim Video Press, ProDance TV, Battle Fest Extreme, Urban Dance Show, Ocke Films, World of Dance Network, and Canal Street TV also produce hundreds of high-quality hip-hop dance content.<ref group=note>CanalStreet.tv is owned by [[Canal+]], a French [[pay television|premium television]] channel.</ref>
''[[The Legion of Extraordinary Dancers]]'' (''The LXD'') was a good-versus-evil themed [[web series]] about a group of dancers who discover they have super powers through their dance moves.<ref name=lxd>{{cite news |url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-ca-extraordinarydancers-20100704,0,4332441,full.story |title='The Legion of Extraordinary Dancers' is ready to battle with flips, spins and dance steps |newspaper=Los Angeles Times |date=July 4, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rdewysqH?url=http://www.latimes.com/entertainment/news/la-ca-extraordinarydancers-20100704,0,4332441,full.story |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |first=Zachary |last=Pincus-Roth |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Each character specializes in one dance style. Consequently, a wide range of styles are displayed including krumping, tutting, breaking, locking, [[Electric boogaloo (dance)|boogaloo]], and popping.<ref name=lxd/><ref name=birdplane>{{cite news|last=Rolnick |first=Katie |date=April 1, 2010 |magazine=Dance Spirit |url=http://dancespirit.com/articles/2534 |title=It's A Bird, It's A Plane, It's The LXD! |accessdate=August 1, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628sT3vyL?url=http://dancespirit.com/articles/2534 |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The majority of the dancing shown in the series is hip-hop; however, other styles have also been performed including jazz, tap, and ballet.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Oppenheimer |first=Jean |work=American Cinematographer |title=Lethal Dance Moves |url=http://www.nxtbook.com/nxtbooks/ac/ac1110/?ap=1#/20 |volume=91 |issue=11 |date=November 2010 |issn=0002-7928 |accessdate=December 9, 2012}}</ref> AdvertisingAge.com gave the series a favorable review stating "...each episode of 'LXD' packs a wealth of narrative sophistication into its eight or nine minutes. Combine this with the theater-worthy production values and a cast that exerts itself to an ungodly extent, and the end result is – pun time! – extraordinary."<ref>{{cite news|last=Dobrow |first=Larry |url=http://adage.com/mediaworks/article?article_id=144955 |title=A Web Series so Good, It (Almost) Makes Dobrow Want to Dance |work=AdAge.com |date=July 15, 2010 |accessdate=August 31, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rdf1gf3b?url=http://adage.com/mediaworks/article?article_id=144955 |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> ''The LXD'' premiered July 7, 2010 on [[Hulu]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thewrap.com/node/18755 |title='The LXD' Launches July 7 on Hulu |work=TheWrap.com |date=June 24, 2010 |accessdate=December 8, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6ClQk4kom?url=http://www.thewrap.com/tv/article/lxd-launches-july-7-hulu-18755 |archivedate=December 8, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2012, [[Jon M. Chu|Jon Chu]], the writer, director, and producer of ''The LXD'' launched a dance channel on YouTube called DS2DIO (pronounced D-Studio).<ref name=dstudio>{{cite web|title=DS2DIO dance lifestyle channel project planned from LXD creator Jon M Chu |url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/05/15/ds2dio-dance-lifestyle-channel-project-planned-from-lxd-creator-jon-m-chu/ |work=AllStreetDance.co.uk |date=May 15, 2012 |accessdate=July 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QAWGhJX?url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/05/15/ds2dio-dance-lifestyle-channel-project-planned-from-lxd-creator-jon-m-chu/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref group=note>Jon Chu also directed the movies ''[[Step Up 2: The Streets]]'' and ''[[Step Up 3D]]''.</ref> DS2DIO has videos of master classes, freestyle dance, and original choreographed performances. Through this channel, Chu also made ''The LXD'' available on YouTube. Before then, it could only be viewed on Hulu.<ref name=dstudio/>
==International competitions== {{See also|B-boying#World championships}} [[File:FSTaiwan.jpg|thumb|right|215px|The 2010 winners of the b-boy crew battle at Freestyle Session Taiwan.|alt=A group of eleven young men holding a large sign that says "BBoy Crew Battle Champion" while posing for a picture in front of a banner that says "Freestyle Session Taiwan".]] *'''[[UK B-Boy Championships]]''' was founded by DJ Hooch in 1996 in London.<ref>{{cite news|title=History |work=BBoyChampionships.com |url=http://bboychampionships.com/about |accessdate=November 18, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63I4kmuhm?url=http://bboychampionships.com/about |archivedate=November 18, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=DJ Hooch |url=http://www.prodance.co.uk/DJHOOCH |work=ProDance.co.uk |accessdate=June 3, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/688Xs2Fzv?url=http://www.prodance.co.uk/DJHOOCH |archivedate=June 3, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> There are four world championship titles: breaking crew champions, solo b-boy champion, solo popping champion, and solo hip-hop champion.<ref>{{cite news|title=What's On: 08 |work=BBoyChampionships.com |url=http://bboychampionships.com/hall-of-fame |accessdate=August 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6Bh5y1AWg?url=http://bboychampionships.com/hall-of-fame |archivedate=October 26, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The world finals also include the "Fresh Awards" (best dressed) which are hosted and judged every year by Richard "[[Crazy Legs (dancer)|Crazy Legs]]" Colón—the president of Rock Steady Crew.<ref>{{cite news|title=Features: 08 |work=BBoyChampionships.com |url=http://www.bboychampionships.com/content/view/244/552/ |accessdate=August 28, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdZr?url=http://www.bboychampionships.com/content/view/244/552/ |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In 2011, DJ Hooch wrote a book about the competition called ''B-Boy Championships: From Bronx to Brixton''.<ref>DJ Hooch 2011, pp. 1–2.</ref> *'''Freestyle Session''' was founded in 1997 in California by graffiti writer and DJ Chris "Cros1" Wright.<ref>{{cite web|title=Freestyle Session Europe 2009 |url=http://www.freestylesession.pl/about.php |work=FreestyleSession.com |accessdate=July 30, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628owNui2?url=http://www.freestylesession.pl/about.php |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref><ref name=stance>{{cite news|last=Bakshani |first=Maya |title=Freestyle Session 2008 Coverage |work=More Than a Stance |date=September 2, 2008 |url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2008/09/freestyle-session-2008-coverage/ |accessdate=August 27, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fda8?url=http://morethanastance.com/features/sf/2008/09/freestyle-session-2008-coverage/ |archivedate=May 28, 2010 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> It is the largest breaking competition in the United States.<ref>{{cite news |last=Bloom |first=Julie |newspaper=The New York Times |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/12/arts/dance/12bloo.html?_r=3&pagewanted=all&oref=slogin |title=With Crews and Zoos, a B-Boy World |date=August 12, 2007 |accessdate=July 31, 2010 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/628p3r6x4?url=http://www.nytimes.com/2007/08/12/arts/dance/12bloo.html?_r=3&pagewanted=all&oref=slogin |archivedate=October 2, 2011 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> The main competitive event is for b-boy crews, but there are also popping and locking competitions for solo competitors.<ref name="funky"/><ref name=stance/> Although the US is the flagship location for Freestyle Session, it is not the only country where it is held. Promoters outside the US pay Cros1 to use Freestyle Session's name and fly him to their location to judge the competition.<ref name=promo>{{cite news|last=Leighton |first=Ken |title=He's Got the Cheese |url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2009/jul/08/hes-got-cheese/ |work=[[San Diego Reader]] |date=July 8, 2009 |accessdate=August 15, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69wKnsBuy?url=http://www.sandiegoreader.com/news/2009/jul/08/hes-got-cheese/ |archivedate=August 15, 2012 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Using this method, Freestyle Session has been held in 18 other countries including Poland, Russia, Switzerland, and Venezuela.<ref name=promo/> *'''[[World Hip Hop Dance Championship|Hip Hop International]]''' (HHI) was founded in 2002 in the United States by Howard and Karen Schwartz.<ref name=hhi/><ref name=all>{{cite web|title=About Us |url=http://hiphopinternational.com/about-us/ |work=HipHopInternational.com |accessdate=May 7, 2012 |archivedate=May 7, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/67UQQ7yr0?url=http://hiphopinternational.com/about-us/}}</ref> There are two categories of competitions: World Battles and World Hip Hop Dance Championship. Within the World Battles category, there are four titles including three-on-three breaking champions, one-on-one popping champion, one-on-one locking champion, and one-on-one all styles (freestyle) champion.<ref name=all/> The World Hip Hop Dance Championship is for hip-hop crews. There are four divisions: junior (ages 8–12), varsity (13–17), adult (18+), and mega crew (all ages).<ref name=racked/> Each crew must have at least five but not more than nine people (mega crew must have 15–40)<ref>{{cite web|title=Rules & Regulations|url=http://www.hiphopinternational.com/rules|work=HipHopInternational.com|accessdate=April 15, 2018|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171206094738/http://www.hiphopinternational.com/rules/|archivedate=December 6, 2017}}</ref> and must perform a routine that showcases three styles of hip-hop dance.<ref name=hhi/> For the 2009 competition, there were 120 crews representing 30 countries.<ref name=hhi/> HHI also created the USA Hip Hop Dance Championship and the television show ''[[America's Best Dance Crew]]''.<ref name=all/> *'''[[Juste Debout]]''' was founded in 2002 by Bruce Ykanji in Paris.<ref name="funky"/><ref name=juste>{{cite web|title=Juste Debout |url=http://www.juste-debout.com/en_UK/in/enjd11-juste-debout |work=Juste-Debout.com |accessdate=December 5, 2011 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/63iHEHyng?url=http://www.juste-debout.com/en_UK/in/enjd11-juste-debout |archivedate=December 5, 2011}}</ref> Competition categories include popping, hip-hop, locking, [[house dance|house]], [[Breakdancing#Dance elements|toprock]], and experimental.<ref name=juste/> Breaking is not included to put more focus on dance styles performed while standing up, hence the name (French for ''Just Standing''). There are not any team trophies at Juste Debout. The experimental and toprock categories are only for solo dancers; popping, new style, locking, and house are for duos.<ref name=juste/> In 2008, Ingrid "Shéyen" Gamboa, the editor-in-chief of ''Juste Debout'' magazine, wrote a book called ''Hip-hop: L'histoire de la danse'' (''Hip Hop: A history of the dance'').<ref>{{cite book |title=Hip-Hop: L'histoire de la danse |last=Gamboa |first=Sheyen |year=2008 |publisher=Scali |location=Paris |isbn=9782350122410 |language=French}}</ref> *'''[[United Dance Organisation]]''' (UDO) was founded in 2002 in the United Kingdom.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.udostreetdance.com/ |title=Homepage - UDO Global |work=UDOStreetDance.com/ |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5rdbHesKE?url=http://www.uniteddance.co.uk/ |archivedate=July 31, 2010 |accessdate=July 31, 2010}}</ref> UDO operates the British Street Dance Championships, the European Street Dance Championships, the North American Championships, and the World Street Dance Championships. The European championships are held in Germany rather than in the UK.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.udostreetdance.com/us/events |title=UDO European Street Dance Championships 2013 |work=UDOStreetDance.com |accessdate=October 22, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6BaiwGGoC?url=http://www.udostreetdance.com/events/european2013 |archivedate=October 22, 2012}}</ref> *'''Street Dance Kemp Europe''' (SDK Europe) is a competition and dance convention founded in 2004 in [[Jedovnice]], Czech Republic.<ref name=sdk2012>{{cite web|title=SKD Europe 2012 international street dance battle winners |url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/07/08/sdk-europe-2012-international-street-dance-battle-winners/ |work=AllStreetDance.co.uk |accessdate=June 25, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69QPDtRRZ?url=http://allstreetdance.co.uk/2012/07/08/sdk-europe-2012-international-street-dance-battle-winners/ |archivedate=July 25, 2012}}</ref> There is a hip-hop crew battle and solo battles for house, krumping, locking, hip-hop male, and hip-hop female dancers.<ref name=sdk2012/> SDK Europe begins every year in the summer and lasts seven days. Daytime hours are reserved primarily for dance workshops and classes taught by an international pool of instructors; competitive events are held at night. All of the classes, workshops, and competitive events are held outside. <!--BLANKED OUT PENDING MORE CONTENT *'''Keep On Dancing''' (KOD) was founded in 2004 in China and is held every May in Beijing. There are four championship tournaments: hip-hop, breaking, locking, and popping.<ref>http://www.prweb.com/releases/2013/3/prweb10516669.htm http://www.showdownla.com/about</ref> <ref>https://web.archive.org/web/20100507040600/http://www.keepondancing.net.cn/photosshow.asp?id=138 {{zh icon}}</ref> <ref>http://translate.google.com/translate?hl=en&sl=zh-CN&u=http://www.jxwujiawu.com {{zh icon}}</ref> <ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20120606220231/http://www.vladofootwear.com/2012site/blog/426/jerkin-in-beijing-kod] </ref> BLANKED OUT PENDING MORE CONTENT--> *'''EuroBattle''' was founded in 2005 in Portugal by Max from Momentum crew.<ref name=hooch>DJ Hooch 2011, p. 184.</ref> There are five competitive events for solo dancers including b-boying, b-girling, hip-hop, locking, and popping.<ref>{{cite web |title=EuroBattle |url=http://www.eurobattle.pt |work=EuroBattle.pt |accessdate=June 4, 2012}}</ref> The international final is held in [[Porto]] but the winner of the Spanish qualifying tournament also gets to compete at the UK B-Boy Championships in London.<ref name=hooch/> *'''World Supremacy Battlegrounds''' is a hip-hop dance competition based in Australia. The heritage of World Supremacy Battlegrounds goes back to 2002 when it began as GROOVE, a local hip-hop competition held in Sydney.<ref name=aussie>{{cite web|title=What is Groove?|url=http://groovetv.com.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12&Itemid=28|work=GrooveTV.com.au|accessdate=May 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120915012530/http://groovetv.com.au/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=12&Itemid=28|archive-date=September 15, 2012|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Over the three years that followed, the competition was renamed Battlegrounds and went national to include dance crews from all over Australia.<ref name=aussie/> It became international in 2006 when crews from the Philippines, Japan, and New Zealand entered the competition.<ref name=aussie/> There are four dance crew categories: open (all ages), junior (12 and under), varsity (12–18), and monster (all ages, 20–40 members). For the 2011 competition, teams from Indonesia, Thailand, Singapore, Malaysia, Vietnam, the Philippines, Japan, Guam, New Zealand, Samoa, and South Africa came to compete.<ref>{{cite web|title=World Supremacy Battlegrounds|url=http://www.enmoretheatre.com.au/events/2011/11/26/world-supremacy-battlegrounds|work=EnmoreTheatre.com|accessdate=May 7, 2012|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111125151348/http://www.enmoretheatre.com.au/events/2011/11/26/world-supremacy-battlegrounds|archive-date=November 25, 2011|dead-url=yes|df=mdy-all}}</ref> *'''[[World of Dance|World of Dance Tour]]''' (WOD) was founded in 2008 by Myron Marten and David Gonzales in [[Pomona, California]].<ref>{{cite av media |people=David Gonzales and Myron Marten (interviewees) |title=World of Dance: A little Past, Present & Future |url=http://www.worldofdance.com/2012/02/29/world-of-dance-a-little-past-present-future-sponsored-by-paul-mitchell/ |date=February 29, 2012 |medium=podcast |publisher=WorldOfDanceTour |accessdate=December 12, 2012}}</ref> It differs from other competitions because there is no final championship. WOD travels to different cities in the United States, Canada, and Europe and holds a competition in each location; therefore, WOD distinguishes itself as a tour.<ref name=canusaeur>{{cite web|url=https://worldofdance.com/events |title=World of Dance Tour: 2012-2013 Tour Schedule |work=WorldofDance.com |accessdate=December 12, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/6CqGDPbm1?url=http://www.worldofdance.com/world-of-dance-tour/ |archivedate=December 11, 2012}}</ref> Each tour stop is a stand-alone competition; they are all related to each other in name only. In 2013, WOD will travel to New York City, [[Vallejo, California|Vallejo]], Seattle, Vancouver, Berlin, Dallas, Toronto, San Diego, Montreal, [[Eindhoven]], Boston, Orlando, Houston, Chicago, Seattle, Honolulu, Los Angeles, [[Union City, New Jersey|Union City]], and [[Antwerp]].<ref name=canusaeur/> *'''World Dance Colosseum''' is a two-on-two dance competition founded in Japan. There are five two-on-two world championship titles: b-boying, locking, popping, hip-hop, and house. Japanese dancers qualify for the international final through preliminary tournaments held in the country but foreign dancers do not qualify through tournaments because 30 of the top-ranked foreign dancers are automatically invited to participate in the final.<ref name=wdc>{{cite web|title=About |url=http://wdcweb.feelin-co.jp/about/hajimeni.html |work=Feelin-Co.jp |accessdate=August 15, 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/69wIFjJUb?url=http://wdcweb.feelin-co.jp/about/hajimeni.html |archivedate=August 15, 2012 |language=ja}}</ref> At the final, the winning duos from the Japanese tournaments compete against the top-ranked foreign duos to determine who is the best.<ref name=wdc/> *'''Vibe Dance Competition''' is a choreography competition that was started by Joseph Lising in 1995 as a Greek Talent Show at UC Irvine. It later evolved into one of the biggest competitions for choreography hip hop teams in the world, hosting teams from all over the US, Canada, the Philippines, and Japan.
==Education== <!--- PLEASE DO NOT TAG THIS SECTION WITH A COPYPASTE BANNER. ----> <!--- The sentence below that references the University of East London's dance degree also appears in the book ---> <!--- "Popular Dance: From Ballroom to Hip-Hop". The book was published in 2010 but this sentence has been in ---> <!--- Wikipedia since August 2009. Please see the talk page for a link to the revision and a longer explanation.--->
In 2004, Safi Thomas founded the [[Hip-Hop Dance Conservatory]] (HHDC) in New York City.<ref name=standard/> Thomas' goal was to provide a comprehensive education to hip-hop dancers that was comparable to what ballet, modern, and jazz dancers experience at their respective institutions.<ref>{{cite web |title=Biography |url=http://www.hdcny.com/staff.html |work=HDCNY.com |accessdate=September 27, 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120204025518/http://www.hdcny.com/staff.html |archive-date=February 4, 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=mdy-all }}</ref> HHDC provides a formal curriculum with dance classes (breaking, freestyle, locking, etc.) and academic classes (dance theory, physiology, kinesiology, etc.) to people who want to pursue hip-hop dance as a career.<ref name=standard/><ref name=bronxnet>{{cite av media |people=Daren Jaime (host) Safi Thomas, Yvonne Chow (artistic director and education director of the Hip-Hop Dance Conservatory) |date=April 27, 2011 |title=Hip Hop Dance Conservatory Repertory Company.mov |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=BsR2HDd1bZU&lr=1 |medium=Television production |accessdate=October 8, 2011 |publisher=BronxnetOPEN |location=Bronx, New York}}</ref> It is the only educational institution in the United States that is exclusively dedicated to hip-hop dance instruction.<ref name=bronxnet/> HHDC does not grant degrees. It is a non-profit organization and repertory company that grants certifications to dancers that complete the three-year program.<ref name=standard/>
Three years later in 2007, the [[University of East London]]'s Center for Performing Arts Development (CPAD) started intake for the only bachelor's degree program in the world specializing in hip-hop, urban, and global dance forms.<ref name=cpad>{{cite web|title=BA (Hons) Dance: Urban Practice |url=https://www.uel.ac.uk/undergraduate/courses/ba-hons-dance-urban-practice |work=UEL.ac.uk |accessdate=August 23, 2009 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/5q4R2fdYa?url=http://www.uel.ac.uk/ipad/programmes/index.htm |archivedate=May 28, 2010}}</ref> The CPAD's program also lasts three years, but it is not exclusive to hip-hop. Students also study African dance, [[kathak]], [[Bollywood#Bollywood song and dance|Bollywood]], and [[capoeira]].
==See also== {{Portal|Hip-hop dance|Hip hop|Dance}} *[[Street dance]] *[[House dance]] *[[Waacking]] *[[Hiplet (dance style)]]

{{lowercase}}
[[Image:Iz toy.png|thumb|128px|right|The green/orange iZ]]
The '''Zizzle iZ''' is an electronic musical toy released in September 2005 from [[Zizzle]]. Taking the shape of an abstract tripod figure, the iZ allows users to interactively manipulate music by twisting particular parts of the figure's body as well as add sound effects to prerecorded sound from a connected audio device. The toy also acts as a dancing speaker.
Since its release it has been available in three color schemes, green/orange, dark blue/light blue and red/yellow.
iZ was developed by [[Roger Shiffman]],<ref>{{cite web|title=A Happy Tune for Zizzle's iZ?|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/bw/stories/2005-08-22/a-happy-tune-for-zizzles-iz|publisher=www.bloomberg.com|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> who also created the [[Giga Pets]], [[Furby]] and [[Poo-Chi]] toys. It was explicitly said during the development phase that a "new [[Furby]]" was the aim.<ref>{{cite news | last=Cole | first=Wendy | title=Toyland's Saviour? | date=August 7, 2005 | publisher=Time | url=http://www.time.com/time/insidebiz/article/0,9171,1090894,00.html | accessdate = October 3, 2006}}</ref> iZ is designed to seem like it has a life of its own and does things out of its user's control when there is interaction with it.
==Modes of operation== Since the iZ is such an abstract kind of toy the easiest way to understand it is by learning what you can do with it.
The iZ has a few methods for input. First, as mentioned, it has an audio jack to connect other audio devices. It has two ears that are twistable and a [[touch-sensitive]] [[tentacle]], called a flicker, on its head. On top of this it also has five buttons placed on different places on its colorful belly. All the input methods except the audio jack are colored in a secondary color to raise its [[affordance]]. The iZ's three legs are also adjustable, but these do not generate any input.
For output the iZ has a built in speaker, a nose that lights up in different colors and two eyes driven by small motors making them able to move up and down.
When another audio device is connected to the iZ it acts as a speaker but also overlays some of its own sound effects on top of the sound from the audio device. When overlaying its own sound effects it also moves its eyes and lights up its nose. By pressing the left side of iZ belly the sound effects will be turned off and iZ will only act as a regular speaker.
When no other audio device is connected iZ has three modes of operation; Play, DJ and WZIZ FM.
In Play mode, which is the startup mode, iZ lets you compose your own music by manipulating his inputs. Each ear corresponds to one audio track, the belly controls the drum track and tempo, and the flicker can be hit for iZ to generate sound effects. iZ randomly adds his own flavour to the track by overlaying witty comments or radio noise.
When in DJ mode iZ evolves the track himself by changing one feature of the track at a time. If the user doesn't like the current music iZ outputs, the belly can be pressed to force iZ to instantly make a change. No interaction is allowed in this mode, so when the user tries any input which will change the track a simple sound is played to indicate that it registered the input but won't react to it.
As stated in iZ's manual "Although he is not a radio, he thinks he is".<ref>{{cite web|title=iZ Operating Instructions |publisher=Zizzle |url=http://www.zizzle.com/images/iZmanual.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |accessdate=2006-10-03 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060526081325/http://zizzle.com/images/iZmanual.pdf |archivedate=2006-05-26 |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> In WZIZ FM mode, iZ creates a completely new track every time it makes a change and inserts a noise to simulate the tuning of radio stations between the tracks. If you adjust the ears, which are supposed to be the antenna, you make iZ create a new random track instantly.
==iZ Cartoon== Zizzle and [[DIC Entertainment]] created a [[direct-to-video]] iZ cartoon, ''iZ and the Zizzles'' in 2007.<ref>{{cite web|title=iZ and the Zizzles|url=http://www.toonarific.com/show.php?show_id=8426|publisher=www.toonarific.com|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=iZ and The Zizzles|url=http://www.dvdtalk.com/reviews/27044/iz-and-the-zizzles/|publisher=www.dvdtalk.com|accessdate=15 December 2015}}</ref> The trailer could be viewed on the Zizzle website.

revision.text:
{{Infobox comic book title |title = Keyhole |image = Keyhole01.jpg |imagesize = |caption = ''Keyhole'' #1. Art by [[Dean Haspiel]]. |schedule = irregular |ongoing = Y |publisher = [[Millennium Publications]],
[[Top Shelf Productions]] |date = June [[1996 in comics|1996]]–December [[1998 in comics|1998]] |issues = 6 |writers = |artists = |pencillers = |inkers = |letterers = |colorists = |editors = |creative_team_month = |creative_team_year = |creators = [[Dean Haspiel]] and [[Josh Neufeld]] |TPB = |ISBN = |TPB# = |ISBN# = |subcat = |altcat = |sort = Keyhole (comics) |addpubcat# = |nonUS = }} '''''Keyhole''''' was a black-and-white [[alternative comics|alternative]] [[comic book]] published from 1996–1998. A two-man [[anthology]] by cartoonists [[Dean Haspiel]] and [[Josh Neufeld]], ''Keyhole'' was published by two different publishers, starting with [[Millennium Publications]] and ending up at [[Top Shelf Productions]]. == Publication history == ''Keyhole'' began as a self-published [[mini-comic]] by the long-time friends Haspiel and Neufeld.Gilbert, Scott. "''Keyhole'' #5," ''The Comics Journal'' #210 (Jan. 1999) ''Keyhole Mini-Comics'' ran for four issues in 1995. Reviewed in ''[[Factsheet Five]]'', ''[[Comics Buyer's Guide]]'', and elsewhere, it was then picked up by Millennium,Bogad, Larry. [http://joshcomix.home.mindspring.com/press/interviews/larry_bogad.htm "A Peek at ''Keyhole''" (Haspiel/Neufeld interview), JoshComix.com (1996).] Accessed Feb. 23, 2009. which published the first full-sized issue in June 1996. With its fourth issue, ''Keyhole'' was released under Millennium's new imprint, [[Millennium Publications|Modern Comics]]. Top Shelf picked up the comic for its fifth and sixth issues. In 2002, Haspiel, Neufeld, and [[Alternative Comics (publisher)|Alternative Comics]] announced plans to publish ''Keyhole'' vol. II,Yarbrough, Beau. [http://www.comicbookresources.com/?page=article&id=1285 "Talent Deserving of Wider Recognition: Dean Haspiel of ''Opposable Thumbs''," Comic Book Resources (July 23, 2002).] Accessed Feb. 23, 2009. but the comic never appeared, and the two cartoonists have since moved on to other projects. == Form and content == Equally inspired by [[Harvey Pekar]]'s ''[[American Splendor]]''[http://www.angelfire.com/yt/sfc/ms.html Neufeld, quoted in "Professional Quotables: M-S," Shadowfish Comics (1999).] Accessed Feb. 23, 2009. and [[Los Bros Hernandez]]' ''[[Love and Rockets (comics)|Love and Rockets]]'', a typical issue of ''Keyhole'' featured an autobiographical travel story by Neufeld, a [[Billy Dogma]] story by Haspiel, and short recurring features such as [[Rob Walker (journalist)|R. Walker]] and Neufeld's "Titans of Finance," Neufeld's one-page "Travel Tips," and the Haspiel/Neufeld collaborative feature "Lionel's Lament." Other stories appearing in ''Keyhole'' included short autobiographical pieces by Haspiel, and assorted collaborations with other writers (including one memorable piece with ''The Duplex Planet'''s [[David Greenberger]]). == Legacy == Although ''Keyhole'' only ran six issues, it was a critically acclaimed project which proved to be a launching pad for both Haspiel and Neufeld's careers. ''The Comics Journal'' characterized ''Keyhole'' this way: "Brought together in a single, independent magazine, these artists' strong, disparate talents create a broad reading experience, and a blending of artistic intentions and personal expression like very few others available today in American comix." Haspiel debuted his existential antihero, Billy Dogma, in ''Keyhole'', a character whose adventures have since been published by Modern Comics, Top Shelf, [[Alternative Comics (publisher)|Alternative Comics]], and [[Image Comics]]. In addition, Haspiel collected many of the autobiographical stories from ''Keyhole'' in ''Opposable Thumbs'' (2001), published by Alternative Comics, and used those stories as a jumping-off point for the ''Street Code'' stories he later told on [[DC Comics]]' [[webcomics]] imprint [[Zuda Comics]]. Neufeld, in turn, collected the "Titans of Finance" stories in a self-titled comic published by Alternative in 2001. In 2004, he collected his ''Keyhole'' travel stories (as well as subsequent ones) in the [[Xeric Award]]-winning graphic novel ''A Few Perfect Hours''. In addition, both cartoonists became regular illustrators for Harvey Pekar and his ''American Splendor'' projects. == Notes == {{reflist}} == References == * {{gcdb series|id=40094|title=Keyhole}} (Millennium) * {{gcdb series|id=44305|title=Keyhole}} (Top Shelf) * {{comicbookdb|type=title|id=20079|title=''Keyhole''}} (Millennium) * {{comicbookdb|type=title|id=20082|title=''Keyhole''}} (Top Shelf) * Boyd, Robert. [http://www.tcj.com/2_archives/r_Ke2La.html "Hit List: ''Keyhole'' to ''Last Gasp Comix & Stories''," ''The Comics Journal'' #189 (Fall 1997).] * VerBeek, Todd. [http://rzero.com/books/Keyhole.html Review of ''Keyhole'' #1-3] == External links == * [http://joshcomix.com/work/keyhole.htm ''Keyhole'' page at Josh Neufeld's website] * [http://www.indyworld.com/keyhole/ Promo for ''Keyhole'' vol. 2, #1 at the Alternative Comics website] * [http://activatecomix.com/50.comic Haspiel & Neufeld's "Lionel's Lament" collaboration, produced after the demise of ''Keyhole''] {{DEFAULTSORT:Keyhole (comics)}} [[Category:1996 comics debuts]] [[Category:Comics anthologies]] [[Category:Comics publications]] [[Category:Top Shelf Productions titles]]

{{Infobox concert |artist = [[Lana Del Rey]] |image = Lana Del Rey - LA to the Moon Tour poster.png |image_size = 220px |album = ''[[Lust for Life (Lana Del Rey album)|Lust for Life]]'' |start_date = {{Start date|2018|01|05}} |end_date = {{End date|2018|08|10}} |number_of_legs = 5 |number_of_shows = 23 in North America
4 in South America
3 in Oceania
8 in Europe
1 in Middle East
39 in total |last_tour = [[The Endless Summer Tour]]
(2015) |next_tour = |this_tour = '''LA to the Moon Tour'''
(2018)}} The '''LA to the Moon Tour''' is the fourth headlining concert tour by American singer [[Lana Del Rey]], in support of her fifth studio album and fourth major-label studio album, [[Lust for Life (Lana Del Rey album)|''Lust for Life'']] (2017). The tour began on January 5, 2018, at the [[Target Center]] in [[Minneapolis]],{{cite web|last=Kreps|first=Daniel|title=Lana Del Rey Sets 2018 LA to the Moon Tour|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/lana-del-rey-sets-2018-la-to-the-moon-tour-w505833|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Ortiz|first=Edwinl|title=Lana Del Rey Announces L.A. to the Moon Tour With Special Guests Jhené Aiko and Kali Uchis|url=https://www.complex.com/music/2017/09/lana-del-rey-la-to-the-moon-tour|work=[[Complex (magazine)|Complex]]|date=September 27, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}} and visited cities across North America, South America, Oceania and Europe. == Background == Del Rey's fifth studio album, ''[[Lust for Life (Lana Del Rey album)|Lust for Life]]'' was officially released worldwide on July 21, 2017. During the months leading up to the album's release, fans and press speculated whether or not Del Rey would embark on a headlining concert tour in support of the album, as she did not for her previous release, ''[[Honeymoon (Lana Del Rey album)|Honeymoon]]''. In an interview for [[Beats 1]] on July 12, 2017, [[Zane Lowe]] asked Del Rey if she planned to go on a world tour and she seemed unsure,{{Cite web|url=https://itunes.apple.com/us/post/idsa.2f404d00-672a-11e7-92c9-80667257793b|date=2017-07-12|title=Listen to 'The Lana Del Rey Interview' posted by Zane Lowe|website=[[Apple Music]]|language=en|access-date=2017-10-16}} but during the following months Del Rey began to announce various one-off promotional concerts across the United Kingdom and United States. The promotional tour took place from July to October 2017, and consisted of concerts at intimate venues in London,{{cite web|last=Trendell|first=Andrew|title=Lana Del Rey announces a rare UK show at Brixton Academy|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/lana-del-rey-uk-tour-show-brixton-academy-tickets-2017-2112646|work=[[NME]]|date=July 18, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}} cities in [[California]]{{Cite news|url=http://www.ocregister.com/2017/07/26/lana-del-rey-announces-intimate-house-of-blues-shows-in-anaheim-and-san-diego-next-week/|title=Lana Del Rey announces intimate House of Blues shows in Anaheim, San Diego next week|date=2017-07-26|work=[[Orange County Register]]|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}{{cite web|last=Demaria|first=Richie|title=Lana Del Rey's Sweet Sadness|url=http://www.independent.com/news/2017/sep/13/lana-del-reys-sweet-sadness/|work=[[Santa Barbara Independent]]|date=September 13, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}}{{cite web|last=Carmancia|first=Jon|title=Review: Lana Del Rey, a Character No More|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/09/06/arts/music/lana-del-rey-lust-for-life-live-review.html|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=September 6, 2017|accessdate=October 17, 2017}} and New York City,{{Cite web|url=http://www.thefader.com/2017/08/10/lana-del-rey-new-york-city-shows-terminal-5|title=Lana Del Rey Announces New York City Shows|date=2017-08-10|website=[[The Fader]]|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}} as well as shows at the [[Echo Arena Liverpool]] and the [[SSE Hydro]] in the United Kingdom.{{Cite news|url=http://www.nme.com/news/music/lana-del-rey-liverpool-glasgow-uk-tour-dates-2116371|title=Lana Del Rey announces Liverpool and Glasgow UK dates|date=2017-07-26|work=[[NME]]|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}} On August 19, 2017, Del Rey confirmed in a video via [[Instagram]] that she would be embarking on an official world tour in support of ''Lust for Life'', as her first official headlining concert tour since [[The Endless Summer Tour]] in 2015, which was in support of ''[[Ultraviolence (album)|Ultraviolence]]''. Del Rey teased many details of the tour during the following weeks, she informed fans of what continents she would be visiting and how to purchase tickets through presale.{{cite web|last=Gamp|first=Joe|title=Lana Del Rey announces world tour in support of chart-topping album Lust For Life|url=http://metro.co.uk/2017/08/19/lana-del-rey-announces-world-tour-in-support-of-chart-topping-album-lust-for-life-6864552/|work=[[Metro (magazine)|Metro]]|date=August 19, 2017|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} The first dates for the LA to the Moon Tour were eventually announced on September 27, 2017, with a leg of North American dates,{{Cite web|url=https://pitchfork.com/news/lana-del-rey-announces-tour/|title=Lana Del Rey Announces Tour|date=2017-09-27|website=[[Pitchfork (website)|Pitchfork]]|language=en|access-date=2017-09-28}} and on the same day Del Rey announced that she would be appearing at various South American festivals.{{Cite news|url=http://www.billboard.com/articles/news/festivals/7980846/lollapalooza-brasil-argentina-chile-2018-south-america-headliners|title=Lollapalooza Chile, Argentina, and Brasil 2018 Headliners: Pearl Jam & More|date=2017-09-27|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|access-date=2017-09-28|language=en-US}}{{Cite news|url=http://www.eltiempo.com/cultura/musica-y-libros/artistas-del-cartel-de-estereo-picnic-2018-135098|title=Artistas del cartel de Estereo Picnic 2018|date=2017-09-27|work=[[El Tiempo (Colombia)|El Tiempo]]|access-date=2017-09-28|language=es}} Tickets for the North American shows became available for presale on September 29, followed by general sale on October 2. The North American leg is supported by American singer [[Jhené Aiko]] and Colombian-American singer [[Kali Uchis]]. Australian and European dates for the tour were announced on October 16, 2017.{{cite web|last=Waterhouse|first=Jonah|title=Lana Del Rey Releases Australia Tour Dates|url=https://www.elle.com.au/culture/lana-del-rey-australia-tour-dates-14697|work=[[Elle (magazine)|Elle]]|date=October 16, 2017|accessdate=November 19, 2017}}European dates: *{{cite web|url=https://www.livenation.it/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|title=Lana Del Rey – Biglietti per i Concerti|work=[[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation Italia]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119203028/https://www.livenation.it/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|language=it|archivedate=November 19, 2017}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.livenation.de/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|title=Lana Del Rey Tourdaten & Konzerte 2018|work=[[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation Deutschland]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119202952/https://www.livenation.de/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|language=de|archivedate=November 19, 2017}} *{{cite web|url=https://fr.livenation.be/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|title=Lana Del Rey Tickets concert|work=[[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation Belgique]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119203117/https://fr.livenation.be/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|language=fr|archivedate=November 19, 2017}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.livenation.es/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|title=Lana Del Rey Entradas de Conciertos|work=[[Live Nation Entertainment|Live Nation España]]|accessdate=November 19, 2017|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20171119202917/https://www.livenation.es/artist/lana-del-rey-tickets|language=es|archivedate=November 19, 2017}}{{cite web|title=Lana Del Rey ha annunciato due concerti in Italia ad aprile 2018!|language=it|url=http://news.mtv.it/musica/lana-del-rey-italia-2018-concerti/|work=[[MTV (Italy)|MTV Italia]]|date=October 17, 2017|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} On January 16, 2018, it was announced that American singer [[Børns]], whom Del Rey had recently collaborated with on two tracks for his second studio album ''[[Blue Madonna]]'', would be joining Del Rey as the opening act for the Australian leg of the tour.{{cite web|title=Lana Del Rey Tour 2018 Australia, Dates and Tickets|url=https://www.secretsounds.com/tours/lana-del-rey-tour-2018/|publisher=Secret Sounds|accessdate=January 16, 2018}} ==Development and stage== In an interview with [[MTV]] during October 2017, Del Rey stated that she was working to create a stage design for the tour that incorporates "lots of senses", and beach themed projections with "beautiful structures that move in and out of the stage to give it a classic feeling".{{cite web|title=Lana Del Rey Talks Next Music Video & Tour w/ Kali Uchis & Jhené Aiko | MTV News|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FTUk2AOuZhM|work=[[YouTube]]|date=October 31, 2017|accessdate=November 19, 2017}} The stage design, designed by Jason Ardizzone-West, was revealed once the tour began on January 5, 2018. The stage features an array of beach-themed props and is backed by a large screen displaying visuals designed by Storme Whitby-Grubb.{{cite web|title=Set Design — Lana Del Rey Arena Tour 2018|url=http://www.ardizzonewest.com/setdesign#/lana-del-rey/|publisher=Jason Ardizzone-West|accessdate=January 16, 2018}} Terence Cawley of ''[[The Boston Globe]]'' described the set-up as a "microcosm of [Del Rey's] beloved California" with a display of rock formations, palm trees, and beach chairs.{{cite web|last=Cawley|first=Terence|title=California dreaming with Lana Del Rey at TD Garden|url=https://www.bostonglobe.com/arts/music/2018/01/14/california-dreaming-with-lana-del-rey-garden/U9llaM9lKElBlRGWAPjTPJ/story.html|work=[[The Boston Globe]]|date=January 14, 2018|accessdate=January 16, 2018}} Reed Fischer of ''GoMN'' similarly described the stage as "pure Los Angeles", suiting the title of the tour, "LA to the Moon", with "projections of crashing waves, a fast-moving highway, and a sun-drenched swimming pool danced on the stage floor throughout the night". ==Set list== This set list is representative of the show on January 5, 2018 in [[Minneapolis, Minnesota]]. It does not represent all dates throughout the tour.{{cite web|last=Harris|first=Keith|title=A surprisingly down-to-earth Lana Del Rey takes her time at Target Center|url=http://www.citypages.com/music/a-surprisingly-down-to-earth-lana-del-rey-takes-her-time-at-target-center/468263103|work=[[City Pages]]|date=January 8, 2018|accessdate=January 8, 2018}}{{cite web|last=Fischer|first=Reed|title=Review: Lana Del Rey rocks slow and steady at Target Center|url=https://www.gomn.com/life/review-lana-del-rey-at-target-center-minneapolis|work=GoMN|date=January 7, 2018|accessdate=January 8, 2018}} {{div col|colwidth=30em}} # "13 Beaches" {{small|(with "[[Experiment in Terror]]" intro)}} # "Pretty When You Cry" # "Cherry" {{small|(with "[[Scarborough Fair (ballad)|Scarborough Fair]]" outro)}} # "[[Born to Die (song)|Born to Die]]" # "[[Blue Jeans *During the show in Melbourne on March 31, 2018, Del Rey performed "[[High by the Beach]]", "[[Gods & Monsters (song)|Gods & Monsters]]", "Million Dollar Man", "[[West Coast (song)|West Coast]]" and venues) "Yayo", "God Bless America – and All the Beautiful Women in It", "Honeymoon", "Body Electric", "Diet Mountain Dew", "Dark Paradise", "Radio", "Get Free", "Old Money", "Cruel World", {{Infobox musical artist | name = Lasse Berghagen | image = File:Lasse Berghagen 2012.jpg | image_size = 200px | landscape = | alt = | caption = Berghagen in Stockholm in 2012 | background = solo_singer | birth_name = | native_name = | native_name_lang = | alias = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1945|5|13|df=y}} | birth_place = [[Enskede-Årsta-Vantör|Enskede]], Sweden | origin = | death_date = | death_place = | genre = [[Pop music|Pop]]
[[Schlager]] | occupation = [[Singer]] | instrument = [[Acoustic guitar]] | years_active = [[1965 in music|1965]]- | label = | associated_acts = | website = }} '''Lars "Lasse" Nils Berghagen''' (born 13 May 1945{{cite web |url=http://www.birthday.se/sok/?f=Lars&l=Berghagen |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120905014458/http://www.birthday.se/sok/?f=Lars&l=Berghagen |archivedate=2012-09-05 |df= }}) is a [[Sweden|Swedish]] [[singer]], [[songwriter]] and [[actor]]. Berghagen is a well known singer-songwriter in Sweden. He released his first record in 1965, aged just 19. Four years later, in 1969, he released the single ''[[Teddybjörnen Fredriksson]]'' ("The Teddybear Fredriksson"), which has become a classic. Other hits include ''[[Sträck ut din hand (song)|Sträck ut din hand]]'', ''[[En kväll i juni]]'' and ''[[Stockholm i mitt hjärta]]''. Berghagen won the Swedish [[Melodifestivalen 1975|1975 Melodifestivalen]] with the song ''[[Jennie, Jennie]]''.{{cite web |url=http://svt.se/melodifestivalen/ommelodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-1975 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120719232510/http://svt.se/melodifestivalen/ommelodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-1975 |archivedate=2012-07-19 |df= }} He also participated in [[Melodifestivalen 1974]] with the song ''[[Min kärlekssång till dig]]'' ("My Lovesong For You"), taking second place (after [[ABBA]]).{{cite web |url=http://svt.se/melodifestivalen/ommelodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-1974 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-06-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20120719075037/http://svt.se/melodifestivalen/ommelodifestivalen/melodifestivalen-1974 |archivedate=2012-07-19 |df= }} He hosted the popular summer TV show ''[[Allsång på Skansen]]'' (''Singalong at Skansen'') from 1994 to 2003. During his time as host the show increased its ratings from 600,000 to 2,000,000 viewers, which by Swedish standards is considered an impressive rating (Sweden has approximately 10,000,000 inhabitants). He was married to singer [[Barbro Svensson|Barbro "Lill-Babs" Svensson]] from 1965 to 1968. He is the father of actress and TV personality [[Malin Berghagen]], and the father-in-law of [[Tommy Nilsson]]. Berghagen also holds the official world record for hitting a golf ball the longest distance, from one country, through another and into a third.{{Citation needed|date=September 2010}} This was done at [[Treriksröset]], when he hit a golf ball from Norway, through Sweden, and into Finland. ==Discography== *1969 ''Lars Berghagen'' *1972 ''Min värld i toner'' *1973 ''Ding Dong'' *1975 ''[[Jennie, Jennie]]'' *1975 ''Hålligång på krogen'' *1976 ''Jag ville bli någon'' *1977 ''Tacka vet jag logdans'' *1978 ''Det är jul'' *1980 ''Tillsammans igen'' *1983 ''Dagboksblad'' *1988 ''Nära naturen'' *1991 ''På begäran'' *1995 ''[[Sträck ut din hand]]'' *1997 ''Inte bara drömmar'' *1999 ''Till sommaren och dig'' *2001 ''Som en blänkande silvertråd'' *2001 ''Det bästa med Lasse Berghagen'' (4-disc box) *2002 ''Stockholm, mina drömmars stad'' *2003 ''Lasses favoriter from "Allsång på Skansen"'' (3-disc box) *2004 ''Lars Berghagen 20 klassiker'' *2004 ''Jul i vårt hus'' *2009 ''Lasse Berghagen och Sveriges Radios Symfoniorkester'' *2011 ''Bara lite längtan'' ==Filmography== *1972: ''Firmafesten'' *1978: ''Dante akta're för Hajen'' *1995: ''Bert - den siste oskulden'' ==References and sources== *{{Cite encyclopedia | title=Lars Berghagen | encyclopedia=[[Nationalencyklopedin]] | language=Swedish | url=http://www.ne.se/lars-berghagen | accessdate=10 May 2010}} *[http://smdb.kb.se/catalog/search?q=%22Lasse+Berghagen%22+ Swedish Media Database] *[http://www.lasseberghagen.se/ Official website] {{Commons category|Lasse Berghagen}} {{S-start}} {{Succession box| before=[[ABBA]]
with ''"[[Waterloo (ABBA song)|Waterloo]]"'' | title=[[Sweden in the Eurovision Song Contest]] | years= [[Eurovision Song Contest 1975|1975]] | after=[[Forbes (band)|Forbes]]
with ''"[[Beatles (song)|Beatles]]"'' }} {{S-end}} {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Berghagen, Lasse}} [[Category:1945 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Singers from Stockholm]] [[Category:Swedish songwriters]] [[Category:Swedish male singers]] [[Category:Eurovision Song Contest entrants of 1975]] [[Category:Swedish Eurovision Song Contest entrants]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen contestants]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen winners]] [[Category:Swedish television personalities]] [[Category:Melodifestivalen presenters]] [[Category:Swedish male actors]] [[Category:20th-century Swedish singers]] {{entertainer-stub}}

page.title: List of Jimmy Fallon games and sketches

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues| {{more citations needed|date=November 2015}} {{very long|date=June 2014}} }}
{{Dynamic list}} The following is a list of recurring games, sketches, and other comedy routines from the [[NBC]] late night talk show ''[[The Tonight Show Starring Jimmy Fallon]]'', and its predecessor, ''[[Late Night with Jimmy Fallon]]''. The sketches feature host [[Jimmy Fallon]], house band [[The Roots]], announcer/sidekick [[Steve Higgins]], the show's writers, celebrity guests, and audience members. Most of the skits below appeared only on ''Late Night'', while some have carried over to the ''Tonight Show''.
==Weekly routines==
===Pros and Cons=== Every Tuesday on the show, Jimmy weighs the pros and cons of a topic that's currently in the news, with the pros being the setups and the cons being the punchlines. (e.g. Pro: With Tiger competing, this year's Masters promises to be the most exciting golf tournament ever. Con: That being said, it's still golf.) Special editions of the sketch include: "The reissue of the [[Rolling Stones]]' album ''[[Exile on Main St.]]''", in which Jimmy was joined via satellite by [[Mick Jagger]], [[Keith Richards]] and [[Charlie Watts]]; one in which the topic was "The New NFL Season", where Jimmy was joined by [[Justin Tuck]] of the [[New York Giants]]; and "The NFL Playoffs" with [[New York Jets]] placekicker [[Nick Folk]].
===''Tonight Show'' #Hashtags=== Every Thursday (formerly Wednesday) on the show, Jimmy reads off viewer comments from a topic for discussion he started the night before on [[Twitter]]. Topics have included "My parents are weird", "Why don't they make that?", "Beach fail", and "Makes Me Mad"
Jimmy previously created a spin-off named "Late Night [[Instagram]]s".
===Thank-you Notes=== Nearly every Friday on the show, Jimmy writes thank-you notes. He claims that Friday is the day he catches up on "personal stuff" like checking his inbox, returning e-mails, and writing his weekly thank-you notes. He explains that he is running behind and asks the audience if they wouldn't mind if he took time out of the show to write them, and asks [[James Poyser]] to play some accompanying music (a sped-up version of U2's "[[October (song)|October]]"). The notes are sarcastic in tone and involve current events, people in the news, or things that annoy Jimmy (e.g. "Thank you, [[pony tail]]s, for turning the backs of girls' heads into horses' butts").
The sketch airs on Thursday during the week of [[Thanksgiving (United States)|Thanksgiving]], in deference to the holiday. The sketch aired on Thursday, March 28, 2013, because the show was off for [[Good Friday]] that year. It also aired on Thursday, February 5, 2015, during the ''Tonight Show'''s week in Los Angeles (the show did not air on Friday that week).
Jimmy also wrote out a special [[2010 Winter Olympics|Winter Olympics]]-themed set of thank you notes during [[NBC]]'s prime-time Olympic coverage on February 26, 2010 (a Friday); anchor [[Bob Costas]] "played" the usual thank you note-writing music (by pretending to play along on a keyboard while a pre-recorded track of the music played in the background). Costas and Jimmy reprised the bit with a [[2012 Summer Olympics|Summer Olympics]]-themed set on August 10, 2012 (also a Friday).
[[Mayor of New York City|Mayor]] [[Michael Bloomberg]] joined Jimmy behind the desk to write out some thank-you notes of his own on Friday, December 13, 2013.
[[Regis Philbin]] joined Jimmy with a little help to write out some thank-you notes of his own on Friday, June 19, 2015.
NASA astronaut [[Scott Kelly (astronaut)|Scott Kelly]] wrote the first thank-you note in space, during his year-long mission to the International Space Station.
President [[Barack Obama]] joined Jimmy in writing out some thank-you notes on Thursday, June 9, 2016.
It was announced on January 31, 2011 that Fallon had signed a book deal to publish entries from the series as two books, the first of which, ''Thank You Notes'', was released May 23, 2011.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nymag.com/daily/entertainment/2011/01/jimmy_fallon_book_deal.html|title=Jimmy Fallon Gets a Book Deal|last=Paskin|first=Willa|publisher=[[New York (magazine)|New York Magazine]]|date=January 31, 2011|accessdate=January 31, 2011}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Thank You Notes [Paperback]|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0892967412|work=Amazon.com|accessdate=6 May 2011}}</ref> The sequel, ''Thank You Notes 2'', was released on May 22, 2012.<ref>{{cite web|title=Thank You Notes 2 [Paperback]|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/0892967366|work=Amazon.com|accessdate=8 May 2012}}</ref> The new book also has a limited edition which has a sound chip that plays the "Thank-you Notes" theme music (to which Jimmy replies "We don't even need James Poyser any more", then the camera cuts to Poyser looking depressed).
===The Week in Review=== Also on Fridays, Jimmy shows a mashup of news anchors reading the week's biggest headlines, set to music.
===''Tonight Show'' Superlatives=== Done on Wednesdays mostly during the NFL season. Similar to a high school yearbook, Jimmy shows pictures of NFL players and says what "Most likely to…" awards they received, to promote the players on the teams of that week's episode of ''[[NBC Sunday Night Football]]'', which are simply based on what they look like. He also does it for random celebrities (including the cast of the new season of ''The Bachelorette''), as well as NHL and NBA players, whose playoffs also air on NBC. For the final version of the skit on ''Late Night'', NFL players listed the awards for the show's writers. They then doused Jimmy with Gatorade. Jimmy then gave away Super Bowl tickets to a lucky audience member.
===Screengrabs=== Sort of an updated version of [[Jay Leno]]'s "[[Headlines (Jay Leno)|Headlines]]", Fallon shows viewer-submitted screen shots from various media (phones, Internet, television, etc.) that contain typos or similar accidentally funny errors, using an [[iPad]] ([[Apple Inc.]] is one of the show's main sponsors). The final selection is always a picture of a man who the viewer claims looks like Jimmy, who will then put on a costume to match.
===Trump News Network=== Citing [[Donald Trump]]'s distrust of mainstream news, Jimmy appears as the President on "Trump News Network" in which he unsuccessfully spins negative stories about him to portray him in a more positive light, instead having the reverse effect.
==TV parodies==
===''7th Floor West''=== In the first two seasons was a parody of the [[MTV]] series ''[[The Hills (TV series)|The Hills]]'', documenting Jimmy's arrival to ''Late Night'' and his initial struggles in the beginning of the show, such as whether to wear a red tie or a blue tie on his premiere episode.<ref>[http://www.latenightwithjimmyfallon.com/video/clips/7th-floor-west-part-1-3509/1055381/ NBC.com - Late Night with Jimmy Fallon - 7th Floor West Episode 1, Part 1]</ref> Season 1 of the series dealt with Jimmy's passive-aggressive power struggle with [[A.D. Miles]], ''Late Night'''s head writer. Future ''Saturday Night Live'' cast member [[Jenny Slate]] appeared as Jimmy's assistant who betrayed his trust by collaborating with Miles. New installments premiered every Monday during the summer of 2009, and have a storyline focused on continuity, much as ''The Hills'' does.
Season two finds Miles, having moved to the costume department in the season one finale, unhappy with his new role and wishing he was back among the writing staff. As revenge, he dresses Jimmy in ridiculous clothes in order to make Jimmy look like an idiot. During the season, Jimmy and Miles both run for the position of fire warden of the floor. In the series finale, Jimmy and Miles decide to end their silly feud and be friends again, Jimmy gives Miles his job in the writing department back, and they appointed fire-safety enthusiast [[Questlove]] to be fire warden.

===''Real Housewives of Late Night''=== ''Real Housewives of Late Night'' is a recurring parody of the various ''[[The Real Housewives of...]]'' reality shows with five cast members playing the roles of their fictional "wives". The cast includes ''Late Night'' host [[Jimmy Fallon]] as power-mad Denise, announcer [[Steve Higgins]] as gravel-voiced chain smoker Lydia, [[The Roots|Roots]] bassist [[Owen Biddle (musician)|Owen Biddle]] as alcoholic Renee, head writer [[A.D. Miles]] as uptight Dale (who is usually accompanied by her son Caleb, who is allergic to all food other than a special paste), and 'director' (in reality, writer) [[Bashir Salahuddin]] as compulsive eater Yvonne. Each segment continues from the last in an overarching story similar to ''7th Floor West''. The plot revolves around alliances and over-the-top rivalries between the characters resulting in exaggerated responses by the characters.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.latenightwithjimmyfallon.com/real-housewives-of-late-night/ |title=The Real Housewives of Late Night |publisher=Latenightwithjimmyfallon.com |date= |accessdate=2013-01-17}}</ref> ''[[Today with Kathie Lee and Hoda|Today Show's Fourth Hour]]'' hosts [[Kathy Lee Gifford]] and [[Hoda Kotb]] appeared on the set of their show during one episode.
When the show was in [[Indianapolis]] for [[Super Bowl XLVI]], the housewives met up with some of the "wives" of the [[Indianapolis Colts]] players (actually the players themselves in drag), including [[Dallas Clark]]'s wife Sherry, [[Pierre Garçon]]'s wife Noelle, [[Antoine Bethea]]'s wife Daris, [[Robert Mathis]]'s wife Shay-Shay, and [[Dan Orlovsky]]'s wife Marianne. During the episode, Denise inadvertently started a fight with the Colts wives when she mistakenly congratulated the Colts on making the Super Bowl (thinking the game was played at one of the teams' home stadium), and was informed they were actually the league's worst team that season, with their [[2011 Indianapolis Colts season|2-14 record]]. This caused Denise and Yvonne to quickly resolve their differences and unite against the Colts wives, causing the ''Late Night'' wives to win the brawl.
====Episodes====
=====Season 1===== *"Thick as Thieves" (aired September 14, 2009) *"Surprise!" (aired October 1, 2009) *"Let's Get Physical" (aired October 15, 2009) *"The Renovation" (aired November 5, 2009) *"Giving Thanks" (aired November 20, 2009) *"What a Difference 'Today' Makes" (aired December 10, 2009) *"The Gift" (aired December 23, 2009) *''Bonus footage from the first six episodes aired December 22, 2009''
=====Season 2===== *"We're Back" (aired February 24, 2011) *"''[[Glamour (magazine)|Glamour]]'' Photo Shoot" (aired April 7, 2011) *"Real Housewives of Late Night in Indianapolis" (aired February 2, 2012)
===''6-Bee''=== Named after ''Late Night'''s location at 30 Rock, Studio 6B, ''6-Bee'' is a parody of the [[Fox Broadcasting Company|FOX]] series ''[[Glee (TV series)|Glee]]''. After Jimmy goes to an NBC accountant (played by [[Fred Armisen]]) to request money for cue cards, he is turned down because the $375 they would cost is too expensive. However, Jimmy discovers that the first place prize money for glee club sectionals (a flyer for which is conveniently posted in the hallway outside Studio 6B across from a row of lockers) is $380, so he decides to gather the ''Late Night'' crew – including [[A. D. Miles]], [[Paula Pell]], [[Bashir Salahuddin]], and [[Abby Elliott]] from ''[[Saturday Night Live|SNL]]'' – together to compete. As practice, they sing the [[Bon Jovi]] song "[[Livin' on a Prayer]]".
Later, Jimmy and the ''Late Night'' squad discover that the cast of the NBC show ''[[Parks and Recreation]]'' (including [[Amy Poehler]], [[Rashida Jones]], [[Nick Offerman]], [[Aubrey Plaza]], and [[Chris Pratt]]) will also be competing in sectionals – and ''Parks & Rec'' has recruited [[The Roots]] to be in their squad. Jimmy is so frustrated by the Roots' defection that he sings the [[Twisted Sister]] song "[[We're Not Gonna Take It (Twisted Sister song)|We're Not Gonna Take It]]" (which, eventually, both squads join in on).
Episode two of ''6-Bee'' won an Emmy in the category "Outstanding Short Form Picture Editing" at the [[62nd Primetime Emmy Awards|2010 Primetime]] [[Creative Arts Emmy Award|Creative Arts Emmys]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.emmys.com/sites/emmys.com/files/62ndemmys_noms_4.pdf |title=62nd Emmys nominations |publisher=Emmys |date= |accessdate=2013-01-17}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|author=HollywoodNews.com |url=http://www.hollywoodnews.com/2010/08/22/primetime-creative-emmys-roundup-hbo-betty-white-are-hits/ |title=Primetime Creative Emmys Roundup: HBO, Betty White are hits |publisher=HollywoodNews.com |date=2010-08-22 |accessdate=2013-01-17}}</ref>
====Episodes==== *Episode 1 (aired February 1, 2010) *Episode 2 (aired April 8, 2010)
===''Late''=== ''Late'' is a parody of the [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] series ''[[Lost (TV series)|Lost]]''. It deals with the twelve survivors of an elevator crash on the day of the very first show of ''Late Night with Jimmy Fallon''. ===''Suckers''=== On November 8, 2010 was a musical parody of several vampire shows and movies ([[The Twilight Saga (film series)|the ''Twilight'' films]], ''[[The Vampire Diaries (TV series)|The Vampire Diaries]]'', ''[[True Blood]]'', ''[[Buffy the Vampire Slayer (TV series)|Buffy the Vampire Slayer]]'', ''[[Angel (1999 TV series)|Angel]]'', etc.). In the first episode, a new writer at ''Late Night'', Angelique (Kate Simses), discovers that several of the show's writers, including Jimmy, [[Bashir Salahuddin]], and [[Morgan Murphy (comedian)|Morgan Murphy]], are secretly [[vampire]]s, and is herself "turned" by Miles.
===''Jersey Floor''=== ''Jersey Floor'' is parody of the [[MTV]] series ''[[Jersey Shore (TV series)|Jersey Shore]]''. It takes place on a floor in the 30 Rock building that, in addition to being a regular office floor, has a social scene filled with hot tubs, tanning, gyms and lots of partying. The floor is accessed by a special elevator that "Jersey-fies" its riders when the "Jersey Floor" button is pressed. It features [[Jimmy Fallon|Jimmy "J-Bro" Fallon]], [[Steve Higgins|Steve "The Inflation" Higgins]], [[Josh Meyers (actor)|Josh "DJ Josh" Meyers]], [[Abby Elliott|Abby "Lovebug" Elliott]], [[A.D. Miles|A.D. "Miles" Miles]], Bashir "B-Hole" Salahuddin, and [[Rachel Dratch|Rachel "Drootchie" Dratch]]. Episode 2 featured guest stars [[Tina Fey]] and [[Amy Poehler]]. Episode 3 featured cameos from many members of the ''Jersey Shore'' cast, including [[Nicole Polizzi|Snooki]], [[Jennifer Farley|JWoww]], Sammi Sweetheart, [[Deena Nicole Cortese|Deena Nicole]], [[Ronnie Ortiz|Ronnie]], and Vinny, who were de-Jerseyfied (appearing in more conservative clothes and hairstyles) when they went back to the regular floor with their analogues, then decided they didn't like it and went back to the Jersey Floor.
====Episodes==== *Episode 1 (aired March 2, 2011) *Episode 2 (aired May 5, 2011) *Episode 3 (aired September 21, 2011)
===''Downton Sixbey''=== ''Downton Sixbey'' is a parody of the [[ITV (TV network)|ITV]]/[[PBS]] series ''[[Downton Abbey]]''. When the Earl of Downton Sixbey (Jimmy) receives word that the current heir to Downton Sixbey, [[Carson Daly]] is missing following a hot-air ballooning accident, a distant nephew (Questlove) receives word that he is to become the new heir. However, in the second episode, Daly appears at Downton Sixbey, alive and well (only to seemingly perish before the third episode, in another hot-air ballooning accident, along with [[Usher (entertainer)|Usher]] and [[Shakira]]).

===''Mister Romney's Neighborhood''=== On October 9, 2012, Jimmy, as [[Mitt Romney]], did a parody of ''[[Mister Rogers' Neighborhood]]'' called ''Mister Romney's Neighborhood''. [[Barack Obama]] (Dion Flynn) also appeared as the mailman (a parody of [[David Newell|Mr. McFeely]]). Later, he visited the [[Neighborhood of Make-Believe]] ("where me and [[Paul Ryan]] get most of our facts from") and outed Henrietta Pussycat as a puppet operated by a union worker. This sketch was in response to the real Romney's claim that he will discontinue federal PBS funding if he is elected president.
