revision.comment: rmv author bio - not how book articles are styled
revision.text:
{{Infobox book | italic title = <!--(see above)--> | name = Making Samba: A New History of Race in Brazil | image = Cover_of_Making_Samba_by_Marc_Hertzman.jpg | image_size = | alt = | caption = | author = Marc A. Hertzman | audio_read_by = | title_orig = | orig_lang_code = | title_working = | translator = | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = United States | language = English | series = | release_number = | subject = | genre = Music criticism | set_in = | publisher = Duke University Press | publisher2 = | pub_date = | english_pub_date = | published = 2013 | media_type = Print (hardcover paperback)/ Online | pages = | awards = | isbn = 9780822354154 | isbn_note = | oclc = | dewey = | congress = | preceded_by = | followed_by = | native_wikisource = | wikisource = | notes = | exclude_cover = | website = }}
'''''Making Samba: A New History of Race and Music in Brazil''''' is a book by Marc A. Hertzman published by [[Duke University Press]] in 2013.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.dukeupress.edu/Making-Samba/|title=Making Samba|work=Duke University Press|access-date=2018-01-22|language=en-US}}</ref> Hertzman's concern with the historical narrative surrounding how [[Samba]] became one of Brazil's most valuable cultural staples prompted him to write this book. By tracing the careers of {{ill|Donga (musician)|lt=Donga|pt|Donga (músico)}} and [[Gilberto Gil]] from the late nineteenth century to the 1970s, Hertzman explores various themes such as intellectual property claims, popular music, race, gender, national identity, and the history of Afro-Brazilians in Rio de Janeiro, and how they all contribute to the making of Samba within the Brazilian State.<ref name=":0" /> == Synopsis == Hertzman's main argument in this book is that the historical narrative surrounding the emergence of samba in Brazil has either been over-criticized, or exceedingly fetishized. By using wide ranging evidence, such as Brazilian musicians' salary contracts, their involvement and activism with various musical associations, and their encounters with law enforcement, Hertzman explores their struggles in exerting their agency by claiming their music as what he calls, "intellectual property." While Hertzman's book explores different themes such as "musical blackface" and "the purity of samba," Hertzman discusses them within the context of [[Afro-Brazilians|Afro-Brazilian]] figures that were heavily involved with the progress of Samba so that his argument doesn't get off track.<ref name=":0" />
== Critical Reception ==
''Making Samba: A New History of Race and Music in Brazil'' has been highly praised by a variety of historical scholars. Three critical reviews come from Charles A. Perrone in the [[Luso-Brazilian Review]] 51 (2014): 209-213.<ref name=":3">{{Cite journal|last=Perrone|first=Charles A.|date=2014|title=Review of Making Samba: A New History of Race & Music in Brazil by Marc A. Hertzman|url=|journal=Luso-Brazilian Review|volume=51|pages=209-213|via=}}</ref> Marshall Eakin in ''[[Social History (journal)|Social History]]'' 39 (2014): 287-289.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Eakin|first=Marshall|date=2014|title=Review of Making Samba: A New History of Race & Music in Brazil by Marc A. Hertzman|url=|journal=Social History|volume=39|pages=287-289|via=}}</ref> As well as Paulina Alberto in ''Americas'' 73 (2016): 266-268.<ref name=":2">{{Cite journal|last=Alberto|first=Paulina L.|date=2016|title=Cultural/Literary Studies - Making Samba: A New History of Race and Music in Brazil. By Marc Hertzman. Durham: Duke University Press, 2013. Pp. 392. Illustrations. $94.95 cloth.|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/journals/americas/article/culturalliterary-studies-making-samba-a-new-history-of-race-and-music-in-brazil-by-marc-hertzman-durham-duke-university-press-2013-pp-392-illustrations-9495-cloth/6BA7B75BB0C5363B37D4597B2251B6C2|journal=The Americas|volume=73|issue=2|pages=266–268|doi=10.1017/tam.2016.44|issn=0003-1615}}</ref> All of these scholars agree that Hertzman's work has been a big success in his field and that it "offers a substantial, indeed superb, contribution to the already robust literature about the birth of samba in the aftermath of slavery in Brazil and its rise to the status of national rhythm by the early twentieth century."<ref name=":2" /> Perrone adds, "Even seasoned veterans of this subject will find some edifying surprises."<ref name=":3" />
== Awards == The [[Latin American Studies Association]] awarded ''Making Samba'' Honorable Mention for the 2014 Bryce Wood Book Award.<ref name=":0" /> * Conrad Humanities Scholar (2017-2022) * New England Council of Latin American Studies Best Dissertation Prize (2009) * Fulbright-Hays (2004)<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://history.illinois.edu/directory/profile/hertzman|title=Marc Adam Hertzman PhD {{!}} History at Illinois|website=history.illinois.edu|language=en|access-date=2018-02-18}}</ref>
== References == <references />{{Brazil-hist-book-stub}} [[Category:Brazilian music]]

revision.comment: Moving from [[Category:Roman Catholic church in fiction]] to [[Category:Catholic Church in fiction]] per [[Wikipedia:Categories for discussion/Log/2018 August 5]] using [[c:Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]
revision.text:
{{Infobox play | name = Mass Appeal | image = | image_size = | image_alt = | caption = | writer = Bill C. Davis | chorus = | characters = Father Tim Farley
Mark Dolson | setting = | premiere = {{Start date|1980|05|11}} | place = [[Bohemian National Hall|Stage 73]]
[[New York City]] | orig_lang = English | series = | subject = | genre = | web = }} '''''Mass Appeal''''' is a two-character play by Bill C. Davis. The [[comedy-drama]] focuses on the conflict between a complacent [[Roman Catholic]] [[pastor]] and the idealistic young [[deacon]] who is assigned to his affluent, suburban [[parish]]. ==Plot== Father Tim Farley is highly popular with his parishioners due to his charm, wit, easy-going manner, and entertaining (but unchallenging) [[sermons]]. One Sunday, [[seminary|seminarian]] Mark Dolson interrupts Farley's sermon to challenge his stance on the ordination of women. The pastor is outraged yet intrigued by the young man, and asks to have him assigned to work with him. Dolson is a firebrand eager to change the Church. He enjoys attacking Farley's "song and dance theology" and questioning why he drinks so much. Dolson feels it's his job to shake parishioners out of their complacency. Farley likes Dolson, but sees that he'll never succeed as a priest if all he does is irritate people and make enemies. Each man has something to teach the other about how to perform his priestly duties. ==Productions== ''Mass Appeal'' was first performed in many small theatres, including The No Smoking Playhouse in Manhattan, produced by Pearl Tisman Minsky and Ken Berman, with Berman playing the role of Farley and Bill Davis playing the role of Dolson. At the suggestion of the pastor of [[The Actors' Church]], Minsky brought the play to [[Geraldine Fitzgerald]], with whom she was acquainted. When Fitzgerald agreed to direct the play, she took it to Circle In The Square Theatre in Greenwich Theatre who agreed to workshop it. After the workshop, Circle In The Square did not pursue the play. Geraldine Fitzgerald continued to develop the script with Davis making extensive revisions that greatly improved it. Minsky was about to bring the play to Lynn Meadows at the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]]. Fitzgerald suggested that she would bring the play to her as she was better acquainted with her where it was produced to great acclaim. Minsky and Berman met with other producers and put together a package for Broadway. At that point, Davis and Fitzgerald dropped Minsky and Berman, and had the play produced on [[Broadway theatre|Broadway]]. The Broadway playbill for ''Mass Appeal'' notes that the play was produced by arrangement with Minsky and Berman. The play originally was produced by the [[Manhattan Theatre Club]]. Directed by Geraldine Fitzgerald and starring [[Milo O'Shea]] as Tim Farley and [[Eric Roberts]] as Mark Dolson, it opened at the [[Off-Broadway]] Stage 73 on April 22, 1980 and ran for 104 performances. Fitzgerald won the [[Outer Critics Circle Award]] for Outstanding New Director. The Broadway production, again directed by Fitzgerald and starring O'Shea as Tim Farley but with [[Michael O'Keefe]] as Mark Dolson, opened at the [[Booth Theatre]] on November 12, 1981 after 16 previews. It closed on May 16, 1982 after 212 performances. The play premiered in the [[United Kingdom]] at the [[Lyric Hammersmith]] in [[London]] in 1982 with [[Gordon Jackson (actor)|Gordon Jackson]] as Father Farley and [[Rupert Everett]] as Mark Dolson. It received its first British revival at the [[Finborough Theatre]] in London in 2006 with [[Kevin Colson]] and Brendan Patricks. In 1982 the play was performed at Sydney's Seymour Centre theatre, and starred real-life father and son actors Michael and Christopher Pate. Actor/Director Will Stutts toured the United States as Farley in the mid 1980s. ==Awards and nominations== *[[Tony Award for Best Performance by a Leading Actor in a Play]] (Milo O'Shea, nominee) *[[Tony Award for Best Direction of a Play]] (Geraldine Fitzergald, nominee) *[[Theatre World Award]] (Michael O'Keefe, '''winner''') *[[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding New Play]] (nominee) *[[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Actor in a Play]] (O'Shea, nominee) *[[Drama Desk Award for Outstanding Director of a Play]] (Fitzgerald, nominee) Michael and Christopher Pate, toured Australia. Returning to the Sydney Opera House. ==Film adaptation== Davis adapted his play for a [[Mass Appeal (film)|1984 feature film]] starring [[Jack Lemmon]] as Tim Farley and [[Željko Ivanek]] as Mark Dolson. ==External links== *{{iobdb show|Mass Appeal}} *{{IBDB show|id=5940|title=Mass Appeal}} [[Category:1980 plays]] [[Category:American plays]] [[Category:Off-Broadway plays]] [[Category:Broadway plays]] [[Category:Catholic Church in fiction]] [[Category:American plays adapted into films]] [[Category:Two-handers]]

revision.comment: /* Prevalence in popular music (mid 1980s to late 2000s) */
revision.text:
[[Image:Syllabic and melismatic.png|thumb|400px|Syllabic and melismatic text setting: "[[Christ the Lord Is Risen Today|Jesus Christ is Ris'n Today]]" (''Methodist Hymn Book'', 1933, No. 204).<ref>Shepherd, John (2003). ''Continuum Encyclopedia of Popular Music of the World: Performance and Production'', p. 565. {{ISBN|9780826463227}}.</ref> {{audio|Syllabic and melismatic.mid|Play}}]]
'''Melisma''' ([[Greek Language|Greek]]: {{wiktell|μέλισμα}}, ''melisma'', song, air, melody; from {{wiktell|μέλος}}, ''melos'', song, melody, plural: ''melismata'') is the singing of a single [[syllable]] of [[lyrics|text]] while moving between several different [[Musical note|note]]s in succession. Music sung in this style is referred to as ''melismatic'', as opposed to ''syllabic'', in which each syllable of text is matched to a single note.
==History==
===General=== Music of ancient cultures used melismatic techniques to induce a hypnotic [[trance]] in the listener,{{citation needed|date=October 2014}} useful for early mystical initiation rites (such as [[Eleusinian Mysteries]]{{citation needed|date=December 2012}}) and religious worship. This quality is still found in [[Arabic music]] where the scale consists of "[[quarter tone]]s". [[Orthodox Christian]] chanting also bears a slight resemblance to this. Middle Eastern melismatic music was developed further in the Torah [[Cantillation|chanting]], as well as by the [[Masoretes]] in the seventh or eighth centuries. It then appeared in some genres of [[Gregorian chant]], where it was used in certain sections of the [[Mass (music)|Mass]], with the earliest written appearance around AD 900. The [[gradual]] and the [[alleluia]], in particular, were characteristically melismatic, for example, while the [[Tract (liturgy)|tract]] is not, and repetitive melodic patterns were deliberately avoided in the style. The [[Byzantine Rite]] also used melismatic elements in its music, which developed roughly concurrently with the Gregorian chant.
In Western music, the term "melisma" most commonly refers to [[Gregorian chant]] (the first definition of melisma by the Merriam-Webster Online Dictionary'<ref>[http://www.m-w.com/cgi-bin/dictionary?book=Dictionary&va=melismatic Melismatic – Definition and More from the Free Merriam-Webster Dictionary<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> is "a group of notes or tones sung on one syllable in [[plainsong]]"). However, the term melisma may be used to describe music of any genre, including [[baroque]] singing and later [[gospel music|gospel]]. Within Jewish liturgical tradition, melisma is still commonly used in the chanting of [[Torah]], readings from the [[Nevi'im|Prophets]], and in the body of a service. For an examination of the evolution of this tradition, see [[Abraham Zevi Idelsohn|Idelsohn]].
Today, melisma is commonly used in [[Middle Eastern music|Middle Eastern]], [[African music|African]], [[Music of Southeastern Europe|Balkan]], and [[African American Music|African American]] music, [[Fado]] (Portuguese), [[Flamenco]] (Spanish), and various [[Asian music|Asian]] folk and popular musical genres. Melisma is also commonly featured in Western [[popular music]]. Early in their careers, [[Ray Charles]], [[Aretha Franklin]], and [[Stevie Wonder]] used it sparingly.<ref name=NYT_2013.12.24/> Melisma is used by countless pop artists such as [[Michael Jackson]], although this form usually involves improvising melismata (and melismatic [[vocalise]]) over a simpler melody. During the fadeout of the Beatles' 1966 track "[[I Want to Tell You]]", bassist [[Paul McCartney]] can be heard singing a high-pitched melisma in the style of classical Indian music.
===Prevalence in popular music (mid 1980s to late 2000s)===
The use of melisma is a common feature of artists such as [[Deniece Williams]], [[Stevie Wonder]], [[Luther Vandross]], [[Whitney Houston]], [[Mariah Carey]], [[Beyoncé]], [[Christina Aguilera]], among others.<ref name="bbc">{{cite web| last=Everitt | first=Lauren |title= Whitney Houston and the art of melisma | date= | url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/magazine-17039208 | work=BBC News | accessdate=2014-07-06}}</ref><ref name="whoanelly">[http://www.allmusic.com/album/whoa-nelly%21-mw0000103677 "Whoa, Nelly!" review by Stephen Thomas Erlewine]</ref> The use of melismatic vocals in pop music slowly grew in the 1980s. [[Deniece Williams]] topped the Billboard Hot 100 chart in May 1984, with [[Let's Hear It for the Boy]] with her melismatic vocals. Although other artists used melisma before, Houston, her rendition of [[Dolly Parton]]'s love song "[[I Will Always Love You]]" pushed the technique into the mainstream in the '90s.<ref name="bbc"/> The trend in [[Contemporary R&B|R&B]] singers is considered to have been popularized by Mariah Carey's song "[[Vision of Love]]", which was released and topped the charts at number one in 1990, and went on to be certified gold.<ref name=TheVillageVoice-Feb2003>{{Cite news | last = | first = | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | title = "Vision of Love" sets off melisma trend | newspaper = [[The Village Voice]] | pages = | year = | date = February 4, 2003 | url = | postscript = <!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}} }}</ref><ref name=TheNewYorker-Apr2006>{{cite web| last = Frere-Jones | first = Sasha | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = On Top: Mariah Carey's record-breaking career | work = [[The New Yorker]] | publisher = [[CondéNet]] | date = April 3, 2006 | url = http://www.newyorker.com/critics/music/?060403crmu_music | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-08-30 }}</ref><ref name=RollingStone-Nov2008>{{cite web | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = The 100 Greatest Singers of All Time : Rolling Stone | work = [[Rolling Stone]] | publisher = | date = November 12, 2008 | url = https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-singers-of-all-time-19691231/mariah-carey-19691231 | format = | doi = | accessdate = 2008-11-22 }}</ref>
===Recent backlash (late 2000s – early 2010s)===
As late as 2007, melismatic singers such as [[Leona Lewis]] were still scoring big hits, but around 2008–2009, this trend reverted to how it was prior to Carey and Houston's success – singers with less showy styles such as [[Kesha]] and [[Cheryl Cole]] began to outsell new releases by Carey and Christina Aguilera, ending nearly two decades of the style's dominance of pop-music vocals.<ref name="NYT_2013.12.24">[https://www.nytimes.com/2010/12/26/arts/music/26browne.html Out With Mariah's Melisma, In With Kesha's Kick: Trilling Songbirds Clip Their Wings]. Browne, David, December 24, 2010. ''[[The New York Times]]''.</ref>
==Examples== The French carol tune "Gloria" arranged by [[Edward Shippen Barnes]] in 1937, to which the hymn "[[Angels We Have Heard on High]]" is usually sung, contains one of the most melismatic sequences in popular Christian hymn music, on the "o" of the word "Gloria", which is held through 16 different notes. "[[Ding Dong Merrily on High]]", arranged by [[George Ratcliffe Woodward]], contains an even longer melisma of 31 notes, also on the "o" of "Gloria".
[[George Frideric Handel]]'s ''[[Messiah (Handel)|Messiah]]'' contains numerous examples of melisma, as in the following excerpt from the chorus "For Unto Us a Child Is Born" ([[Messiah Part I#12|Part I, No. 12]]). The soprano and alto lines engage in a 57-note melisma on the word "born".
<!--this image displayed wider than 400px for clarity--> [[Image:Handel Messiah - For Unto Us a Child is Born excerpt.JPG|center|577px]] {{audio|Handel Messiah - For Unto Us a Child is Born excerpt.mid|Play}}
Melisma is also used, though rarely and briefly, in the music of [[Jethro Tull (band)|Jethro Tull]]: examples include the eponymous track of the album ''[[Songs From the Wood]]'' and the song "Skating Away (On the Thin Ice of the New Day)". One of the most striking instances in recent pop music occurs in [[Bruce Springsteen]]'s "[[The Ties That Bind (Bruce Springsteen song)|The Ties that Bind]]", in which the "I" in "bind" is iterated 13 times.
[[Wolfgang Amadeus Mozart]] also uses melisma in his ''[[Requiem (Mozart)|Requiem Mass in D minor]]'' ([[Köchel catalogue|K.]] 626) in the ''[[Kyrie]]'' [[Sequence (poetry)|sequence]], with the "e" in "eleison" being elaborately sung in various notes.
== See also == * [[Arabic maqam]]
==References== {{reflist|40em}}
== External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20021114225910/http://www.bartleby.com/61/69/M0206900.html American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language entry on "melisma"] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20030503171228/http://www.music.vt.edu/musicdictionary/textm/Melisma.html Virginia Tech Multimedia Music Dictionary entry on melisma]
[[Category:Singing techniques]] [[Category:Musical terminology]]

page.title: Miscegenation: The Theory of the Blending of the Races, Applied to the American White Man and Negro

revision.text:
{{italictitle}} '''''Miscegenation: The Theory of the Blending of the Races, Applied to the American White Man and Negro''''' is a December 1863 [[hoax]] [[pamphlet]] created by ''[[New York World]]'' staff as part of an anti-Lincoln [[Copperhead (politics)|Copperhead]] campaign leading up to the [[United States presidential election, 1864|1864 presidential election]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kaplan|first=Sidney|date=1949|title=The Miscegenation Issue in the Election of 1864|journal=The Journal of Negro History|volume=34|issue=3|pages=274–343|doi=10.2307/2715904|jstor=2715904}}</ref> The 72-page piece coined the term ''[[miscegenation]]'' (from the Latin ''miscere'' "to mix" + ''genus'' "kind") and was put together by ''World'' managing editor [[David Goodman Croly]] and reporter George Wakeman.<ref>{{Cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=NDzSypIhISUC&pg=PA318|title=Reelecting Lincoln: The Battle For The 1864 Presidency|last=Waugh|first=John|date=2009-04-30|publisher=Da Capo Press, Incorporated|isbn=9780786747115|language=en}}</ref>
The work purports to be a sincere advocacy of the virtues of racial mixing, but it is a [[literary forgery]] intended to argue against racial equality, and to blame the Lincoln administration for allegedly supporting this goal. The authors unsuccessfully attempted to trick Lincoln into endorsing the work. The ''World'' also featured a hoax about a "Miscegenation Ball" with interracial dancing alleged to have been held at a Republican function in New York City during the campaign.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.thedailybeast.com/articles/2013/05/02/how-a-racist-newspaper-defeated-lincoln-in-new-york-in-the-1864-election|title=How a Racist Newspaper Defeated Lincoln in New York in the 1864 Election|last=Holzer|first=Harold|date=2013-05-02|work=The Daily Beast|access-date=2018-09-15|language=en}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.loc.gov/resource/lprbscsm.scsm1371/ Library of Congress scan] *[http://hoaxes.org/archive/permalink/the_miscegenation_hoax The Miscegenation Hoax] at the [[Museum of Hoaxes]]
[[Category:1863 books]] [[Category:19th-century hoaxes]] [[Category:Literary forgeries]] [[Category:Multiracial affairs in the United States]] [[Category:New York World]] [[Category:Racial hoaxes]] [[Category:Pamphlets]] [[Category:Political forgery]] [[Category:Racism in the United States]] [[Category:United States presidential election, 1864]] [[Category:Conspiracy theories involving race and ethnicity]]

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2012}} {{Infobox company | name = National Film Registry | logo = File:National Film Registry logo vector.svg | logo_caption = Logo for the National Film Registry. | type = Film preservation | industry = [[Archive|Archiving]] | fate = | predecessor = | successor = | founded = {{Start date and age|1988}}
[[United States]] | founder = | defunct = | hq_location_city = | hq_location_country = | area_served = | key_people = | products = | owner = | num_employees = | num_employees_year = | parent = [[Library of Congress]] | website = {{URL|loc.gov/programs/national-film-preservation-board/film-registry}} }} The '''National Film Registry''' ('''NFR''') is the United States [[National Film Preservation Board]]'s (NFPB) selection of [[film]]s deserving of [[preservation (library and archival science)|preservation]]. The NFPB, established by the [[National Film Preservation Act]] of 1988, was reauthorized by [[Act of Congress|acts of Congress]] in 1992, 1996, 2005, and again in October 2008.{{cite news|title=Reagan Signs Law on Film|work=The New York Times|date=September 28, 1988|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1988/09/28/movies/reagan-signs-law-on-film.html?sec=&spon=|accessdate=July 22, 2009}}{{cite web|title=Legislative Authorization |publisher=[[National Film Preservation Board]] |url=https://www.loc.gov/film/filmabou.html |accessdate=July 22, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080829144823/http://www.loc.gov/film/filmabou.html |archivedate=August 29, 2008 |df= }}{{cite web|title=Public Law 110–336—Oct. 2, 2008|publisher=[[United States Government Printing Office]]|url=http://www.gpo.gov/fdsys/pkg/PLAW-110publ336/pdf/PLAW-110publ336.pdf|format=PDF|accessdate=August 15, 2009}} The NFPB's mission, to which the NFR contributes, is to ensure the survival, conservation, and increased public availability of America's film heritage.{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/programs/national-film-preservation-board/about-this-program|title=About This Program - National Film Preservation Board|author=|date=|website=loc.gov}} The 1996 law also created the non-profit [[National Film Preservation Foundation]] which, although affiliated with the NFPB, raises money from the [[private sector]].{{cite news|last=Fox|first=Michael|title=Running Around San Francisco for an Education|work=[[SF Weekly]]|url=http://www.sfweekly.com/2003-05-28/film/running-around-san-francisco-for-an-education/|date=May 28, 2003|accessdate=July 30, 2009}} == Criteria == The NFPB adds to the NFR up to 25 "culturally, historically, or aesthetically significant films" each year, showcasing the range and diversity of [[Cinema of the United States|American film heritage]] to increase awareness for its preservation.{{cite news|title=National Film Registry Adds 25 Films|publisher=Millimeter|date=December 17, 2002|url=http://digitalcontentproducer.com/news/video_national_film_registry/|accessdate=February 19, 2009}} A film becomes eligible for inclusion ten years after its original release.{{cite news|last=Molotsky|first=Irvin|title=25 Films Chosen for the National Registry|work=The New York Times|date=September 20, 1989|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1989/09/20/movies/25-films-chosen-for-the-national-registry.html|accessdate=July 30, 2009}} For the first selection in 1989, the public nominated almost 1,000 films for consideration. Members of the NFPB then developed individual ballots of possible films for inclusion. The ballots were tabulated into a list of 25 films which was then modified by [[Librarian of Congress]] [[James H. Billington]] and his staff at the Library for the final selection.{{cite news|agency=[[United Press International]]|title=National treasures|work=Ellensburg Daily Record|date=October 16, 1989|url=https://news.google.com/newspapers?id=EjoQAAAAIBAJ&sjid=Wo8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=3379,5826077&dq|accessdate=August 4, 2009}} Since 1997, members of the public have been able to nominate up to 50 films a year for the NFPB and Librarian to consider.{{cite news|last=Keogh|first=Jim|title=Public gets ticket to put favorite flicks in registry|work=[[Telegram & Gazette]]|date=March 25, 1999|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=WO&p_theme=wo&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADFA285C0152F2&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|accessdate=August 4, 2009}} {{quote box|width=27.7em|bgcolor=#c6dbf7|quote="Taken together, the ... films in the National Film Registry represent a stunning range of American filmmaking—including Hollywood features, documentaries, avant-garde and amateur productions, films of regional interest, ethnic, animated, and short film subjects—all deserving recognition, preservation and access by future generations. As we begin this new millennium, the registry stands among the finest summations of American cinema's wondrous first century."|source=—Dr. [[James H. Billington]], [[Library of Congress#Librarians of Congress|Librarian of Congress]].}} The NFR includes films ranging from Hollywood classics to [[orphan film]]s. A film is not required to be [[Feature film|feature-length]], nor is it required to have been [[Movie theater|theatrically]] released in the traditional sense. In addition, television programs, commercials, and foreign films are not excluded from consideration, although American films are given preference. The Registry contains [[newsreel]]s, [[silent film]]s, student films, [[experimental film]]s, [[short film]]s, [[music video]]s, films out of [[copyright]] protection or in the public domain, [[Serial film|film serial]]s, [[home movies]], documentaries, animation and [[independent film]]s. As of the 2017 listing, there are 725 films in the Registry. Currently, the earliest listed film is ''[[Newark Athlete]]'' (1891), and the most recent is ''[[13 Lakes]]'' (2004). Counting the 11 multi-year serials in the NFR once each (as the NFR does) by year of completion, the year with the most films selected is 1939, with 19 films from that year chosen. The time between a film's debut and its selection varies greatly. The longest span is 121 years; ''Edison Kinetographic Record of a Sneeze'' was originally released in 1894 and selected in 2015. The shortest span is the minimum 10 years; this distinction is shared by ''[[Raging Bull]]'', ''[[Do the Right Thing]]'', ''[[Goodfellas]]'', ''[[Toy Story]]'', ''[[Fargo (film)|Fargo]]'' and ''[[13 Lakes]]''. ==Films== [[File:Fred Ott Sneeze L.gif|thumb|right|''[[Fred Ott's Sneeze]]'' is one of the earliest U.S. films. [[Thomas Edison]] made this 5-second film.]] [[File:DicksonFilm Still.png|thumb|right|alt=Black-and-white film screenshot of a man (at center) playing a violin while facing a large cone. An obscured man is seen behind the cone. Two men at the right are dancing with each other.|''[[The Dickson Experimental Sound Film]]'' is the first known film with live-recorded sound.{{cite news|last=Desowitz|first=Bill|title=Sound and Image Reunited 105 Years Later|work=Los Angeles Times|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/62165218.html?dids=62165218:62165218&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Oct+06%2C+2000&author=BILL+DESOWITZ&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Sound+and+Image+Reunited+105+Years+Later&pqatl=google|format=Fee required|date=October 6, 2000|accessdate=August 15, 2009}}]] [[File:The Kiss 1896 Film Strip.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Three black-and-white film strips showing a woman and man facing each other and then eventually kissing. Each film strip has about five visible frames.|The 47-second long ''[[The Kiss (1896 film)|The Kiss]]'' was one of the first films shown commercially to the public.{{cite news|last=Carr|first=Jay|title=Movies Begin: Exploring the Vitality of First Films|work=Boston Globe|url=http://nl.newsbank.com/nl-search/we/Archives?p_product=BG&p_theme=bg&p_action=search&p_maxdocs=200&p_topdoc=1&p_text_direct-0=0EADE19152227365&p_field_direct-0=document_id&p_perpage=10&p_sort=YMD_date:D&s_trackval=GooglePM|format=Fee required|date=November 30, 1995|accessdate=August 15, 2009}}]] [[File:Fitzsimmons Corbett 1897.jpg|thumb|right|''[[The Corbett-Fitzsimmons Fight]]'' was both the first feature-length picture (running at almost 100 minutes) as well as film's first bona-fide financial success (grossing between $100,000-$750,000), sparking the earliest large-scale discussion about the medium.]] [[File:Great train robbery still.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of a man facing the camera, while also pointing a revolver forward. He has a large mustache and is wearing a cowboy hat, a bandana around his neck, and a heavy jacket.|''[[The Great Train Robbery (1903 film)|The Great Train Robbery]]'' used a variety of editing techniques that were becoming popular at the time of its release.]] [[File:Gertie with cartoon McCay.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Animated black-and-white image of a large dinosaur atop a cliff, with a man in a suit standing in its mouth. Several boulders can be seen in the background.|Although not the first animated film, ''[[Gertie the Dinosaur]]'' became the first popular cartoon.{{cite news|last=Corliss|first=Richard|title=The Cartoon Character|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,988514,00.html?promoid=googlep|date=June 8, 1998|accessdate=August 15, 2009}}]] [[File:Birth-of-a-nation-klan-and-black-man.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of several men in white robes and hoods surrounding an African-American man (a white actor using "blackface"). The men's robe have crosses on them and in the background other men are on top of horses.|''[[The Birth of a Nation]]'' developed innovative camera techniques and special effects and became Hollywood's first successful feature film, being cited as the first "super-production".]] [[File:Intolerance-lillian gish.jpg|thumb|The influential ''[[Intolerance (film)|Intolerance]]'' was made by [[D. W. Griffith]] partly in response to controversy over the racism seen in ''The Birth of a Nation''.]] [[File:Still from Charles Chaplin - The_Kid - 1921 - Charles Chaplin Productions - EYE FOT2423.jpg|thumb|[[Charlie Chaplin]]'s 1921 film ''[[The Kid (1921 film)|The Kid]]'' not only became the first successful comedy feature film, but also demonstrated the compatibility between dramatic and comedic elements, cementing Chaplin's reputation.]] [[File:Robert Flaherty Nyla 1920.jpg|thumb|''[[Nanook of the North]]'' revolutionized the [[documentary film]] with its large scale production, though it continues to receive controversy for staging several of the events it depicts.]] [[File:Safetylast-1.jpg|thumb|The iconic scene featuring [[Harold Lloyd]] hanging from the clock in ''[[Safety Last!]]'' has been referenced by numerous media, with a number of films including similar events in their plots.]] [[File:ChaneyPhantomoftheOpera.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A man wearing extensive makeup is looking to his left. The makeup gives a skull-like appearance and he is wearing a robe with his arms crossed in front of him.|''[[The Phantom of the Opera (1925 film)|The Phantom of the Opera]]'' featured extensive makeup for its main character.{{cite news|last=Sullivan|first=James|title=The Old 'Phantom' Rises From the Dead – In Living Color – With a New Score|work=San Francisco Chronicle|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/c/a/2005/04/21/DDGQBC89M817.DTL&type=movies|date=April 21, 2005|accessdate=August 15, 2009}}]] [[File:Al Jolson Jazz Singer.JPG|right|thumb|[[Al Jolson]] in ''[[The Jazz Singer]]'', the first feature film to include scenes of fully synchronized sound.]] [[File:Bela Lugosi as Dracula.jpg|thumb|The 1931 film ''[[Dracula (1931 English-language film)|Dracula]]'' became highly influential over future depictions of the title character. Its simultaneously-filmed [[Drácula (1931 Spanish-language film)|Spanish-language version]] is unique among [[Multiple-language version|foreign-language versions]] for being preserved by the NFR as well.]] [[File:Little Caesar.JPG|thumb|''[[Little Caesar (film)|Little Caesar]]'' sparked a vogue for [[gangster film]]s during the early 1930s and established [[Edward G. Robinson]] as the quintessential "movie mobster".]] [[File:PopeyeMeetsSindbad.png|thumb|Lasting 16 minutes, ''[[Popeye the Sailor Meets Sindbad the Sailor]]'' was the first U.S.-produced animated film with a running time over the standard 7-8 minutes, predating Disney's ''Snow White'' by a year.]] [[File:Snow white 1937 trailer screenshot (2).jpg|thumb|right|The famous "[[Heigh-Ho]]" sequence from ''[[Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs (1937 film)|Snow White and the Seven Dwarfs]]'', the first American animated feature film, created by [[Walt Disney]], and showing the [[Seven Dwarfs|seven dwarfs]] ([[Seven Dwarfs#Disney Dwarfs|Doc, Happy, Grumpy, Bashful, Sneezy, Dopey, Sleepy]]).]] [[File:Judy Garland in The Wizard of Oz trailer 2.jpg|thumb|right|Despite not being the first film in color, ''[[The Wizard of Oz (1939 film)|The Wizard of Oz]]'' startled audiences when [[Judy Garland]] seamlessly transitioned from black-and-white to color.]] [[File:Gable-Leigh GWTW-b.jpg|thumb|Adjusted for inflation, ''[[Gone with the Wind (film)|Gone with the Wind]]'' is the highest-grossing film in box-office history.]] [[File:Pinochio2 1940.jpg|thumb|right|Despite initial box-office struggles, ''[[Pinocchio (1940 film)|Pinocchio]]'' has long been acclaimed for its technical merits.]] [[File:Dictator charlie5.jpg|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of a man sitting upon a table, holding a globe.|thumb|''[[The Great Dictator]]'' (1940) was [[Charlie Chaplin]]'s first [[sound film]] after his era of [[silent film]]s.]] [[File:Orson Welles-Citizen Kane1.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white image of a man wearing a suit standing at a podium. His right arm is resting on the podium and is left is pointing up to his left. A large headshot of the same man is visible in the background.|''[[Citizen Kane]]'' is considered by many critics and scholars (including the [[American Film Institute]]) to be the greatest film ever made.[http://www.afi.com/100years/ 100 years], AFI website]] [[File:Casablanca, Trailer Screenshot.JPG|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of a man and woman close together appearing ready to kiss.|''[[Casablanca (film)|Casablanca]]'' has six lines of dialogue on [[AFI's 100 Years... 100 Movie Quotes]], more than any other film.]] [[File:Whywefight30vs200.png|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of an image of a world map. Above the United States is a figure of a white soldier, and above Asia is a larger black soldier. Text at the bottom-left of the image states "30 Millions vs. 200 Millions".|''[[Why We Fight]]'' was a series of propaganda films directed by [[Frank Capra]] explaining to soldiers why the United States was involved in World War II.]] [[File:It's A Wonderful Life.jpg|thumb|''[[It's a Wonderful Life]]'' disappointed both critics and audiences while in theaters, but frequent television showings have transformed it into one of the most beloved and widely referenced films of all time.]] [[File:Lettherebehuston.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot of a soldier.|''[[Let There Be Light (1946 film)|Let There Be Light]]'' was a controversial documentary blocked from public distribution for 35 years.]] [[File:KlaatuandGortdepart.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A black-and-white screenshot with a robot at the left near the background and a man at the right standing in the foreground. Four bright lights can be seen in the background.|''[[The Day the Earth Stood Still]]'' is a 1950s [[science fiction film]].]] [[File:Gary Cooper in High Noon 1952.JPG|thumb|right|[[Gary Cooper]] in the controversial ''[[High Noon]]'', which was said to be an allegory on [[McCarthyism]].]] [[File:Ann Doran, James Dean and Jim Backus in Rebel Without a Cause trailer.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A color screenshot of a woman on the middle of a staircase, a teenager at the bottom, and a man in the front of the staircase. The teenager is wearing a red jacket and has his arms outstretched at his side.|''[[Rebel Without a Cause]]'' was released in theaters less than one month after the main actor, [[James Dean]], died in a car accident.{{cite news|title='Cause' for Celebration: 'Rebel' is 40|work=[[Daily News (New York)|Daily News]]|date=April 28, 1995|url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/entertainment/1995/04/28/1995-04-28__ca use__for_celebration___re.html|accessdate=August 15, 2009}}{{dead link|date=September 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}]] [[File:The searchers Ford Trailer screenshot (crop).jpg|thumb|right|Often cited as one of the greatest westerns of all time, ''[[The Searchers]]'' was an influence on directors including [[Martin Scorsese]], [[Steven Spielberg]], and [[David Lean]].]] [[File:Charlton Heston in The Ten Commandments film trailer.jpg|thumb|right|alt=A color screenshot of a man with a beard wearing a robe. He has his hands raised at his side, and his right hand is holding a staff. Dark clouds can be seen in the background.|For ''[[The Ten Commandments (1956 film)|The Ten Commandments]]'', various visual effects were used to create the illusion of [[Moses]] ([[Charlton Heston]]) parting the [[Red Sea]].]] [[File:Elvis Presley and Judy Tyler in Jailhouse Rock trailer.jpg|thumb|right|alt=Black-and-white screenshot of a man and woman standing next to each other. The man has his arm around the woman's shoulders as she smiles.|[[Elvis Presley]] refused to watch the completed ''[[Jailhouse Rock (film)|Jailhouse Rock]]'' after [[Judy Tyler]] was killed in a car accident a few weeks before the film's release.Victor, Adam, ''The Elvis Encyclopaedia'', p.269]] [[File:Mary Poppins3.jpg|thumb|In ''[[Mary Poppins (film)|Mary Poppins]]'', [[Dick van Dyke]] plays Bert, the chimney sweeper.]] [[File:Zombies NightoftheLivingDead.jpg|thumb|''[[Night of the Living Dead]]'' was the first film to feature the modern interpretation of [[zombie|zombies]].]] {|class="wikitable sortable" ! revision.comment: /* Locations */ It always performs at the Gran Teatro Nacional, I have been there two times this year ... and once elsewhere ...
revision.text:
{{Infobox orchestra | name = National Symphony Orchestra (OSN) | image = | caption = | founded = 1938 | location = [[Lima]], [[Peru]] | website = {{URL|inc.perucultural.org.pe/el.shtml}} | principal_conductor = Fernando Valcárcel }} The '''National Symphony Orchestra''' (Orquesta Sinfónica Nacional, abbreviated OSN) is the state symphony orchestra of [[Peru]]; it is located in [[Lima]]. It is one of the components of the Peruvian [[Instituto Nacional de Cultura]]. As of 2007, the orchestra had ninety members. Besides the traditional classical repertory, the orchestra also performs Latin American and Peruvian works, including numerous world premieres.
==History== Before the formation of the National Symphony Orchestra, there was an amateur symphony orchestra, founded in 1907 under the auspices of the [[Lima Philharmonic Society]] (Sociedad Filarmónica de Lima). The National Symphony Orchestra was founded during the administration of [[Óscar R. Benavides]] by law of 11 August 1938. It initially consisted of sixty-four musicians, half of them native Peruvians, the other half foreigners then living in Peru or hired by contract from abroad. The orchestra gave its first concert on 11 December 1938 at the [[Teatro Municipal de Lima]], under the baton of [[Theo Buchwald]], as part of the eighth [[International Conference of American States]]. The program featured the [[National Anthem of Peru]], plus works by [[Beethoven]], [[Debussy]], [[Manuel de Falla]], [[Ravel]], and [[Wagner]].
The first director of the orchestra was the viennese conductor Theo Buchwald, who remained in that position until his death in 1960. This epoch of the orchestra's existence is considered its most brilliant period, since the orchestra had among her members many talented musicians who had come from Europe to Peru when fleeing the [[Second World War]], among them many [[Jews]] [http://www.lp.edu.pe/l_trahtemberg/otros/judio251102.htm]. Visiting conductors who led the orchestra included [[Fritz Busch]], [[Carlos Chávez]], [[Aaron Copland]], [[Antal Doráti]], [[Erich Kleiber]], [[Igor Markevitch]], [[Malcolm Sargent]], [[Hermann Scherchen]], and [[Igor Stravinsky]]. Visiting soloists who performed with the orchestra included [[Claudio Arrau]], [[Yehudi Menuhin]], [[Artur Rubinstein]], [[Andrés Segovia]] and [[Nicanor Zabaleta]]. A period of decline began in the 1960s, due in part to the socio-economic problems of Peru and to government cultural policies. The orchestra is now passing through a period of financial crisis and managerial reorganization that has engendered much controversy, partly over the transfer of the management of the orchestra to the [[National Association of Musical Performing Arts Organizations]] (Asociación Nacional de Elencos Musicales).[http://www.elcomercioperu.com.pe/edicionimpresa/html/2006%2D05%2D02/impopinion0498700.html] [http://www.elcomercioperu.com.pe/edicionimpresa/html/2006%2D05%2D05/impdominical0500828.html] In August 2006, angered that they would not be paid for a performance of [[Mozart's Requiem]] with the [[National Chorus (Peru)]] (Coro Nacional), the union of musicians of the orchestra refused to play, and a substitute orchestra was hurriedly assembled instead.[http://www.elcomercioperu.com.pe/edicionimpresa/html/2006%2D08%2D22/imecluces0563351.html]
The orchestra has long promoted the work of Peruvian composers, and it has performed works by [[Daniel Alomía Robles]], [[Celso Garrido-Lecca]], Roberto Carpio, Enrique Iturriaga, [[Armando Guevara Ochoa]], [[Ernesto López Mindreau]], [[Enrique Pinilla]], [[Francisco Pulgar Vidal]], [[Alfonso de Silva]], [[Teodoro Valcárcel]] and Edgar Valcárcel, among others.
==Locations== The orchestra's home for many years was the Teatro Municipal de Lima. The orchestra currently performs at the [[Gran Teatro Nacional]], but it also gives educational concerts elsewhere in Lima and throughout Peru.
==Music Directors== *[[Theo Buchwald]] (1938–1960) *[[Carmen Moral]] (on two separate occasions; the first woman to be a music director of an orchestra in Latin America; she has been named "Conductor Emeritus" of the orchestra) *[[Leopoldo La Rosa]] *[[Luis Herrera de la Fuente]] *[[José Malsio]] *[[José Santos]] *[[Armando Sánchez]] *[[Guillermina Maggiolo]] (September 2006-July 2009) *[http://www.matteopagliari.com Matteo Pagliari] (since July 2009; incumbent)
==Bibliography== *[[Luis Antonio Meza Casas]], "Música Académica", ''Enciclopedia Temática del Perú,'' vol. 16 (Lima: El Comercio S.A.) {{ISBN|978-9972-752-16-2}}
==External links== * {{es icon}} [http://cultura.gob.pe/industriasculturalesartes/elencos/osn Official page] * {{es icon}} [http://www.oei.es/cultura2/peru/08c.htm Summary of the cultural institutions of Peru]
{{DEFAULTSORT:National Symphony Orchestra}} [[Category:South American orchestras|Orquesta Sinfonica Nacional (Peru)]] [[Category:Musical groups established in 1938]] [[Category:Peruvian music]]

revision.text:
{{Orphan|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox musical artist <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Musicians --> |name = Orchestra Invisibile |origin = Italy |genre = [[Jazz]] |background = group_or_band |years_active = {{start date|2005}}-present |label = [[Etichette Invisibili]] |image = OI Live in Tortona.jpg |caption = Orchestra Invisibile live in [[Tortona]] |website = [http://www.cascinarossago.net/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=52%3Amusica&catid=41%3Amusica&Itemid=80&lang=it/ Orchestra Invisibile] }}
The '''Orchestra Invisibile''' (Invisible Orchestra) is an [[Italy|Italian]] [[band (music)|band]] formed in 2005 in [http://www.cascinarossago.net/ Cascina Rossago] (PV, Italy), the first Italian farm community designed to meet the needs and unfold possibilities of young adults with [[autism]].<ref>{{vcite journal | author = Politi P, Emanuele E, Grassi M, Invisible Orchestra Project. | year = 2011| title = Development of the "Playing-in-Touch"(PiT) questionnaire: a measure of musical intouchness in people with low-functioning autism.| journal =Neuro Endocrinology Letters | volume =33 |pp=552-558 | pmid=23090275}}</ref>
==History== The original group, formed by the first guests of Cascina Rossago and some students, trainee psychiatrists and professors of the [[University of Pavia]], has grown to the actual number of 25 components, 12 of them affected by [[autism]]. The band counts 14 percussionists, 5 saxophonist, 3 trumpeters, 3 trombonists, one tuba player and a double-bass player, with several pianists. The term ''invisibile'' (invisible) refers to a feature of the group: the need to restrain the ''visibility'' of the musicians, to minimize distress for the more sensitive components, which could find the presence of an audience difficult to tolerate. Nevertheless, the ''Orchestra Invisibile'' appeared in public and performed live in theatres ([[Torino]], [http://www.comune.pv.it/site/home/archivio-news/articolo17044.html/ Pavia]{{dead link|date=March 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, [http://www.associazionepaoloperduca.it/2012/03/22-aprile-orchestra-invisibile/ and Tortona],<ref>{{cite news|title=Concerto dell’Orchestra Invisibile|magazine=La Provincia Pavese|date=10 May 2013}}</ref> and [https://web.archive.org/web/20160701211610/http://caffeinacultura.eu/event/sunday-meet-up-2/ Viterbo]. Yet, the communicative exchanges within the band are mainly non-verbal. The majority of the ''Orchestra Invisibile'''s repertoire is jazz [[mainstream]]. The experience has shown how this musical genre could be a good compromise between the consistency of the harmonic structures and the changes deriving from the improvisation and the spirit of freedom, characteristic features of [[jazz]]. This can be heard in their first album Orchestra Invisibile, live 2012, published by the independent label [[Etichette Invisibili]]. This would sound like an off-key and uncoordinated group in the beginning that gradually harmonizes and synchronizes reaching a pleasant ensemble towards the end. The only way to assist the rehearsals is to actively participate by playing. This aspect has promoted the collaboration with famous musicians as [[Ellade Bandini]]<ref>{{cite news|title=Ellade Bandini e l’Orchestra Invisibile – Face To Face|url=http://www.drumsetmag.com/ellade-bandini-e-lorchestra-invisibile/|magazine=Drumset Mag. N°22|date=22 March 2014}}</ref> (drummers for [[Paolo Conte]], [[Fabrizio De André]], [[Francesco Guccini]], [[Mina (singer)|Mina]] and many more), Jorge Alberto Guerrero and [http://www.claudioperelli.com/ Claudio Perelli]. Another critical feature of the band is the circular setting, both during rehearsals and live concerts, alternating melodic and rhythmic instruments, consistently with the [[sameness]] during the weekly rehearsals and the performance on stage. This disposition aims at improving the communication within the band, facilitating the visual contact. From the talent of Simona Concaro, and thanks to the contribution of the international musician [http://www.hannashybayeva.com/ Hanna Shybayeva], the album Playing with Autism 1.0 ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1301) and the book Playing with Autism 1.1 - Encountering Simona Concaro by Her Music (PUP 2014) have recently been published. Simona Concaro's executions have further been recorded in Playing with Autism 2.0 ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1401). In 2015 it was published the photographic book Orchestra Invisibile (Jaca Book 2015). Celebrating the ten years of activity, the Orchestra Invisibile performed two live concerts at the [http://www.comune.casale-monferrato.al.it/flex/cm/pages/ServeAttachment.php/L/IT/D/0%252F3%252F1%252FD.24302fdf068554f7f9ae/P/BLOB%3AID%3D5664/E/pdf Teatro Municipale] of Casale Monferrato (AL, Italy) and at the Auditorium of the [https://web.archive.org/web/20151212233405/http://www.paviabarocca.it/concerti/concerto123/ Istituto Vittadini] of Pavia (Italy). Furthermore, Edizioni Cardano of Pavia published the book Ritratti Invisibili as a gift for the percussionists of the band. In 2016 the Orchestra Invisibile took part at the Caffeina Festival in Viterbo, gaining the favour of both audience and critics.<ref>{{cite news|title=Orchestra Invisibile, quando la musica cura l'anima|url=http://www.tusciatimes.eu/orchestra-invisibile-quando-la-musica-cura-lanima/}}</ref> In 2017, in the context of the [[World Autism Awareness Day]], the Orchestra played at the auditorium Tiziano Zalli of the Banca Popolare di [[Lodi, Lombardy|Lodi]],<ref>{{cite news|author= Gaia Curci|title=A Lodi suona l’Orchestra invisibile, la musica aiuta gli autistici a integrarsi | url=http://laprovinciapavese.gelocal.it/tempo-libero/2017/04/01/news/a-lodi-suona-l-orchestra-invisibile-la-musica-aiuta-gli-autistici-a-integrarsi-1.15125530/}}</ref> designed by [[Renzo Piano]]. The performance has been recorded and published in Orchestra Invisibile Live 2017 ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1701) along with a videoclip about the Orchestra Invisibile directed by [https://www.soygiorgiasoi.com/ Giorgia Soi] with the contribution of [http://www.daviddidonatello.it/concorso/schedaunicalungo.php?idfilm=9230 Rossana De Michele].
== Active components == * Gianfranco Ciavarella, Stefano Damiani, Mariacristina Migliardi, [http://www.claudioperelli.com/ Claudio Perelli]: [[Saxophone|sax]] * Enrico Pozzato, Umberto Provenzani, Walter Vitullo: [[trumpet]] * Laura Fusar-Poli, Pierluigi Politi, Matteo Rocchetti: [[trombone]] * Alice Mandrini: [[guitar]] * Simona Concaro, Pierluigi Politi: [[piano]] * Marco Vercesi: [[Bass (guitar)|bass]] * Salvatore Alberghina, Annalisa Aquilano, [http://www.elladebandini.com/ Ellade Bandini]{{Dead link|date=November 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Giovanni Barale, Marcos Beretta, Federico Campi, Dario Caporaso, Federico Carini, Erminia Casciaro, Claudia Castiglioni, Simona Concaro, Elena Croci, Elisa Guarrera, Alice Mandrini, Andrea Randon, Cristiano Ravasini, Francesca Spagnuolo, Paolo Rovelli, Andrea Tomaselli, Tiziano Vaghi: [[percussions]]
== Have played with the ‘’Orchestra Invisibile’’ == * Roberto Aglieri * Alessio Alogna * Noemi Ancona * [http://www.bernardoaroztegui.com/ Bernardo Aroztegui] * Giuliana Bagnasco * David Ruben Barbaglia * Andrea Bassi * Maria Besozzi * Giulia Bianchi * Ilaria Bonoldi * Anna Maria Bordin * Marianna Boso * Davide Broglia * Marcella Cambianica * Antonella Caputo * Vincenzo Caracciolo * Walter Casali * Alessandra Comai * Massimiliano Confalonieri * Marta Crippa * Silvia Cucchi * Mariarosa D'Amico * Davide Donatellis * [http://www.elodiefavre.com/ Elodie Favre] * Andrea Ferrario * Fulvio Ferraris * Manuela Filippa * Corrado Garbazza * Lorenzo Giapparize * Leonardo Graffeo * [https://web.archive.org/web/20160502054851/http://www.paolaerdas.it/musicisti_guerrero.html Jorge Alberto Guerrero] * Ike Hasbani * Amy Loan * Lara Mancini * Giovanni Marchese * Mara Marini * Alessandro Minutillo * Alessia Mori * Elisabetta Napoli * Gabriele Naretto * Elena Nobile * Lucrezia Oliver * Filippo Perelli * Marianna Pinto * Francesca Podavini * Viviana Ponta * Enrico Pozzo * Adriano Primadei * Alessandra Ramati * Livio Ravetta * Elena Rho * Veronica Riva * Cristian Rossotti * Chiara Salvottini * Marco Sannella * Simona Schiatti * [http://www.hannashybayeva.com/ Hanna Shybayeva] * Cecilia Spallarossa * Sara Targa * Luigi Tomaselli * Tobia Veglia * [http://www.istitutodipsicomotricita.com/index.php/ Anne-Marie Wille]
== Discography ==
===Albums=== * 2012 - “Orchestra Invisibile live 2012” ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1201) * 2013 - "Playing with Autism 1.0" ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1301) * 2014 - "Playing with Autism 2.0" ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1401) * 2017 - "Orchestra Invisibile live 2017" ([[Etichette Invisibili]], INVI1701)
<gallery mode="nolines"> File:OI Live 2012.jpg|Orchestra Invisibile live 2012 File:PwA 1 0 2013.jpg|Playing with Autism 1.0 File:PwA 2 0 2014.jpg|Playing with Autism 2.0 |Orchestra Invisibile live 2017 </gallery>

(2009). [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1111/j.1601-5215.2008.00336.x/pdf A piano composer with low-functioning severe autism.] Acta Neuropsychiatrica, 21(1), 2-3.

{{Refimprove|date=July 2017}} {{Infobox concert | | concert_name = Party at the Palace | image = Party at the Palace.jpg | image_caption = Logo | artist = [[#Performers|various artists]] | type = concert and commemoration | date = {{Start date|2002|06|03|df=y}} | venue = [[Buckingham Palace Garden]], [[London]], [[England]] }}
The '''Party at the Palace''', was a British music concert and celebration held in [[London]] in 2002. The event was in commemoration of the [[Golden Jubilee of Elizabeth II|Golden Jubilee of Queen Elizabeth II]] held over the [[Golden Jubilee Weekend]] 1–4 June 2002. The event itself was hosted at [[Buckingham Palace Garden]] on 3 June 2002. It was the pop/rock equivalent of the [[Prom at the Palace]], that showcased [[classical music]].
==Event and venue== The concert was held at the gardens of Buckingham Palace Garden as part of the Golden Jubilee. The event was touted as the greatest concert in Britain since [[Live Aid]] or possibly ever. Tickets to the event were determined by a lottery. 12,000 people attended the concert.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/in_depth/entertainment/2002/jubilee/concert/7.stm |title=Picture Gallery |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> An estimated 1 million people watched outside the Palace in [[The Mall (London)|The Mall]] and around the [[Victoria Memorial (London)|Queen Victoria Memorial]],<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Factfiles/TheQueensGoldenJubilee.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-06-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150626114539/http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Factfiles/TheQueensGoldenJubilee.aspx |archivedate=2015-06-26 |df= }} </ref> and 200 million on television.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2002/50factsonTheQueensGoldenJubileeyear-2002.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-11-28 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090216150003/http://www.royal.gov.uk/LatestNewsandDiary/Pressreleases/2002/50factsonTheQueensGoldenJubileeyear-2002.aspx |archivedate=2009-02-16 |df= }} </ref> The concert included performances of many hit songs from the reign of [[Elizabeth II of the United Kingdom|Queen Elizabeth II]]. The event was the culmination of a national day of partying. The BBC Music Live Festival also occurred on the day. At 13:00 towns across the [[United Kingdom]] had bands play [[The Beatles]] hit "[[All You Need Is Love]]" before church bells were rung around the country.
==Entertainers== Amongst others, performers included:
[[Paul McCartney]], [[Bryan Adams]], [[Queen (band)|Queen]], [[Elton John]], [[Shirley Bassey]], [[Eric Clapton]], [[Joe Cocker]], [[Phil Collins]], [[Ray Davies]], [[Dame Edna Everage]], [[Tony Iommi]], [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]], [[Ladysmith Black Mambazo]], [[Annie Lennox]], [[S Club 7]], [[Ricky Martin]], [[Ozzy Osbourne]], [[Rod Stewart]], [[Tony Bennett]], [[Blue (boy band)|Blue]], [[Emma Bunton]], [[Atomic Kitten]], [[Mis-Teeq]], [[The Corrs]], [[Cliff Richard]], [[Will Young]], [[Ruby Wax]], [[Steve Winwood]] and [[Brian Wilson]].
Also performing was the London cast of the musical ''[[We Will Rock You (musical)|We Will Rock You]]''. Several newspapers mentioned the absence of [[The Rolling Stones]]. The Stones said the event conflicted with their upcoming world tour.
== House band == The [[house band]] for the performance consisted of [[Phil Palmer]] (guitar), [[Pino Palladino]] (bass), [[Paul Wickens]] (keyboards), [[Phil Collins]] (drums), [[Ray Cooper]] (percussion), Eric Robinson (saxophone), [[Sam Brown (singer)|Sam Brown]], [[Margo Buchanan]] and [[Claudia Fontaine]] (backing vocals) and the [[Royal Academy of Music]] Symphony Orchestra conducted by [[Michael Kamen]]. Some performers brought their own musicians to the concert.
==Hosts== The concert was hosted by [[Lenny Henry]] and [[Ben Elton]]. Between some acts were short comedy segments featuring [[Meera Syal]], [[Nina Wadia]], [[Ruby Wax]], [[Kermit the Frog]] (voiced by [[Steve Whitmire]]), and [[Barry Humphries]] (in characters as [[Dame Edna Everage]] and [[Sir Les Patterson]]).
==Performances== {| class="wikitable" |- ! Song ! Artists ! Notes |- | "[[God Save the Queen]]" | [[Queen (band)|Queen]] ([[Brian May]], [[Roger Taylor (Queen drummer)|Roger Taylor]]) with house orchestra, |Brian on the roof of Buckingham Palace and Roger played with the orchestra on the stage |- | "[[The Cup of Life]]" | [[Ricky Martin]] | |- | "[[B with Me]]"/"[[Livin' La Vida Loca]]" | Ricky Martin and [[Mis-Teeq]] | |- | "[[Don't Stop Movin' (S Club 7 song)|Don't Stop Movin]]" | [[S Club 7]] | |- | "[[Sisters Are Doin' It for Themselves]]" | [[Annie Lennox]] | |- | "[[You Can't Hurry Love#Phil Collins version|You Can't Hurry Love]]" | [[Phil Collins]] | Roger Taylor took Phil Collins's place on drums for this song. |- | "[[Dancing In The Street]]" | [[Atomic Kitten]] | |- | "[[I Heard It Through The Grapevine]]" | [[Will Young]] | |- | "[[Get Ready (The Temptations song)|Get Ready]]" | [[Blue (English band)|Blue]] | |- | "[[Baby Love]]" | [[Emma Bunton]] | |- | "[[Stop! In The Name Of Love]]" | Mis-Teeq | |- | "[[Sex Bomb (song)|Sex Bomb]]" | [[Tom Jones (singer)|Tom Jones]] | |- | "[[The Long And Winding Road]]" | [[The Corrs]] | |- | "[[Dancing In The Moonlight]]" | [[Toploader]] | |- | [[Goldfinger (song)|Goldfinger]] | [[Shirley Bassey]] | |- | "[[Everything I Do (I Do It For You)]]" | [[Bryan Adams]] | |- | "[[You Can Leave Your Hat On]]" | Tom Jones and Blue | |- | "[[Radio Ga Ga]]" | Queen (Brian May, Roger Taylor), | Phil Collins took Roger Taylor's place on drums for this song, while Roger Taylor did lead vocals. |- | "[[We Will Rock You]]" | Queen (Brian May, Roger Taylor) and the London cast of [[We Will Rock You (musical)|We Will Rock You]] | Brian May did lead vocals. |- | "[[We Are The Champions]]" | Queen (Brian May, Roger Taylor), Will Young and the London cast of We Will Rock You | |- | "[[Bohemian Rhapsody]]" | Queen (Brian May, Roger Taylor), and the London cast of We Will Rock You | Tony Vincent from the cast of We Will Rock You on lead vocals. |- | "[[If I Ruled The World]] | [[Tony Bennett]] | |- | "[[Why (Annie Lennox song)|Why]]" | Annie Lennox | |- | "[[Living Doll (song)|Living Doll]]" | [[Cliff Richard]] | |- | "[[Move It]]" | Cliff Richard, S Club 7 and Brian May | |- | "[[Paranoid (Black Sabbath song)|Paranoid]]" | [[Ozzy Osbourne]] and [[Tony Iommi]] | |- | "[[I Want Love]]" | [[Elton John]] | Pre-recorded in the Music Room inside Buckingham Palace. |- | "[[California Girls]]" | [[Brian Wilson]] | |- | "[[The Warmth Of The Sun]]" | Brian Wilson and [[Eric Clapton]] | |- | "[[God Only Knows]]" | Brian Wilson and The Corrs | |- | "[[Good Vibrations]]" | Brian Wilson with Emma Bunton, Atomic Kitten and Cliff Richard | |- | "[[Layla]]" | Eric Clapton | |- | "[[Gimme Some Lovin']]" | [[Steve Winwood]] | |- | "[[With A Little Help From My Friends]]" | [[Joe Cocker]], Steve Winwood and Brian May | |- | "[[Lola (song)|Lola]]" | [[Ray Davies]] | |- | "[[Handbags & Gladrags]]" | [[Rod Stewart]] | |- | "[[Her Majesty (song)|Her Majesty]]"/"[[Blackbird (Beatles song)|Blackbird]]" | [[Paul McCartney]] | |- | "[[While My Guitar Gently Weeps]]" | Paul McCartney and Eric Clapton | |- | "[[Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band (Reprise)]]"/"[[The End (Beatles song)|The End]]" | Paul McCartney | |- | "[[All You Need Is Love]]" | Paul McCartney, Rod Stewart, Joe Cocker, Brian Wilson, Queen (Brian May, Roger Taylor), Cliff Richard, Ozzy Osbourne and [[Ladysmith Black Mambazo]] | Joined by the rest of the cast part way through the song. |- | "[[Hey Jude]]" | Paul McCartney and the entire cast | |- | "[[I Saw Her Standing There]]" | Paul McCartney | Not broadcast to television, only radio. |}
==Aspects of concert== The concert began with Brian May performing God Save the Queen on the roof of [[Buckingham Palace]] as a guitar solo with support from the orchestra onstage in the Garden far below.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/hi/english/static/in_depth/entertainment/2002/jubilee/concert/1.stm |title=Picture Gallery |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date= |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref> This sequence was spectacularly filmed, including some upward photography of May in full "rock god" mode and shots of the crowd in the Garden below. It has become an iconic moment and Brian May himself has said in interview that he hoped that he would strike the last chord at the same time as the orchestra in the gardens far below. Once it was finished, said May, the arm and fist went up, and the guitar was free, for it had done its work.<ref>''The Queen at 80'' - BBC TV documentary, 2006. Note: DVD only available in the UK at present; British ISBN B000IFS05Y</ref> Ozzy Osbourne recently said in the same interview that this was the greatest moment of his career and pronounced the Queen to be "a beautiful woman."
[[Phil Collins]] played drums for many of the artists, as well as singing his 1983 [[List of UK Singles Chart number ones of the 1980s|UK number one single]] "[[You Can't Hurry Love#Phil Collins version|You Can't Hurry Love]]", with [[Queen (band)|Queen]]'s [[Roger Taylor (Queen drummer)|Roger Taylor]] playing drums. Taylor took late singer [[Freddie Mercury]]'s place by singing lead vocals for the band's 1984 number two hit "[[Radio Ga Ga]]" (which Taylor had also written), with Collins playing drums in place of Taylor.
S Club 7's performance of "Don't Stop Movin'" was announced as the last time the group would be performing as a septet, as [[Paul Cattermole]] had announced his departure from the group prior to the event.
==Royal family commemoration== The event ended with the Royal Family joining the stars onstage. [[Prince Charles]] thanked his mother for her fifty years on the throne, famously beginning his speech with the words, "Your Majesty.....MUMMY!" to the delight of the crowd and bemusement of the Queen.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/uk/2023942.stm |title=UK | Charles tribute speech in full |publisher=[[BBC News]] |date=2002-06-04 |accessdate=2017-07-09}}</ref>
Following this the Queen and [[Prince Philip]] went to light the National Beacon on the Mall. After the lighting of the beacon the largest fireworks show in the history of London took place. During this time different symbols were projected onto the palace including a [[Union Flag]].
==Recordings== A DVD has been issued of the performance. Some portions have been cut, e.g. [[Ruby Wax]]'s monologue, Dame Edna's introduction of Paul McCartney performing "[[Blackbird (Beatles song)|Blackbird]]" and Paul McCartney's spontaneous performance of "[[Her Majesty (song)|Her Majesty]]".<ref>DVD recording ISBN B0000687F4</ref>
A live CD recording of the performance was also released in 2002.<ref>CD recording ISBN B000069003</ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000069003 amazon.com CD listing with listening facility] *[https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0000687F4 amazon.com DVD listing]
{{Elizabeth II}}
[[Category:Concerts in the United Kingdom]] [[Category:Entertainment in London]] [[Category:2002 in British music]] [[Category:2002 in London]] [[Category:June 2002 events]]

{{italic title}} The '''''Play of Daniel''''', or ''Ludus Danielis'', is either of two medieval [[Latin]] [[liturgical drama]]s based on the biblical [[Book of Daniel]], one of which is accompanied by [[monophony|monophonic]] music.
Two medieval plays of Daniel survive. The first is one of the plays in the ''[[Fleury Playbook]]'', a 13th-century [[manuscript]] containing ten liturgical dramas; the text is by [[Hilarius (poet)|Hilarius]], and no music accompanies it. The play itself dates from c. 1140. The second is a 13th-century drama with monophonic music, written about 1227 to 1234 by students at the school of [[Beauvais Cathedral]], located in northern France.<ref>http://www.encyclopedia.com/doc/1O76-PlayofDanielThe.html</ref> A large portion of the text is poetic rather than strictly [[liturgy|liturgical]] in origin; it closely follows the narrative of the [[Bible|biblical]] story of [[Daniel (biblical figure)|Daniel]] at the court of [[Belshazzar]].<ref name="The European Music Series">{{cite web|url=http://www.ou.edu/earlymusic/daniel.html|title=The Play of Daniel: European Music Series|last=Eugene|first=Enrico|publisher=The University of Oklahoma|accessdate=2009-11-18|location=Oklahoma}}</ref>
In the US the latter play was revived in the 1950s by [[Noah Greenberg]], director of the [[New York Pro Musica]]; a commentary in English, written and performed by [[W. H. Auden]], was used in some of their performances. A recorded 1958 performance by the group at the [[Metropolitan Museum of Art]], and featuring boy choristers of the [[Church of the Transfiguration (New York, New York)|Church of the Transfiguration]] as satraps and soldiers, was released by [[Decca Records|Decca]], with sleeve notes by [[Paul Henry Lang]] and [[Dom (title)|Dom]] [[Rembert Weakland]], [[Order of St. Benedict|O.S.B.]], who had discovered the text at the [[British Library]].<ref name="one">Joseph Kerman, ''Contemplating Music''. Harvard, 1985, p. 195.</ref> Since the New York Pro Musica production it has enjoyed many performances among early music troupes.<ref name="Songs of Peace">{{cite web|url=http://www.songsofpeace.com/ncmcmusic/Mus213/play_of_daniel.htm|title=Play of Daniel: Songs of Peace|publisher=Songs of Peace Online|accessdate=2009-11-18}}</ref> Also important in the history of modern revivals of the Beauvais Cathedral version, ''Daniel'' was the 1985 production of the [[Boston Camerata]], staged by Andrea von Ramm, with musical direction by [[Joel Cohen (musician)|Joel Cohen]]. In 2008, The [[Dufay Collective]] and William Lyons released their CD, ''The Play of Daniel'' on the Harmonia Mundi usa label. A new production of the ''Play of Daniel'' by the Boston Camerata, this time under the direction of French-born medievalist [[Anne Azéma]], was presented in Boston in November, 2014. Daniel was played by tenor Jordan Weatherston Pitts.
In 2008, a new production, staged by Drew Minter with musical direction by Mary Anne Ballard in commemoration of the 50th anniversary of the noted [[The Cloisters|Cloisters]] production of 1958, was created, also at the Cloisters. The show has been reprised in subsequent seasons, in 2012 at the Cloisters and in 2013 and 2014 as part of the Twelfth Night Festival at [[Trinity Church (Manhattan)|Trinity Church Wall Street]].
